SOLASStatus: LE RONG: Unknown/unspecified, SEA BARON: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
Whilst M.V. SEA BARON DEPARTING FROM PORT OF JEDDAH, KSA, UNDER PILOTAGE ON 31TH JANUARY 2007, "SEA BARON" WAS AWARE INCOMING VESSEL, M.V.LE RONG, UNDER PILOTAGE ON HER STARBOARD BOW SHOWING GREEN SIDE LIGHT.
"SEA BARON" PILOT COMMUNICATED WITH "LE RONG" PILOT TO PASS PORT TO PORT AND MUTUALLY AGRED AT 1941LT.
WHEN "SEA BARON" ADJUSTED HER COURSE IN ORDER TO AVOID SHALLOW WATER WAS ALSO RIGHT AHEAD ABOUT 5 CABLES AND LE RONG WAS ALREADY SHOWING RED SIDE LIGHT AND CROSSING TO OUR COURSE AROUND 1945LT.
"SEA BARON" PILOT ANTICIPATED "LE RONG" WOULD ALTER TO STARBOARD MORE IN ADVANCE, BUT"LE RONG" KEPT HER COURSE AND CONTINUOSLY CROSSING ON "SEA BARON".
AROUND 1947LT, "SEA BARON" STOPPED HER ENGINE, BUT PORT QUARTER OF "LE RONG" COLLIDED ON PORT BOW OF "SEA BARON". NO MARINE POLLUTION AND INJURED CREW ON BOARD "SEA BARON"
CLASS NK SURVEYOR HANDED RECOMMENDATION FOR TEMPORARY REPAIRS AT THE PORT OF JEDDAH.
AFTER TEMPORARY REPAIRS CLASS NK RE-SURVEYED AGAIN ON HER DAMAGE PORTION AND THE VESSEL WAS PERMITED TO SAIL THE PORT OF JEDDAH.

A survey vessel was alongside a south coast port and was preparing to carry out load testing of a winch that had been subject to weld repairs.  The intention was to load test progressively up to 31 tonnes using  water bags suspended from a certified wire and shackles supplied by the load test contractor.   However it was found that the load cell shackle pin would not fit through the hard eye of the supplied rope.    It was agreed by all parties to use a bowline knotted plasma rope of 70 t breaking strain to hang the water bag from the load cell shackle.   The water bag was lifted clear of the quayside and filling was commenced using a fresh water supply from the quay.  At a load between 10-12 tonnes the sheaves on test were inspected for any structural change.  None was found so filling of the water bag continued.  At a load of about 17 tonnes the rope failed and the water bag fell to the edge of the quay.  There was no damage and no injuries.

The introduction of the knotted rope into a tested lifting system caused the collapse.  Reference books state that the strength of a rope is reduced by at least 50% when knotted.  In this case the rope failed at about 25% of its breaking strain. 

The DPA has promulgated the lessons learnt and warned of the reduction in breaking starin when a knot is fitted to a system.

On 30th January 2007, whilst en route from Tokyo Japan to TComas USA, the container ship EVER UNIFIC encountered very rough weather with hurricane-force winds, high seas and abnormal swells. Sixty six containers were found lost overboard.

THE HYUNDAI CONFIDENCE SAILED FROM PUSAN, KOREA ON JAN.23, 2007 AND WHILE EN ROUTE TO LONG BEACH, USA, THE VESSEL ENCOUNTERED WITH BOISTEROUS WEATHER AND VERY HIGH SEAS, AND LABOURED AND STRAINED HEAVILY SHIPPING MUCH SEAS ON DECK. ON ACCOUNT OF VIOLENT STRAINING OF THE VESSEL, ITS MAIN ENGINE WAS SHUT DOWN. TWO(2) CREWMEMBERS WERE INJURED AROUND 0150LT ON JAN.30, 2007.

Location: 1 Mile East of Dover Harbour Entrance
SummaryOfEvents:
A passenger cargo Ro-Ro ferry had a crew of 66 and 145 passengers onboard.  There were 4 main engines, No 1 engine was out of service for maintenance.  As the ferry left its French port No 3 main engine was shut down in accordance with normal procedures.  The crossing was then made on Nos 2 and 4 main engines.

The engineers attempted to start No 3 main engine when the ferry was about 3 miles from the UK port, but this was unsuccessful.  The master decided to abandon port entry when about 1.5 miles from the entrance. At one mile from the entrance No 4 main engine stopped and the master turned the ferry away from the port.  A short time later No 1 main engine, the final running engine stopped and a blackout occurred.  The emergency generator immediately came on line.  

The master then ordered a tug to assist and shortly afterwards let go of the port anchor, 5 shackles on deck.  An hour later the situation had not been resolved but 2 tugs were by now standing by.  The engineers managed to start one generator but at severely reduced power.  Breakers were operated to allow the generator to supply only the port winch motor.  The anchor was raised and the two tugs towed the ferry into port about one hour later.

The MCA surveyor and the company technical superintendent attended the vessel.  It was found that the low pressure air activated heavy fuel oil filters were defective.  The air from the actuator was pressurising the fuel bowl and forcing air into the fuel system.  It was believed that a fuel problem had occurred and the engineers cross connected the fuel systems.  This caused the air to be transferred into the other fuel system causing the cascade failure of the engines.

The engineers eventually discovered the faulty changeover cock and replaced the seals.

The engines were subsequently trialled with the technical superintendent and MCA surveyors present.  Trial included a one hour full power trial which was trouble free.

Location: Off the South West Coast of Ireland
SummaryOfEvents: While stowing the mornings catch the fishing ship Discovery heeled over to starboard and after a short period capsized. The crew of seven were able to board liferaft and were rescued after four hours by the Oil Tanker Font Commander.

El buque Sierra Nava arribó al fondeadero "C" de la Bahía de Algeciras, con 6 grilletes el día 7 de enero de 2007, en coordenadas I=36º 06,5 N y L=5º 24,9 W en una sonda de 32 m.  El día 28 de enero de 2007 a las 0801 hora local, el buque Sierra Nava estaba fondeado en la Bahía antes mencionada con cinco grilletes en el agua en coordenadas I=36º 06' 37,54" N y L=005º 25' 04,76" W, a 0.655 millas náuticas (mn), unos 1,213 metros y al 260º de Punta San García con fuerte temporal de levante, cuando a primeras horas el viento empieza a arreciar.   Entre las 0801 y las 0855 horas, el buque se desplaza de la situación en sentido lineal  hacia el W de 0.08 mn. A las 0825 comiena un desplazamiento lineal hacia el oeste. Desde las 0843 hasta las 0855 se desplaza 0.075 millas a una velocidad aproximada de 0.3 nudos al rumbo 342º sobre el fondo. A las 0855 de I=36º 06' 39,84" N y L=005º 25' 11,52" se encontraba a 0,605 mn de la zona de costa más próxima y a 0,30 m del veril de 10 m, a 0,29 mn de la zona proihibida de fondeo y a 0,4 mn del punto más próximo del veril de 5 m. Entre las 0855 y las 1130 el buque bornea regularmente en un arco de 50º sobre el punto de pivoteo, desplazándose aproximadamente 0,006 mn entre rumbos N1/4NE y S1/4SW, presentando diferentes proas entre 068º y 141º.

A las 1032 en posición I=36º 36,14"N y L=005º 25' 13,82"W, el buque se encuentra a distancia de 0,25 mn del punto más próximo del veril de 10 m, a 0,25 mn del lìmite de fondeo y a 0,35 mn del punto más próximo del veril de 5 m, muy próximo a un bajo de 1,6 m de sonda. A las 1130 tomo rumbo sobree componente oeste, comenzando desplazamiento lineal hacia oeste. El capitán declara en ese momento que el buque garrea y ordena se vire la cadena. Entre 1130 y 1134 el buque cambia el costado al viento, de babor a estribor, oscilando las proas entre 011º y 054º, con una velocidad media de 1,6 n y recorriendo en 10 minutos (de 1134 a 1144) o,24 mn lineales hacia el oeste. Luego se encuentra dentro del área prohibida de fondeo, a 0,24 mn de la Laja del Ventorrillo y a 0,16 mn del veril de 5 m.

A 1140 se rompe tubería de aceite hidráulico del molinete y se ordena al personal de máquinas rellenar manualmente el tanque de compensación en pañol proa,  se da avante para virar ancla pero buque mantiene casi un grillete en el agua y el capitán manifiesta que sigue atravesado y no responde la máquina. A las 1144 el buque se desplaza hacia el Norte con el costado de estribor al viento y con tendencia de desplazamiento hacia el oeste. Entre 114 y 1149 sigue desplazándose hacia el Norte, y pro primera vez se observa desplazamiento pequeño hacia el Este. Desde 1149 el buque presenta rumbo proa como rumbo efectivo Sur a velocidad de 2.8 n.  A las 1153 se encuentra a 0,189 mn de la Laja de Ventoirrillo y a 0,1 mn del veril de 5 m.  A las 1203 cambia de costado para recibirlo por babor y en 6 minutos se desplaza linealmente hacia el Sur 0,24 mn y linealmente hacia el Oeste 0,12 mn, con aumento de velocidad hasta 5,1 nudos, sin ganar barlovento. El desplazamiento hacia Oeste hace que el buque se encuentra a las 1209 entre los bajos (1,6) entre Los Bordiones y Las Lajas.

Entre 1211 y 1224 toca fondo y el capitán indica que el buque está sobre las piedras, el mismo frena bruscamente desplazamiento avante hacia el Oeste, aproándose progresivamente al viento y disminuyendo su velocidad sobre el fondo.  El capitán envía mensaje de socorro por GMDSS. Se tocan alarmas y la tripulación se presenta al puente. A las 1224 el buque cambia proa al viento y pasa a recibirlo por estribor, cpon velocidad mínima, lo que indica que escaso desplazamiento hacia Oeste se debe al viento intenso capaz de desplazarlo tocando fondo.

A las 1234 el capitán avisa fuego a bordo, se observa humo y tripulación se reúne en castillo de proa para ser rescatados. El helicóptero de rescate llega a la zona de rescate a las 1342 y la tripulación es rescatada sana y salva a las 1420.

El buque queda varado con fuertes daños en costado y el fondo y la sala de máquinas quedan inundados. De ahí que se produce contaminación de los tanques de combustible, estimada de de 100 t.  Se establecen las barreras de contención. 

El Estado español coordina las acciones de control de los efectos del siniestro, especialmente el derrame del combustible del buque. La compañía de salvamento se encuentra con el armador y se inicia plan de reflote.

On the morning of 26 January 2007, the m/v BRITISH MALLARD berthed at the BP Kwinana oil refinery jetty, Western Australia, to discharge its cargo.

At about 17.50 hours LT on 27 January, the ship’s engineers attempted to rectify an elevator fault that had been reported earlier in the day. After making some adjustments to the second deck elevator landing door switches, the electrical technician stepped onto the ladder in the elevator shaft. He then asked the second engineer to let the doors close behind him. 

Soon after the doors closed, the elevator car travelled upwards and after a few seconds it stopped. 

The second engineer could not open the second deck elevator landing doors. He called the third engineer, on his hand held radio, and told him to come to the second deck. The two men tried, unsuccessfully, to open the elevator doors.

The two men then went upstairs and opened the upper deck elevator landing doors. They looked down and saw the electrical technician. He had been trapped by the elevator car and he appeared to be unconscious. Shortly afterwards, the second engineer activated the general alarm.

The master reported the accident to the refinery operator while the crew tried to free the electrical technician. 
Assistance arrived from ashore and, at about 19.20 hours LT, the refinery doctor examined the electrical technician and pronounced him dead.

AFTER LOADING 4,766 M/T OF STEEL PLATES, THE GENERAL CARGO VESSEL "JIN YING" LEFT PORT TIANJIN IN CHINA FOR PORT INCHEON IN KOREA AT 11.54 HOURS ON 24th JANUARY 2007.
AT 06.55 ON 26th JANUARY THE VESSEL GROUNDED NEAR THE MINEOTAN LIGHTHOUSE.
AS A RESULT OF THE GROUNDING, THE HULL WAS BROKEN INTO TWO PIECES AND SANK, BUT NO INJURIES WERE SUSTAINED.

SOLASStatus: KORYO MARU: Unknown/unspecified, NAMHAE PIONEER II: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
Panamanian- registered Chemical tanker Namhae PioneerⅡ (2310 gt, built 1991), with 13 crew (Chinese 7, South Korean 6), and fishing vessel Koryo Maru (4.9 t), with 1 crew (Japanese), were in collision off Sukumo-shi, Kochi Prefecture, Japan.
Namhae PioneerⅡ sustained scratching damage to its bow plate. Meanwhile, Koryo Maru parted in three portions and master became missing.

Le 19 Décembre 2006, le thonier senneur Cap Saint Paul appareille d’Abidjan pour  ses lieux de pêche, dans le Golfe de Guinée.

La marée se passe dans incident ; une pêche  de 370 tonnes est à bord. Le 23 Janvier 2007, le navire étant à 530 milles dans le Sud-Ouest d’Abidjan, des travaux sont entrepris dans le local air conditionné lorsque, vers 15h00, un incendie se déclare dans le magasin machine contigu.

En luttant contre l’incendie, le chef mécanicien observateur est grièvement brûlé.

L’incendie ne pouvant être maîtrisé, le capitaine ordonne l’abandon du navire et le transfert de l’équipage sur le skiff.

Le 24 Janvier au matin, le blessé et 15 hommes d’équipage sont  transférés sur le thonier espagnol Montecelo qui  fait ensuite route pour Abidjan. 

Les navires de pêche Via Zéphyr puis Santa Maria rallient la Zone  de l’accident pour assister le Cap Saint Paul  et les six membres d’équipage restés à bord du  skiff. Ils participent à la lutte contre l’incendie qui  est éteint  le 25 janvier dans l’après-midi.

Le 30 Janvier, le convoi arrive à Abidjan et le Cap Saint Paul est à quai à 18h45.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
Le lundi 22 janvier 2007, le chalutier côtier Manureva appareille en soirée du port de Saint-Cast  pour une pêche de nuit au chalut dans l’Est de la Baie de Saint-Brieuc.

Au lever du jour, inquiète de n’avoir pu joindre son mari au téléphone, l’épouse du patron appelle le sémaphore. 

La coque du navire retourné est alors localisée à quelques encablures du port de Saint-Cast.

Dans des conditions particulièrement difficiles par la suite de l’état de la mer, un rescapé, embarqué en tant que passager, est extrait du navire dont la coque a été découpée par les sauveteurs.

Les trois membres d’équipage du Manureva ont péri dans le naufrage
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 22nd January 2007 the OCEAN GLOBE was approaching the pilot station when the pilot requested that the vessel alter its course. After the pilot boarded the Master realised that the vessel was close to a sandbank, and took avoiding action. The vessel grounded and a forward tank was holed. The vessel was refloated with tug assistance and proceeded to port for discharge of cargo and repair.

On 22nd January 2007, the vessel M/V NOBEL collided with the vessel SI HANG FEN JIN at JINTANG anchorage of NINGBO port This subsequently lead to the sinking of M/V NOBEL at 0330 on 23rd January 2007,  and her cargo of logs drifting at sea. All crew members survived.

A large dry container carrier was alongside a Mediterranean port and was carrying out the routine monthly launch test of the rescue boat.

The boat was brought up to the stowed position, but upon reaching the position the motor failed to stop when the operator tried to stop the winch.  The boat continued to be hoisted but the limit switches also failed to stop the hoist.  The winch continued to heave resulting in the winch mountings failing and the boat and winch falling into the water.

Upon investigation it was found that the limit switch was fully operational.  However one phase of the winch power supply contactor was still in the closed position causing the winch to continue to haul causing the boat to rise under the derrick head, this in turn caused the corroded winch base plate to part from the deck and the boat and winch toppled into the water.

There were no injuries.

SOLASStatus: Fione: Unknown/unspecified, FIONE: SOLAS, La Cangue : Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: AT APPROXIMATELY O1.00 GMT ON 22ND FEBRUARY 2006 A COLLISION OCCURRED BETWEEN 'FIONE' AND THE FRENCH TRAWLER, 'LA CANGUE'. 'FIONE' WAS SAILING IN THE GULF OF BISCAYE AND THE TRAWLER WAS FISHING. THE COLLISION OCCURRED IN INTERNATIONAL WATERS 13 MILES TO THE SOUTH OF ILE D'YEU. THERE WERE NO SEROIUS CASUALTIES, AND MATERIAL DAMAGES WERE MINOR.

On 21 January 2007, the cargo vessel MV NIJORD, was on passage, in ballast from Rouen, France to Riga, Latvia.
At 20.00 hours LT the master took over the navigational watch from the chief officer.  At the time, the vessel was navigating the Irlan Strait.  Visibility was good with a northerly moderate to fresh breeze.  Both radar sets were in working condition and switched on at the time.  The vessel was making a speed of 7.5 knots.  Between 2236 and 2244, Riga Rescue Radio tried to establish contact with the vessel.  After encountering some difficulties in communicating with the master, Riga Rescue Radio warned the vessel that she was heading for shallow water and advised the master to alter course.
The master, who had no look-out at the time, did not alter his vessel’s course and at 22.47 hours LT the vessel ran aground.

When on passage a dry cargo ship suferred a main engine failure. After several hours at anchor off the Dutch Coast, during which it was attempted to re-start the engine, the vessel was towed to Ijmuiden for repairs. The ship was attended on arrival by the engine manufacturers accompanied by the ship's superintendent. Investigation showed that the major contributory cause of the engine failure was a leaking valve in the main control air start system. This caused excessive wear on the air distributor, which in turn prevented the engine from being started. The ship manager has 10 engines of this type in its fleet and has instructed that all air distributors be checked for excessive wear. Instructions for the main air start valve to be checked have also been issued.

At about 02 :45 hours on January 2007, a fire broke out on board the ship Lindy Lou which was moored at Lyme View Marina, Adlington. One person died as a result of the inferno, which quickly swept through the ship. The other occupant, the owner of the boat, suffered from serious burns and effects of smoke Inhalation.

Location: Entre Las Palmas, Islas Canarias y Praia, Cabo Verde
SummaryOfEvents: On 20th January 2007 at 00.31 hours LT, a fire was detected on board vessel KEVIN (Panama flag). At that time she was en route from Las Palmas (Canary Islands) to Praia (Cabo Verde), and she had 13 crew members on board. The fire started on the main deck near the kitchen, and was apparently caused by an electric arch into the main electric panel which provided electricity to that deck. Within 15 minutes the fire had spread rapidly to the crew dining room, cabins, etc. and black smoke was found in the officer's space and also on the bridge. One crew member died as a result of the smoke, and five more requested assistance. Some areas of the ship apparently did not comply with all of the SOLAS requirements (Chapter II - tiles of the deck covered with polyurethane, wooden and plastic furniture all of which is highly flammable and produces great quantities of smoke). The spreading fire crossed horizontal and vertical limits of the zone, into the main deck, without structural divisions or thermal barriers. It took four hours to extinguish the fire by using CO2 extinguishers, personal fire-fighting equipment, water fire hose in adjacent external areas and cabins. It was very difficult to get to the source of the flames because of the location of the zone. Three rooms were condemned after the fire, all the crew dining room and part of the kitchen were affected by fire, water and smoke, and also the actuator (engine) was afftected because it was flooded by the water used to fight the fire.
PLEASE SEE THE ATTACHED SEA PROTEST CAP.T OF HO FENG NO.6

Location: Aubenelbe, near the racon Buoy Elbe
SummaryOfEvents:
On 19 January 2007, the bulk carrier Lena was sailing from London to Hamburg. Since the pilot was to come on board at the Elbe Buoy, the bosun received an order around 08:00 hours, to rig the pilot ladder on the starboard side.
The freeboard of the ballasted carrier LENA was approximately 11 metres so it was decided to rig the so-called "combined accommodation/pilot ladder". This comprises a classic rope ladder and a permanently installed gangway. One the rope ladder was rigged, the gangway was lowered to an angle of 40° so that its landing rests next to the rope ladder. 
The stanchions were set up and the handhold stanchions secured. Then the bosun wanted to connect the end of the gangway with the rope ladder using a rope end.
No one saw him falling overboard, but his shout was heard and the crew immediately instigated the necessary rescue measures.

The distress call to the Maritime Rescue Co-ordinating Centre (MRCC) in Bremen activated different rescue units including a helicopter that sighted the accident victim at 09:18 hours and recovered him at 09:21 hours. At 10:05 hours, he was delivered to the hospital in Oldenburg. Due to being in the cold water for too long, he died in hospital on 23 January 2007
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
AT AROUND 0000-0400 HRS 19th JANUARY 2007, PIRATES CLIMBED THROUGH PORT ANCHOR CHAIN PASSING THROUG THE HAWSE PIPE AND FORCE ENTRY BY LIFTING THE STEEL SCREEN COVER OF HAWSE PIPE. THE PIRATES ONCE ON FORECASTLE DECK, THEY FORCEFULLY OPEN THE BOSUN STORE HATCH COVER EVEN IT WAS FULLY SECURED WITH PADLOCK AND BARS.

AT AROUND 0410 HRS 19th JANUARY 2005, DUTY OFFICER NOTICED THAT THE MOORING ROPE REELED INNER PART PORTSIDE WINCH IS MISSING. HE IMMEDIATELY RAISED THE ALARM AND CALLED ALL CREW TO CHECK THE SITUATION AT FORECASTLE DECK. AND IT WAS CONFIRMED WE HAD BEEN BOARDED BY PIRATES AND THIEVES. SHIP PROPERTY STOLEN AS FOLLOWS: 2 COIL MOORING ROPE, SUEZ CANAL LIGHT-1 PC, MOTOR BLOWER 12 PCS, BELL GONG 1PC, AND 2 COIL POLYPROPYLENE ROPE.

Location: In Chitose Port, Hiroshima Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 18th January 2007 the training ship SPIRIT OF MOL (registered Panama, 4,888 gt, built 1972) was under construction in the dockyard at Chitose Port. At 16.25 hours LT a fire broke out, resulting in damage to the crew quarters, and dealy in the construction.
All the workers evacuated the ship safely.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: The vessel suffered serious structural failure, resulting in flooding of the engine room, and subsequent abandonment. The vessel was towed towards a safe port in the United Kingdom, however on voyage it became apparent the vessel may break up or sink and she was intentionally beached in Branscombe Bay on the south coast of England. The cargo was removed along with the bunker fuel while beached. The vessel was then separated in two pieces for recycling. The forward section was towed to a shipyard in Northern Ireland and recycled. The aft section was broken up for recycling in-situ.
On 16th January 2007 the fishing boat The Millers was in the North Sea, when a crew member fell overboard whilst putting nets into the water. The crew member drowned

SOLASStatus: SEGESTA JET: Unknown/unspecified, SUSAN BORCHARD: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
ON 15 JANUARY 2007 DURING THE PASSAGE OF MESSINA STRAIT, SPEED 16,5 KNOTS, THE M/V "SUSAN BORCHARD" COLLIDED WITH HSC "SEGESTA JET" THAT WAS IN NAVIGATION FROM REGGIO CALABRIA PORT TO MESSINA PORT.
AS RESULT OF THE COLLISION THE "SEGESTA JET" SUFFERED RELEVANT DAMAGES AND TWO CREW-MEMBERS OF THE SAME SHIP LOST THEIR LIFE.

ANCHOR DRAGGED DURING ANCHOR DUE TO HEAVY WEATHER AND VESSEL DID NOT SUFFER ANY DAMAGES.
THEN MASTER REQUESTED FOR PILOT TO RE-ANCHOR AT SUITABLE POSITION

Location: In vicinity of port of Ventspils (Latvia) outer roadstead
SummaryOfEvents: On January 11, 2007 at 19.35 hours (UTC+3) GOLDEN SKY departed from the port of Ventspils with cargo of 24983.370 mt of “Muriate of Potash” in bulk. At 22.00 hours the ship experienced some problems with the  main engine. The crew tried to resolve the problems and GOLDEN SKY stopped and recommenced her voyage several times with various courses and speed. The captain of the ship decided to return to Ventspils anchorage, because the main engine problems couldn’t be resolved by the crew. On January 12th the Captain received permission from Ventspils VTS to return to outer anchorage. GOLDEN SKY returned and anchored at designated anchorage place “V3”.  On January 13 pilot boat tried to reach GOLDEN SKY to deliver three shore technicians, who were to assist in main engine repairs. Due to high waves the pilot boat was unable to deliver the technicians onboard GOLDEN SKY. In the afternoon of January 14,  the wind changed to NW and wind speed increased to 25 m/s, then after midnight up to 33 m/s. At 23.00 hours GOLDEN SKY started dragging anchor and drifting towards the shore. On January 15 at 02.06 GOLDEN SKY grounded in position φ=57o28.12’ N; λ=021°35.10’ E. At 0628 LAF helicopter evacuated 16 crew members from GOLDEN SKY. Captain and 7 crew members remained onboard. Remaining crew was evacuated on January 17.

The Trans Frej left Järnverkskajen (Ironworks Quay), Oxelösund, without a pilot. The ship was loaded mainly with steel, wood and containers in the cargo holds and containers on deck. At departure the weather was bad, strong wind with showers of snow and rain. The master took the ship from berth out through the arkipelago. About 10 minutes after departure also the third officer came to the bridge but did not take part in the navigation of the ship. At one waypoint the TRANS FREJ took the wrong course and got her first touch to the bottom at the Stora Rönnskär ground and grounded on Runnskärsgrund. The ship rested on the ground from approximately frame 35 to frame 85. The sea level was 70 cm above the normal.

On 13th January 2007 the research vessel FUGRO MERIDIAN was waiting off Aberdeen for berthing instructions in adverse weather but with good visibility. At approximately 01.00 hours LT, the vessel ran lightly aground, the general alarm was sounded and the vessel was re-floated under its own power. There was no damage to the vessel, no pollution and no injuries were reported.

Cambodian-registered general cargo vessel Syenite (683 gt), with 14 crew (Russian), ran aground on the shore off Ishikari-wan Port, Hokkaido, Japan.
The vessel was refloated by tugs, however, no injuries and no oil leak. The vessel sustained scratching damage to its bottom keel.

Location: The West coast of Norway, near Bergen
SummaryOfEvents:
At 1730 GMT, 12 January 2007, The 180-metre vessel SERVER hit rocks in a storm off the west coast of Norway, near the island of Fedje, and split in two some four hours later.  The ship ran aground due to reduced power resulting from a severe storm.
An estimated 370-tonnes of oil seeped from the vessel.  The ship was not carrying any cargo but contained 585 tonnes of  heavy fuel and 72 tonnes of diesel for its own use.  The 25-person crew were safely evacuated from the ship by helicopter.  There is concern for the longer-term environmental impacts, as there are a number of bird sanctuaries in the area The bow section of the stricken vessel was towed to a protected harbour in Agotnes on Saturday. The stern of the vessel sank.

The container ship JRS Canis was at Bremerhaven on 11 January 2007. After loading and unloading, the crew checked that the containers were secured, the Ship departed at 23:06 under pilot advice heading for St. Petersburg.

According to the weather forecast for the German Bight, there was a storm developing that night originating from west to west-northwest 8 to 9 gusting to 11 Bft, with sea rising to 8 metres.
The pilot disembarked on 12 January 2007 at 00:45 hours. The ship’s speed was adapted to the sea conditions. After passing buoy 4a, German Bight Traffic was informed that the JRS Canis was on her way to the Kiel Canal. At this point, the ship was pitching and rolling severely.
A true course of 330° was applied and the ship was sailing at about 7 kn. After passing an oncoming ship, the course was altered to 060° and the speed was changed to about 15.5 kn. 
This wind was approaching from 285° at force 9 Bft. 
At 02:40 hours the ship keeled briefly to each side, several times, by up to 20°.  The bridges crew were able to see that the container stack on the port side leaned inwards while the container stack on the starboard side shifted outwards. At the same time 10 containers were lost overboard.
The German Bight Vessel Traffic Service was immediately informed of the incident. Then an inspection was made on deck to determine the damage. The decision was made to continue the voyage to the Kiel Canal at reduced speed.
At 07:12 hours, the JRS Canis moored at Brunsbüttel where the first investigations began onboard.

On 11 January 2007, the Marshall Islands flag general cargo vessel TASMAN RESOLUTION was berthed starboard side to Mount Maunganui wharf at the Port of Tauranga.  The vessel had been operating on the New Zealand coast for the previous 12 days after completing a voyage from the Far East.
At approximately 2240 on the evening of Thursday 11 January, the ship's Boatswain, together with the Third Officer, and two Able Seamen, was assisting to move pontoon covers from number five hatch and stow them on top of number three hatch.
After connecting the Number 1 gantry crane to the centre pontoon cover of number 5 hatch, the Boatswain climbed off the starboard side of the pontoon cover onto the main deck.
At approximately 2244, the gantry crane lifted the pontoon cover off number 5 hatch coaming and started to travel forward along the deck towards number 3 hatch.  Meanwhile, the Boatswain was still between the number 5 hatch coaming and the inboard side of the moving gantry crane.
At approximately 2231, a Stevedore noticed a body on the deck inboard of the gantry crane track and adjacent to the starboard side of number 5 hatch.  He immediately raised the alarm.
The body was found to be that of the Boatswain. He had suffered massive injuries and was dead when discovered.
The accident was immediately investigated by Maritime New Zealand.

On 11th January 2007 the m/v SIERRA LARA sailed into Skagen port during windy weather. The vessel subsequently made contact with the quay, and also the breakwater, with the result that the propeller was damaged.

SOLASStatus: EIKO MARU NO. 16: Unknown/unspecified, KATSURAGISAN: Unknown/unspecified
Location: At the private sea berth of Seibu Oil Co. off Yamaguchi Ube Air port, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
Panamanian- registered Crude Oil Tanker Katsuragisan (160292 gt, built 2005), with 26 crew (Croatian: 8, British: 1, Filipino: 15, Yugoslav: 2), and General Cargo Eiko Maru No.16 (749 gt, built 2006), with 6 crew (Japanese), were in collision at the private sea berth of Seibu Oil Co. off Yamaguchi Ube Air port, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan.
Katsuragisan sustained denting/cracking damage to the starboard midship.
Eiko Maru No.16 sustained denting/cracking damage to the bow resulting in water ingress into the forepeak tank below the waterline. Two crew members of Eiko Maru No.16 were injured.

At 05.35 hours on January 9th 2007, the vessel LT UNICA of LLOYD TRIESTINO DI NAVIGAZIONE SPA collided with the fishing boat ZHEJIAOYU6027 on the Southeast sea, 23 miles from DACHEN island（28°16.′700N /122°17.′100E). The fishing boat was destroyed and sank, killing one man and injuring four others.

Japanese - registered Crude Oil Tanker Mogamigawa (160,229 gt, built 2001), with 24 crew (Japanese: 8, Filipino: 16), and US Submarine Newport News collided near the Straits of Hormuz.
Mogamigawa sustained denting and hole damage to its ballast tank, however, after repair work the vessel headed for Singapore.
There ware no oil spill and injuries in both vessels.

Failure to close a stern ramp before sailing, resulted in the ramp making contact with a fender pile on departure. The ramp was forced out of its securing machanism and lost overboard.  It was standard practice to close this particular ramp in the early stages of loading, however, on this occasion the shore supervisor was engaged elswhere and the deck supervisor became distracted with the remaining cargo operation.

Location: On the beach, 1 kilometer to SE from Funagata Fishing Port, Tateyama City, Chiba Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
Under the heavy weather, Cambodian-registered general cargo ship Yang Tong (1106 gt, built 1982), with 9 crews(Chinese), ran aground on the beach, 1 kilo-meters to SE from Funagata Fishing Port, Tateyama City, Chiba Prefecture, Japan due to machinery failure.
The ship is not able to refloat by its own power, however, no injuries and no oil leak. JCG dispatched its helicopter to rescue.

EXTRACTS FROM THE REPORT OF THE MASTER

ON 3RD JANUARY 2007 DURING THE FINAL STRIPPING OF A FORWARD TANK INTO AN AFT TANK, THE DROPVALVE LEADING INTO THE AFT TANK WAS OPENED.  THE LINE LEADING TO THIS DROPVALVE WAS PRESSURIZED BECAUSE TWO CROSS-OVER VALVES AT THE MANIFOLD HAD INADVERTENTLY BEEN LEFT IN THE OPEN POSITION. THIS OPENING OF THE DROPVALVE INTO THE AFT TANK RESULTED IN CARGO FLOWING INTO THE TANK INSTEAD OF TO SHORE VIA THE CONNECTED HOSE.  
THE ACTUAL SPILL TOOK PLACE THROUGH THE PRESS/VAC VALVE AND FROM BETWEEN THE HATCHCOAMING AND LID INTO THE TANK IN QUESTION.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
A small general bulk cargo vessel had been alongside Goole from 23 December 2006 for the Christmas period.  She sailed in ballast during the early evening of the 2 January 2007.  On exiting the Dutch River Berth the vessel suffered a main engine failure and the captain immediately ordered the anchor to be let go.  

The next 2 hours was spent on trying to restart the engine but this was unsuccessful.  It was initially suspected that the engine had suffered a fuel supply problem.  The electrical generators continued to function normally.  The harbour authorities decided that the vessel should move from the anchorage and the management company arranged for the vessel to be towed the short distance to the berth.

The vessel was attended by an engineer and MCA and Class surveyors the following morning.  The engine operates on a dry sump system.   It was found that the main engine oil charge was still in the engine sump and had not been transferred to the daily lube oil tank.  The engine stopped because the low lube oil pressure trip operated, thus protecting the engine.  Further investigation found that the lube oil scavenge pump was defective.  The pump was removed and overhauled by a local engineering company and refitted the following day.  The engine was successfully test run and the vessel sailed a short time later.
On January 1st 2007 at 21.52 , M.V.UNI-ACCORD collided with Chinese cargo vessel M.V.LONG XING whilst approaching the port.

At 10.34 hours LT on 31st December 2006 the QUEEN ELIZABETH 2 was en route from Madeira to Southampton when a passenger was discovered missing, presumed lost overboard.
The vessel turned around to retrace its path and search the route, along with assistance from Portuguese resources coordinated by MRCC Lisbon. The search was abandoned after dark.

On 30 December 2006 the dry bulk cargo ship Maike sailing under German flag was in her voyage from Rostock, Germany, To Perth in Scotland. At about 11:25 hours, the ship’s command ordered two crew members to check a bilge alarm in the bowthruster room. Both of them had put on protective rainwear and hard hats.

At that time the ship was in the Dutch exclusive economic zone (EEZ) within the Traffic Separation Scheme “Terschelling German Bight”. In this area, the wind was blowing from southwest with average forces of 7 to 8 Bft and gusts of 9 to 10 Bft. The wave heights were between 3 and 4 m.

The bilge alarm proved to be a false alarm that had been triggered but condensation water. In order to bail the water by condensation water by means of a bucket, one deck hand remained in the bowthruster room, while the other one on deck received the bucket handed up to him. At about 11:35 h, the seaman standing on was hit by a wave coming over the stem, whereby he lost his hard hat. When an even greater wave arose, he sought shelter behind the opened hatch cover, which was secured by means of a retaining hook. Due to the impact of the wave, the retaining device broke, so that the hatch coaming, whereby he suffered several injuries.
 
The injured seaman was recovered by a rescue helicopter after he had been given First Aid and then transported into the hospital of Groningen, The Netherlands. He survived the accident and returned to Germany one week later for further treatment.

No harmful substances were released by accident

Location: North Sea 1.5 miles from the semi submersible Rig J W Mclean
SummaryOfEvents:
On 30th December 2006 the M/V OCEAN VISCOUNT was operating in the North Sea about 1.5 miles away from a semi submersible platform.  The weather was poor with winds gusting to Force 9 and worsening when the vessel suffered a main engine failure at approximately 08.12 hours LT.

The coastguard was alerted and checked the availability of helicopter and lifeboat resources.  In the meantime the engineers onboard checked the fuel system which they believed may have been agitated by the poor weather.  The fuel system was found to be functioning correctly and the generators continued to function.

The engineers were able to start the engine but it would not continue to run.  The Aquamaster retractable thruster was used to affect some steerage control.  As this was happening a towing vessel in the vicinity made her way to standby the vessel and the CG continued to carry out routing hourly safety checks with the vessel.  The vessel was eventually taken under tow and arrived safely alongside some 8 hours later.

Further investigation showed that the drive shaft to the Roots mechanical turbo charger had sheared due to metal fatigue at the step down near to the second supporting bearing.  Spares were being sourced from Norway.

ON 30TH DECEMBER 2006, AT ABOUT 04.00 HOURS LT IN APPROXIMATE POSITION LAT.12º 06' N, LONG 047º 51' W, THE M/V VESSEL ALBANE EXPERIENCED STEERING FAILURE. THE  VESSEL CONTINUED HER  VOYAGE TOWARDS DESTINATION PORT USING EMERGENCY STEERING AT SLOW AND VARIABLE SPEEDS.
THAT VESSEL DROPPERD ANCHOR ON 2ND JANUARY 2007 AT POINT LISAS ROADS, WHERE IT AWAITED REPAIR OF STEERING GEAR

SOLASStatus: CEBU ROSA: SOLAS, MEIJI MARU: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: ON 28th DECEMBER 2006, AT PORT OF HAKATA JAPAN, VESSEL LOST CONTROL DURING UNBERTHING (BY MASTER`S SELF PILOT), DUE TO STRONG WIND (SUDDEN WIND DIRECTION CHANGE). AS A RESULT, VESSEL HIT HER BULBOUS BOW(STARBOARD SIDE) TO THE WHARF AND COLLIDED WITH BOW PART OF M/V MEIJI MARU WHO WAS BERTHING BEHIND M/V CEBU ROSA. DETAILS ARE WRTTEN IN ATTACHED MASTER`S STATEMENT.

Location: Off coast of Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea
SummaryOfEvents:
THE M/V MARINE EAGLE, VOY. 0630, SAILED FROM VLADIVOSTOK, RUSSIA AT 16.00 HOURS LT ON 26TH DECEMBER 2006 AFTER COMPLETING LOADING OF WOODEN PULP FOR DISCHARGING AT GUNSAN PORT, KOREA,  WITHOUT ANY PROBLEMS.
THE WEATHER CONDITIONS WERE: ROUGH SEA, WIND DIRECTION NORTH, WIND SPEED 15M AND 5M SWELL.

IN THE MORNING AT 08,00 HOURS LT ON 27TH DECEMBER 2006, STRONG VIBRATIONS WERE FELT AND NOISE HEARD COMING FROM LOWER AREA OF ENGINE ROOM.

AT 11.30 HOURS LT ON 27TH DECEMBER 2006 THE VESSEL´S MAIN ENGINE WAS SUDDENLY STOPPED. AS A RESULT OF IMMEDIATE INSPECTION OF THE ENGINE ROOM, IT WAS FOUND THAT THE INTERMEDIATE SHAFT WAS CUT OFF, AND ALL EMERGENCY STATIONS WERE ACTIVATED.

On 22nd December 2006 the Oil Product Tanker STOC REGINA was at quay in Gulfhavn, Denmark for discharging of oil mixed water. A surveyor wanted to take samples from the cargo. The second officer was in the navigation house and asked an AB by radio to make sure to take samples and to assist the surveyor when he arrived on deck. The AB walked to a tank cleaning hatch where he started to loosen the finger nut on the hatch. As soon as he started to loosen the finger nut, gas was released from the hatch. The AB immediately left the spot,  but fell down unconscious beside a ladder. An apprentice who was close by tried to move the AB away from the place, but as he himself felt dazed he had to get away. He was able to inform the second officer of what had happened before he too fell down more or less unconscious on the poop deck. The second officer ran down to the deck and by holding his breath he was able to reach the hatch and close it. The AB and the apprentice were taken to hospital.
The investigation shows that there were no MSDS available onboard the vessel. On the vessel it was more or less customary to take samples by opening the tank cleaning hatch. Although the vessel was fully equipped with a closed sampling vapour lock system, the tank cleaning hatches was seen as a more convenient method on this occasion as the cargo was regarded as relatively harmless. The AB acted by force of habit when he opened the tank cleaning hatch. The tank in question was filled to about 75 per cent which contributed to the high concentration of gas. The Investigation also pointed out the importance of using all available equipment and systems in the way they are meant to, and that MSDS always should be available onboard before the loading commences.

The M/V "RYONG AK SAN" left the port of HAEJU, DPR of Korea on 25 December 2006 at 09.00 hours LT, laden with 2800 tons of magnetite. While en route to the port of HEBEI, China, her discharging port, she was capsized off the coast of DALIAN in extremly adverse weather conditions.
The vessel was sunk due to the strong winds and high seas which caused the shifting of the bulk cargo on board.

SOLASStatus: ARROWANA BARCELONA: Unknown/unspecified, OCEAN PRESTIGE: Unknown/unspecified, POPPY: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 26th December 2006 at 07.00 hours LT the Master of the Liberian oil tanker POPPY went onto the bridge and at 09.37 hours LT , while the ship was at Brothers Island, he took over the command of the ship from the 2nd Officer, who was on watch duty. the Bridge team consisted of the master, 2nd Officer, AB, Wheelman and Training Navigating Officer as lookout. At 11.09 hours LT POPPY was passing the north line of the west bound traffic lane proceeding to the anchoring position recommended by the vessel's agents, and the Master reported that the ship was heading NNE'y in order to pass two cables clear of two double banked ships. However, POPPY came into contact with the M.T. Arowana Barcelona, which sustained damage mostly to the stem/ bow/forecastle region, and also the Ocean Prestige which sustained damage to her bow permanent steel fender. It was later found that the Master was in breach of collision regulations as he failed to comply with Company's procedures regarding safe navigation, displayed poor judgment in following rules and made inadequate risk assessment.

On 25th December 2006 the general cargo ship TRUST BUSAN was off the coast of Busuanga when, at approximately 12.00 hours LT she  suffered major engine damage as the engine was automatically shut down by the safety system due to low low lub oil pressure.
While the crew sounded the engine, it was observed that an oil-water mixture was leaking through the sounding plug and crankshaft seal near the fly wheel.
The crank case doors were opened up and crankcase inspected. Piston no 5 was found damaged and the liner was leaking heavily. The crew proceed to remove the cyl cover etc.
Distance to Mariveles appr 120 NM. (appr same distance to Batangas). The vessel was towed to Mariveles.

InitialEvent: COLLIDED WITH A MOBILE DRILLING PLATFORM 205 (USA)
SummaryOfEvents:
ON 24TH DECEMBER 2006 THE BLUE STAR COMPLETED DISCHARGING AT THE PORT OF VERACRUZ, WHERE IT ALSO UNDERWENT A PARTIAL ANNUAL CLASS INSPECTION, AND PROCEEDED TO VERACRUZ, ANCHORAGE TO COMPLETE THE CLASS INSPECTION. AT 07.10 HOURS LT ON DECEMBER 24TH 2006 THE CHIEF OFFICER S. HAMIBUR RAHMAN, WHO WAS ON WATCH, INFORMED THE MASTER THAT PORT ANCHOR WAS DRAGGING AND ASKED HIM TO COME ON TO THE BRIDGE. 
THE MASTER INFORMED THE CHIEF ENGINEER AND INSTRUCTED THE BOSUN TO BEGING HEAVING THE ANCHOR, AND ORDERED THE MAIN ENGINE TO GO SLOW AHEAD, TO EASE UP ON THE ANCHOR LINE. AT 08.01 HOURS LT THE WIND INCREASED DRAMATICALLY AND THE MASTER ORDERED MAIN ENGINE FULL AHEAD, BUT THE VESSEL COULD NOT PICK UP SPEED BECAUSE OF THE STRONG WINDS. THE MOBILE DRILLING PLATFORM MODU 205 WAS ABOUT 0.4 MILES, AND AT 08.18 HOURS LT THE BLUE STAR COLLIDED WITH THE MODU 205.
On 22nd December 2006 at 18.24 hours LT the general cargo vessel LEONIS experience machinery problems, but the ship remained fit to proceed.

SOLASStatus: SEA PLAIN NO 2: Unknown/unspecified, WOOYANG ACE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: ON 21ST DECEMBER 2006 AT 23.27 HOURS LT THE M/V WOOYANG ACE WAS NAVIGATING THE NORTH PASSSAGE OF NAGOYA PORT, WHEN PORT SIDE SHELL OF THE VESSEL COLLIDED WITH THE STARBOARD SIDE OF THE M/V SEA PLAIN NO.2

At about 23.00 hours LT on 21st December 2006 an OS discovered a fire on no. 1 deck in the accommodation of the container ship DANIA CARINA.  On hearing the shouts of the OS, the master activated the fire alarm, and the crew were mustered. The fire quickly generated a lot of smoke and all ventilation and power supplies to 1 deck were stopped. An emergency fire pump was also started, and hoses and extinguishers were prepared to allow entry to the area. Two firemen in BA tried to enter the accommodation, but were forced back by the high temeperatures. The main engine was stopped, and boundary cooling was established . At about 23.40 hours LT, two firemen entered the accommodation and reported that the fire was extinguished. However, at about 00.10 hours the fire was found to be spreading via void spaces above the deckhead linings. The fire was eventually extinguished at about 02.00 hours LT, after water hoses had been used through penetrations made into the galley, and officer's and crew messes. Subsequent investigation indicated that the fire started in the vicinity of the sauna. The cause of the fire was considered to be either a fault with the sauna heater, a fault in the lighting in the sauna, an electrical short-circuit, or by crew leaving items on top of the sauna heater. Following a review of the evidence, the ship's surprintendent concluded that the fire was probably started by an electrical short-circuit in the wiring of the electrical items fitted in the sauna.

SOLASStatus: HUMBER ENERGY: Unknown/unspecified, RED EAGLE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 21st December 2006 at 19.21 hours LT the HUMBER ENERGY and the RED EAGLE collided in a busy estuary at the entrance to a channel. Both vessels' bridges were manned by a full bridge team according to their company procedures. As a result of the collision, Red Eagle suffered minor damage to her hull above the water line and there was paint damage and slight indentation to the bow of Humber Energy.  There were no injuries to any personnel or any pollution.

Location: ENTRY IN THE PORT OF BRINDISI
SummaryOfEvents: ON 19TH DECEMBER 2006 AT 06.00 HOURS LT, IN VERY BAD WEATHER CONDITIONS AND HEAVY RAIN, THE CAPTAIN OF THE M/V VLORA ORDERED ENGINE DEAD SLOW AHEAD PROOCEDING FOR BOARDING PILOT. SUDDENLY AT ABOUT 06.10 HRS, A TUG BOAT WAS SEEN AND HE HAULED TO STARBOARD, BUT COLLIDED WITH BREAKWATER THAT COULDN'T BE SEEN DUE TO THE HEAVY RAIN.

On 16th December 2006 the container ship MOL WISDOM  was alongside S/S at the TCP terminal in Montevideo.
At about 01.50 hours LT on 17th December 2006, the wind suddenly gusted to 65 to 75 knots without any warning. The Aft ropes started running out and started parting.
At 01.51 hours LT the emergency alarm rang, and forward and aft stations called.
The staff requested tug and pilot´s assistance. Port replied a tug was already on its way.

Forward stations manned at 01.53 hours LT.
E/R manned at 01.55 hours. HRS ford ropes started running out and parted.
The vessel then started drifting away from the berth. After informing port Control, Port & Starboard anchors were dropped to prevent vessel drifting onto the break water. The engines were also used intermittently. 
At 02.00 hours the first tug arrived to assist.
At 02.20 hours the second tug also came for assistance. A pilot boarded at 03.22 hours LT.

Between the hours of 03.30 to 11.40 the vessel repeatedly sustained gale force winds, but the vessel maintained her position using three tugs / bow thruster and two anchors.
At 12.15 hours LT the vessel was brought back and made fast to the berth. The wind force reduced to 15 Kts.

On 15 December 2006, the trawler PAIX DU CIEL was engaged in fishing about 0,3 nautical miles off Hourtin beach, in depths of about 6 metres when, at about 14h15, she was hit by a high wave and capsized.  
The wheelhouse was immediately destroyed as she rolled over.  The Skipper who was alone in the wheelhouse was thrown overboard and managed to swim ashore but the other 2 crew members who were resting in the crew's quarters were trapped inside and died.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On the afternoon of 14 December 2006, the high-speed passenger ship VILLUM CLAUSEN departed from Fredericia bound for Rønne. 
The ship did not carry any passengers. When entering Rønne Port in the evening there was a strong wind from southwest and west and a high sea.
The bridge watch team felt as if the ship was almost “surfing” on following seas, when VILLUM CLAUSEN was approximately three times a ship’s length from the entrance to the harbour. According to the statements, this caused the ship to alter its course unintentionally and it was forced to port side. Thus, the ship was heading direct towards the pier-head north of the outer entrance to the harbour. 
The master and the chief officer did not succeed in getting the ship back on its course, and it became clear to the master that a collision with the pier was inevitable. Therefore, he concentrated on reducing speed as much as possible.
VILLUM CLAUSEN collided with the pier-head at approximately 1938 hours.
Shortly after the accident, the bridge crew managed to get the ship safely alongside in the harbour by the ship’s own power.
The ship was moored at approximately 19.48 hours LT.
Three crewmembers were slightly injured in the collision. 

According to a prognosis by DMI (Danish Meteorological Institute), the significant wave height was within the limits according to the permit to operate issued by the Danish Maritime Authority

The Division for Investigation of Maritime Accidents is of the opinion that the main cause for the ship’s loss of steering control was that the ship was surfing on a following wave. The ship’s speed in the sea was of significant importance to why the bridge watch team was not able to get the ship back on course.

The ship’s stern – and thereby also the water jets – may have been lifted out of the water, thus the manoeuvrability of the ship may have been reduced momentarily

The ship’s speed had a significant influence on the sequence of events – both with regards to the possibility of altering the dangerous course towards the pier and the possibility of stopping the ship after the control of the steering had been lost.

On 7th December 2006, the bulk carrier VULTURNUS left Singapore for Shihu  port off Fujian province with a cargo of 28000 tonnes. At 09.40 hours on 14th December, VULTURNUS slightly deviated from the channel and stranded on an unmarked rock, causing damage to NO3 port ballast tank. No one was injured.

On 13th December 2006 the container vessel FLOTTBEK  was en route from North Europe to Canada when she encountered heavy weather in the reported position. During the morning, speed was reduced to ease the movement of the vessel. However in the afternoon, the winds and seas increased, and at one stage the vessel was hit by two large waves.
At 15.40 hours LT the first wave rolled under the vessel and when it reached the midship's position, the bow fell down about 8-10 meters. At this time the second wave came over the bow and the vessel shipped green seas.
When it was safe to go forward, it was found that the vessel had sustained some damage to the hull above the water line. Some damage to the radio and navigation equipment was also reported.
On 11th December 2006 the tanker WORLD DYNASTY was in open sea when it was found that the reamer bolts of propeller shaft had broken. The ship remained fit to proceed.

On the evening of December 8, 2006, shortly before 2235, while in heavy weather, a deckhand was swept overboard from the leeward side of the vessel. An air and sea search ensued, but it was unsuccessful.

On 8th December 2006 the fishing vessel MICHEL was laid up alongside in the Bay of Biscay.
The vessel had no current certification as a FV, the last UKFVC had expired in May 2005, and she was uninsured. At 04.55 hours LT, during bad weather, the vessel broke its moorings and drifted out of the harbour, to sea, without contact with any other vessels or the quays. There was no one on board at the time.
The vessel grounded on a beach near Saturraran, coming to rest on its side in shallow water.
The fuel and lube oil on board caused minor pollution.

see http://www.tagzania.com/item/37037
On 7th December 2006 the bulk carrier SEA HONESTY was in international waters when she experienced machinery problems and was temporarily unable to proceed.

On 6th December 2006, on  theCambodian-registered general cargo ship Sakurakawa (1195 gt, built 1985), with 8 crew members (Chinese), a fire broke out at 23.03 hours LT off Izu O-Shima, Japan when a load of scrap steel caught fire. 
All crew were rescued by Japanese Coast Guard.

Location: Off Mogusa Fishing port, Matsumae Cho, Hokkaido Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
At 11.50 hours LT on 6th December 2006, in heavy weather, the Panamanian-registered general cargo ship Outsailing 5 (1972 gt), with 14 crew members (Chinese), ran aground on the shallows off Mogusa Fishing port, Matsumae Cho, Hokkaido, Japan due to machinery failure. 
All crew were rescued by Japanese Coast Guard, but oil leaked into the sea.

In contrary to the previously made plan, discharge of an oil rig does not find place on the planned located inside the port area, but off the coast in waterdepth of about 50 m. During discharge the heavy load vessel is partly submerged to 21.5 m depth. Due to unexpected list of the rig, the rig doesn't float at calculated submerged depth. Vessel is submerged further and trimmed forward to release the rig from the deck. Once the rig is fully afloat, the heavy load ship starts to sink in an uncontrolled way. Crew abandones the ship and is rescued. 
Vessel recovered and reconditioned.

SOLASStatus: FRANCESCO GANCITANO: Unknown/unspecified, ROYAL COOLER: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: COLLISION IN OPEN SEA BETWEEN THE ITALIAN FISHING BOAT "FRANCESCO GANCITANO" AND ST. VINCENT AND GRENADINES SHIP "ROYAL COOLER". THE COLLISION HAS HAPPENED WHILE THE "FRANCESCO GANCITANO" WAS IN FISHING ACTIVITY WITH COURSE 295° AND SPEED 3 KNOTS. THE "ROYAL COOLER" WAS STEERING WITH COURSE 284, SPEED 20 KNOTS. THE F/B HAS BEEN CRASHED AT STERN BY THE M/V AND IT HAS SUNK IN A FEW MINUTES. 2 PEOPLE DIED AND 2 WERE MISSING.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: At about 07.00 hours LT on 6th December 2006 the passenger ship STATENDAM narrowly avoided running aground on her approach to Melbourne. This was the result of poor bridge management. The tip of her stabilizer was possibly damaged.

On 5th December 2006 the container carrier HERTFORD was on passage across the North Sea in very severe weather, which was gusting force 11.

The vessel had suffered a tube leak on the combination boiler which was due to boiler tube fatigue.  Soon afterwards, at 05.15 hours LT while off the Dutch coast, the vessel suffered an electrical blackout.  The captain immediately ordered that both anchors be let go.  The engineers traced the fault to an electrical circuit board on the generator’s excitation circuit.  This caused the generator to shed its load onto the only other, parallel running, generator.  That in turn tripped the supply breaker on overload protection, causing the blackout.

The fault was rectified within 3 hours and the generators proven to be running correctly.

The port anchor was successfully hauled in but as the starboard anchor was being recovered the weather deteriorated again and the anchor paid out to within 2 shackles of the “bitter end”.  Unable to haul the cable in the captain contacted the DPA who approved jettisoning the anchor and cable.

ON 4TH DECEMBER 2006 A C/E WAS WELDING ON DECK WHEN SPARKS CAUSED  MINOR BURNS TO HIS CHEST. THE C/E TREATED THE INJURY HIMSELF FOR A FEW DAYS. AFTER DISINFECTING WITH ALCOHOL HE APPLIED "NADLAN" OINTMENT AND A BURNS DRESSING,AND FROM 12 th DECEMBER HE TOOK 2 CAPS OF AMPICILLINE THREE TIMES DAILY.

The M/V NORTHUMBERLAND arrived at its Italian discharging port on 3rd December 2006 with No 3P tank gauge inoperative.  The usual safety meeting was carried out between the crew and terminal loading representative and 2 firemen allocated to the ship during the period of discharge; however, the terminal staff were not informed of the defective gauge.

It was decided to carry out work on the gauge during cargo discharging operations.  The chief officer and 2 of the ship's gas engineers were working on the top of the tank which had the defective gauge.  The gauge top had been opened and methanol was being used to free the components.  The methanol was contained in a plastic bucket.  It is notable that the normal Permit to Work procedures had not been carried out and no electrical isolations had been made.  At about 15.55 hours LT the bucket of methanol fell from the domed tank top and hit the deck, at which point it burst into flames about 2.5m high.  The chief officer and gas engineer were on the tank top as the fire started.  The duty officer saw the flame and immediately pushed the emergency cargo discharge shut down button.  At the same time he took a dry powder extinguisher and put the fire out.  The fire lasted less than one minute.  The master, hearing the emergency shut down ran to the deck.  Although the fire was short lived the fire alarm was not used and the terminal staff nor port authorities were not informed.

Soon after the fire was put out the area was cleaned and painted.  At 16.12 hours LT the terminal staff instructed the chief officer to stop discharging cargo.  Fire officers went onboard as well as the port chemist.  Discharging recommenced at 18.36 hours LT.  At about 19.05 hours LT the vessel was checked again by the port authorities.  At 19.48 hours LT the master received a request by UHF to stop pumping and proceed to an anchorage.  At the same time the master advised and ordered Ch Eng to report the incident to the Company.  He did so by telephone.

Location: at Pier No.33 of the Songak Warf of the port of Pyeongtaek-Dangjin
SummaryOfEvents: At 14:30 hours on 2 December 2006 the ship Eastern Paris 1 berthed on her portside at the Pier No.33 of the Songak wharf of the port of Pyeongtaek-Dangjin and started loading mixed metal scrap at 19:30 on the same day. While the cargo loading and unloading work was begun  at 08:00 hours on 4 December, a fire broke out at the starboard ahead of the cargo hold in the Pier  No.33 of the Songak wharf of the port of Pyeongtaek-Dangjin at 08:25 hours on position 36°59.28 N and 126°43.24 E. As the fire further  spread to the inside of the cargo hold, fire fighters from the neighbouring fire station and coast guard boats were dispatched to the accident  area and joined the fire  fighting operation. At 02:00 hours on 5 Decembers, the fire was finally contained. The fire left the shell plating and structures around the area of the fire of the Eastern Paris 1 heated and damaged. As part of the Cargo loaded in the cargo hold was burnt and became useless, some of it was unloaded in the wharf.

On 4th December 2006 at 04.00 hours LT a stand-by safety vessel was on passage when the master reported that the vessel was taking in water from the port rudder stock. It was unclear at the time whether the vessel had struck an object causing damage or whether it was as a result of bad weather and high seas, or due to a manufacturing defect. The crew removed ballast from the after end of the vessel to reduce the water pressure on the rudder stock.

The CG maintained a 2 hour watch as the casualty made her way towards Lerwick using the bow thruster to assist in steering. As the vessel approached Lerwick, steerage became more difficult with the increasingly bad weather and a tow was connected as a safety precaution.
On arrival at Lerwick the operators arranged for divers inspection and found that the port rudder had become detached below the keyway on the tiller arm. The recovered upper section was removed and the section forwarded for metallurgical analysis. The outcome of this investigation is not known but the failure is suspected to be due to metal fatigue exacerbated by severe weather.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
On 3rd December 2006 the general cargo ship EREN C was en route from Odessa, Ukraine to Genoa, Italy. ETA to Istanbul Bosphorus was same date at approx. 14.30 LT, which was reported to
Vts control station by Vhf Ch 11. The Vts control station rescheduled the entering time to 20.50 hours LT.  Engines were stopped at 12.30 hours LT in position 41 31N - 029 11E 17 MN off from Turkish Control Station ( Sea state 4/5ENE- Visibilty 6NM ) and vessel started drifting.
At 18.45 hours LT the vessel sailed towards Istanbul Bosphorus and duly arrived at the entrance at 20.50 hours LT. During the South bound sailing period with course True 219 degree at 21 22LT in position Sariyer seperation zone it was noted that the vessel was reducing speed by it self, (without any engine control order), from 9.4 nts to 7.8 nts.
The Master immediately called ECR, and  according to the Chief Enginer's information it was established that the engine´s reduction gear had serious problems. Smoke was seen coming from the area of the Engine Room. At 21.42 hours LT in position Yenikoy-Koybasi area, the Master ordered a forcastle gang to make ready each anchor to let go-Alesta Ferro Funda -position. 
The  helmsman reported that he could not "steady as she goes"  and at the same time  speed had reduced 3,2 nts and with emergency call from ECR, Main Engine has been stopped.
The Master immediately ordered the helmsman to Hard A Port in an attempt to keep the vessel position at a safe distance from shore side.
He also reported to Vts Control Sector Kavak from Ch 12 that his vessel was not under command, and requested an emergency call and other southbound vessels to be notified. It was also reported that the vessel was ready to drop anchor at same place nearest distance from shore, but was told by Vts Center station not to drop anchor at our posittion and tug boat Kurtarma 3 was on its way to assist.  The main engine was stopped and the Master intended to command the vessel with the rudder only and tried to keep to its position, and was ready to drop anchor in position 1,5 cables away from nearest shore line at Koybasi area.
When Tug Boat Kurtarma 3 approached at 21.56 hours LT she kept her position on  starboard side.  The Master then called the owner and  reported the emergency situation. On receiving affirmative reply at 22.04 hours LT the Master gave the forward rope to Tug Boat from the forecastle deck and vessel maintained its position form shore. This position was reported to Vts control station once again from Ch 12.
Again Vts Center reported that Bosphorus Pilot was on its way to assist entrance to anchorage area by towing.
At 22.22 LT Bosphorus pilot went on board., and at 22.23 hours LT, with the assistance of the tug boat as an NUC the vessel proceeded toward Buyukdere Anchorage area.
At 22.35 hours LT the vessel dropped anchor ( starboard anchor 4 shackles in the water ) and at 23.45 hours LT the tug boat line let go.
The vessel did not use second tug boat for any assistance.
At 23 .55 hours LT the Bosporus Pilot went away, and the ship owner and shore staff came on board.

On 2nd December 2006 the the research vessel DISCOVERY was operating off the Scottish coast and had gone to anchor, seeking shelter, but was slowly drifting.  While at anchor the vessel suffered an electrical failure at 02.12 hours LT.  The fault was traced to an AC module of the Electrical Sharing Loading control.  As the module failed the load automatically transferred to the other running generator, causing it to trip out on overload.

The problem was identified, and at 02.28 hours LT, power was restored and sufficient bow thruster power was available to arrest the drift.

Location: 300 MILES TO THE EASTWARD OF CAPE LOPATKA
SummaryOfEvents: At approximately 11.00 hours on 1st December 2006 the bulk carrier RUBIN PEARL was at sea when the vessel took a 22 degree roll. A Cadet who was standing on top of the cargo deck lost his balance  and fell overboard. Efforts to recover the man were unsuccessful. Safety lines were not used and the man was not wearing a lifejacket.

On 30th November 2006 the hopper/dredger NAUTILUS capsized during dredging operations due to overloading. The vessel had dumped only part of the cargo when she capsized further, resulting in the death of three people.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
AT 09.24 LT ON 26TH NOVEMBER 2006 THE VESSEL ARRIVED AT KARWAR ROADS AND ANCHORED. THE VESSEL WAS ON BALLAST WAITING TO BERTH FOR LOADING IRON ORE.
AT AROUND 02.00 HOURS LT ON 30 NOVEMBER 2006 THE VESSEL WAS NOTICED TO BE DRAGGING ANCHOR DUE TO ROUGH WEATHER, WITH WINDS GUSTING AT 50 KNOTS. THE VESSEL`S ANCHOR WAS HEAVED UP WITH THE MAIN ENGINE RUNNING AHEAD AT 92 RPM, BUT DUE TO THE WEATHER AND LIGHT CONDITION OF THE VESSEL, THE VESSEL COULD NOT BE SWUNG INTO THE WIND AND CONTINUED DRIFTING TOWARDS THE SHORE. IT RAN AGROUND AT APPROXIMATELY 06.00 HOURS LT ON THE OYSTER ROCKS ON THE STARBOARD SIDE. THIS RESULTED IN A BREACH OF THE BILGE TANK AND THE SHIP SIDE, CAUSING THE ENGINE ROOM TO FLOOD AND RESULTING IN LOSS OF POWER.
THE VESSEL THEN LISTED ABOUT 10 DEG TO PORT.
BECAUSE OF THE BAD WEATHER AND THE SITUATION ON BOARD, THE CREW MEMBERS WERE EVACUATED BY HELICOPTER WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF THE INDIAN COAST GUARD AND NAVY.
THERE WAS NO IMMINENT THREAT OF POLLUTION. WE UNDERSTAND THAT THE SECOND OFFICER HAD DONNED HIS LIFEJACKET AND WAS TRYING TO CROSS OVER TO THE ROCK BY GOING DOWN THE LADDER ON THE STARBOARD SIDE. HE WAS LATER SEEN IN THE WATER BUT COULD NOT BE FOUND DURING THE SEARCH OPERATIONS.

SOLASStatus: SHOSEI MARU: Unknown/unspecified, TRUST BUSAN: SOLAS
Location: In Seto Naikai off Toyoshima, Kagawa Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 28 November 2006 at aproximately 17.45 hrs LT the South Korean-registered general cargo ship TRUST BUSAN (4690 gt, built 1997), with 15 crew (Korean: 9, Myanmarese: 6), and Japanese-registered oil tanker SHOSEI MARU (154 gt, built 1983), with 3 crew (Japanese), were in collision in Seto Naikai off Toyoshima, Kagawa Prefecture, Japan
TRUST BUSAN sustained denting and scratching damage to her bow. The shell plating of SHOSEI MARU below sea level "of port mid.", was cracked, resulting in water ingress into the engine room. Oil spilled through the crack and the vessel was unable to navigate under its own power. As a consequence, the SHOSEI MARU was a total loss.

On 28th November 2007 the bulk carrier PORT ALICE departed port of Dalian and arrived Brisbane pilot Station at 02.30 hours LT. The pilot came on board at 04.06 hours LT on the same day. When the vessel was under way in the east channel a small boat was seen on the port side at 06.47 hours LT, and immediate instructions were given to stop the engine urgently. The small boat was observed to see if she required assistance, and the pilot requested the water police  to help through VHF.  At 07.42 hours LT one police boat arrived at the PORT ALICE and another went to the small boat, to carry out the "Alcohol Test" on the pilot and the Master, the results of which were okay. The policeman on the PORT ALICE asked the policeman on the small boat whether there were any problems, to which he replied that there was no damage to the boat, including the fishing net, and no injuries. The policeman filled in a "Marine Incident Report" and interviewed the Master and Pilot on board the PORT ALICE.  The policeman disembarkerd at 08.15 hours LT . Another pilot came on board at 09.50 hours LT, and the vessel completed berthing at 12.35 hours LT.

ON 28TH NOVEMBER 2006 THE M/V ‘NUEVA FORTUNA’ , IMO No. 9228112,  IN LOADING CONDITION  (40.691 MT GRAIN PRODUCTS - LOADING PORT: ROZARIO / ARGENTINA, DISCHARGING PORT: CAPE TOWN) UNDER PILOT, RAN AGROUND IN RIO PARANA RIVER / ARGENTINA (390.4 KM)  .
THE VESSEL WAS REFLOATED ON 6TH DECEMBER 2006 AT 19.20 HOURS LT AND GROUNDED AGAIN AT VILLA CONSTITUCION ANCHORAGE (361.7 KM) , DURING ANCHORING MANOEUVRES. REFLOATED AGAIN THE NEXT DAY AT 15.55 HOURS LT.  
DURING THE GROUNDING AND REFLOATING OPERATIONS NO INJURY, NO DAMAGE AND NO POLLUTION WERE OBSERVED.  
AFTERWARDS ALL ESSENTIAL INSPECTIONS WERE COMPLETED.
SHE RESUMED SEA PASSAGE ON 12TH DECEMBER 2006 AT 14.30 HRS.

Location: Off Kunisaki-cho, Toba-city, Mie Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: At 22.40 hours LT on 27th November 2006 the oil product tanker YORYU MARU, (499 gt, built 1993), loaded with a heavy oil of 900 kl ran aground off Kunisaki-cho, Toba-city, Mie Prefecture, Japan. An oil spill was observed. There were no injuries.

Location: DELTA DOCK TERMINAL WHARF, RIO LA PLATA
SummaryOfEvents: On 27th November 2006 the bulk carrier ROSELLA, which had sailed from Rosario with a full load of maize from Argelia, was under pilot command when she collided with Delta Dock Terminal wharf at Rio de La Plata.

During her approach to Fredericia, Denmark on 25th November 2006, a fire broke out in the engine room of the tug boat FRIGGA. The ship's crew extinguished the fire by the use of fire extinguishers and the fixed fire extinguishing plant in the engine room.
The ship was able to proceed to Middelfart on its own propulsion. After extinguishing the fire it was not possible to proceed on the ship's own propulsion, and therefore it was towed to Fredericia.

On 24th November 2006 the M/V OTILIA was shifting from berth to loading position alongside another vessel in the Port of Rotterdam. At 10.30 hours LT the alarm for "Remote Control Failure" sounded repeatedly whereupon the propeller pitch went into the position of 100% ahead and stuck in this position.  The ship was unable to maneouvre, and the main engine was stopped.
A tug was ordered to assist the ship to go alongside.
With the assistance from the manufacturers of the propeller plant it was established that two servo valves had stuck in a given position due to some air pockets in the system, possibly caused by a recent oil change.

ON 24TH NOVEMBER 2006 THE CONTAINER SHIP HYUNDAI PRIMORSKIY WAS ENTERING THE PORT OF PUSAN UNDER THE MASTER´S INSTRUCTIONS. AS A RESULT OF HEAVY WEATHER THE SHIP´S STARBOARD BOW WAS TOUCHED WITH ORYUKDO BREAKWATER, RESULTING IN HULL AND BREAKWATER DAMAGE.
NO INJURIES TO CREWMEMBERS, NO POLLUTION

On 24th November 2006 a crew member was found to be missing on board the bulk carrier NIKKEI-PHOENIX. A search was carried out between 06.00 and 06.30 hours, but with no success, and at 06.30 hours LT the vessel retraced its course, arriving at its last way point at 14.30 hours LT.  
RCC (USCG) air craft search was also conducted, but the casualty could not be found. The search and rescue operation was abandandoned at approximately 18:00 hours on 24th November 2006.

SOLASStatus: LIBERTY V: Unknown/unspecified, PRINCESS AVIV: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 22nd November 2006 the general cargo ship PRINCESS AVIV was at anchorage when she was hit by a storm. She ran aground on the coastline, but had apparently not sustained significant damage to her hull. However, another vessel in the vicinity LIBERTY V, was also at anchor but as a result of the storm her anchor chain was broken and she collided against the fore of the PRINCESS AVIV. The two ships remained in contact for three days, during which time the PRINCESS AVIV sustained serious damages.

On 21st November 2006 the bulk carrier ZOSCO ZHOUSHAN left the inner anchorage of Flushing at about 22.30 hours, and the Flushing pilot left the ship at 02.25 hours LT on November 22nd. At 04.00 hours LT the vessel was proceeding to her destination, following the outboard fairway at about 80 RPM, at which time everything was running smoothly. Soon afterwards the Chief Engineer ordered the vessel to be stopped immediately as the turbocharge was explosive. We dropped anchor in the fairway at 04.24 hours LT on 22nd November 2006. Fortunately, nobody was injured in this accident.

Location: At the Kanmon Route of Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
The Korean registered general cargo ship Wide Force was on passage form the port of Yokohama in Japan in ballast condition to the port of Kwangyang in Republic of Korea.

The Korean registered general Cargo ship Tomika left the port of Kashima in Japan to the port of Ulsan in Republic of Korea.

At 19:40 hours on 18 November 2006, the two ship collided 700 meters off the Light Buoy 27 in the Kanmon Route of Japan in the direction of 172°, in position 33°55.25 N and 130°56.00 E. The tomika suffered indentation and damage in the shell plating and handrail of the center of the portside.

The Wide Force sustained indentation and damage in the shell plating of the bow of the starboard.

SOLASStatus: GUO TONG: SOLAS, TAIKEI MARU NO.68: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Off Funa Island in Kanmon Straight, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 17th November 2006 the General Cargo Ship GUO TONG (1498 gt, built 1984), with 10 crew on board (Chinese), and fishing vessel Taikei Maru (296 gt, built 2003), with 6 crew on board (Japanese), were in collision off Funa Island in Kanmon Straight, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan.
The GUO TONG sank, and 3 crew members  died. The Taikei Maru No.68 sustained damage to its bow, but returned to home port by its own power. All 6 people on board Taikei Maru No.68 were unharmed.
GUO TONG was en route to China from Tokushima Prefecture, Japan. Meanwhile, Taikei Maru No.68 was on the way to Shimonoseki Port from China.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
ON 17th NOVEMBER 2006 AT 18.02 HOURS LT THE CONTAINER SHIP MSC JILHAN WAS STEERING A COURSE OF 265 (T), WHILST ANOTHER  VESSEL, THE M.V. REMO, WAS ON AN ALMOST RECIPROCAL COURSE IN OPPOSITE LANE.  BOTH VESSELS WERE FOLLOWING THE BUOYED RECOMMENDED ROUTE OF KEIL CANAL APPROACHES.  AS PER INITIAL ARPA INFORMATION, C.P.A. OF M.V. REMO WAS 0.4 NM AND PASSING CLEAR OF OWN VESSEL.
M.V. REMO SUDDENLY STARTED TURNING TO PORT TOWARDS MSC JILHAN, WHICH ATTEMPTED TO ATTRACT ATTENTION OF M.V. REMO OVER VHF AND BY FLASHING THE ALDIS LAMP.  MSC JILHAN  THEN ALTERED COURSE TO STARBOARD TO AVOID A CLOSE QUARTER SITUATION BUT WAS RESTRICTED IN FURTHER ALTERATION DUE TO PRESENCE OF A VESSEL BEING OVERTAKEN ABEAM AT RANGE OF 0.6 nm.
AT 18.06 HOURS LT THE BOW OF M.V. REMO MADE CONTACT WITH MSC JILHAN PORT SITE ABREAST OF BAY NO.9.
10 CARGO CONTAINERS, 4 CONTAINER PEDESTALS, 2 LASHING PLATFORMS AND SOME LASHING MATERIAL WERE DAMAGED. MSC JILHAN COMMUNICATED WITH M.V. REMO OVER V.H.F.  TO CONFIRM THE SAFETY OF THEOTHER SHIP AND CREW.
SHIP'S NAME'S WERE EXCHANGED M.V. REMO REPORTED THAT FAILURE OF STEERING SYSTEM CAUSED THE SWING OF THE SHIP'S BOW TOWARDS OWN SHIP.

SOLASStatus: GUI HE YU 80063: Unknown/unspecified, HAI NAM 36: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 16th November 2006 about 20.00 hours LT, there was a collision between M/V“HAI NAM 36” under Vietnam's flag and M/V “GUI HE YU 80063” under China's flag in position 21°16.860′N,108°54.682′E, approximately  15 miles southwest of the coast of Beihai port. Four crew members were injured in the collision,  and the M/V“GUI HE YU 80063”sank, representing a financial loss of about RMB485,000 yuan.

At 08.00 hours LT on 16th November 2006 the Saga Spray was discharging pellets when a crew member and a stevedore went down a staircase leading to the cargo hold. The staircase had been locked for about 7 weeks. They went down without checking the atmosphere in the space and as a consequence both became unconscious. The crew member died and the stevedore was seriously injured due to the high concentration of carbon monoxide in the space. Seven other persons were seriously injured during the rescue operation.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On 15th November 2006 the cargo ferry KRONPRINZ FREDERIK was in the port of Rostock but the vessel began to sway and picked up too much speed astern. The master who was maneouvering was not able to stop the ship before it hit the fender beams with a perceptible bump.

On 15th November 2006 at approximately 06.00 hours LT, the m/v FU YANG was discharging timber logs in the port of Kandla, using no. 2 crane. The crane became dislodged from the stowing base and fell into the cargo hold no. 3, resulting in serious injuries to one deck worker. He was given medical assistance on shore but died of his injuries on 30th November 2006. 
The vessel was later inspected by the Port Authorities and other regulating bodies.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SOLASStatus: BIANCO BULKER: SOLAS, NING YANG HANG 13: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On 14th November 2006 the M/V BIANCO BULKER  (PANAMA) en route from ZhenJiang, China to Zhoushan, China, with two pilots on board, collided with M/V NING YANG HANG 13 near the NO.81 buoy in Chang jiang River at 16.12 hours LT.
The main cause of the collision was the failure of the MV BIANCO BULKER's crew to look out with caution, as well as neglecting to give out the correct sound signal in accordance with the Rules.

On 13th November 2006 at 09.00 hours LT problems were experienced with no.3 fuel pump for main engine on board the bulk carrier JACARANDA.
On the same day at 10.30 hours LT the vessel anchored at 34-32.8N, 134-43.1E to carry out checks and discovered severe damage to the fuel pump; they could not repair the damage as they did not have the appropriate spare parts.
At 13.12 hours LT the vessel set sail to return to Hirohata for repairing.
At 14.42 hours LT she dropped anchor at Hirohata anchorage, position 34-44.1N, 134-37.8E.
On 14th November 2006 the repairs were completed and the vessel returned to her voyage.

On 13th November 2006 at 09.00 hours LT a problem with no.3 fuel pump for main engine was found on the bulk carrier JACARANDA. At 10.30 hours LT the vessel anchored at 34-32.8N, 134-43.1E in order to check the fuel pump, and realised that the damage was severe, and that no spares were on board.
At 13.12 hours LT the vessel returned to Hirohata for repairs.
At 14.42hours LT she dropped anchor at Hirohata anchorage position 34-44.1N, 134-37.8E
On 14th November 2006 at 07.27hours the repairs were completed and the vessel continued her voyage.

On 10th November 2006 the M/V SEA VETERAN discharged part of her cargo and was en route from Montreal to Hamilton, Canada with the remaining cargo on board of about 19,000 metric tons of Urea Fertilizer in bulk.
On 11th November 2006 at around 13:32 hours LT whilst maneuvering to enter IROQUOIS LOCK under pilot assistance (Capt.
