Tetzlaff) the vessel's stern starboard side hull plating, which was about 3 to 5 meters above the water, hit the lock approach wall, causing damage to the vessel's hull plating (steel structure).  Initial inspection showed that the vessel had sustained damage of about 10 meters in length and about 1-2 meters in width, but nobody was injured, there was no pollution and no damage to the lock approach wall.  
At 13.29 hours LT, prior to the time of impact, the pilot ordered to let go the starboard anchor in an effort to stop the bow from further swinging to the port. The attempt was not successful due to a strong wind coming from 025 degrees direction wind speed about 15 to 20 Knots, which subsequently pushed the vessel bow more to port.  The main engine was then stopped and at 13:30 hours full astern pilot tried to swing bow to starboard without succes.  This was followed by emergency full ahead and a moment later the vessel's astern hit the lock wall.
This incident was reported to Sea Way inspector and at 16:20 hours the inspector boarded the vessel to check the damage sustained by the vessel.  Sea way inspector issued in writing a letter with recommendation that the damage should be repaired at Hamilton and that vessel's classification society should be informed.

Location: near west pilot station for Scapa Flow, Orkney Islands
InitialEvent: OTHER - fatalities in heavy weather conditions
SummaryOfEvents:
While outbound from Scapa Flow and transiting the Pentland Firth, the Singaporean registered tanker FR8 VENTURE shipped two large waves over the bow.  This resulted in the death of two able seamen (ABs) and serious injuries to an ordinary seaman (OS), all of whom were working on the forward mooring deck.  
The waves also caused minor damage to the ship.

At 06.59 hours LT on 11th November 2006 the RoRo cargo ship MAERSK DELFT was commencing departure from the loading berth in Northern France when it suffered a total loss of power. The vessel managed to clear the loading berth and the master then ordered the starboard anchor to be let go. The ship drifted across the harbour and made contact with another Quay in the way of the starboard quarter.  The vessel then fell bodily onto No4 Ro-Ro berth and the ship's hull plating was pierced due to the contact.
The initial investigation identified that No2 DG main breaker had come out, which in turn caused a progressive shut down of power generators and, ultimately, the total loss of electrical power and main engines. 
This was the result of the failure of the shaft generators to load share with the DG's.  After testing various modes of shaft generators against DG's, the company  produced a written procedure ( ECR and bridge)  for the operation of a single shaft generator with the bridge giving permission to go on shaft when safe to do so.  The incident was the accidental stopping of a main engine powering a shaft generator.  The power management system worked as designed.  The stopping of the ME was from a remote panel  which has a check system built in which requires three definite requests.  This was a human factors related incident and showed that care needs to be exercised when stopping engines at sea, as positive reporting could have prevented the accident.  Standing orders have been amended and an action plan agreed.

Location: Southern Ocean, south of Hobart, Tasmania
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 0530 on 11 November 2006, a fire started in the engine room on board the Antarctic supply ship L'ASTROLABE.  The fire was fed by a spray of diesel fuel from a leak that had developed in the starboard main engine fuel system.
The ship's crew closed the remotely operated fuel system quick closing valves, which shut down all of the main and auxiliary engines, isolated all ventilation to the engine room and then operated the engine room's fixed fire extinguishing system.
By 0620, the fire had been extinguished and the crew worked to restart the ship's main and auxiliary engines.  By about 1200, L'ASTROLABE had resumed its passage to Hobart using its port main engine and, by 1030 on 12 November, the starboard main engine was also back in service.
The ATSB's investigation found that the fire was caused by a leak of diesel fuel, probably in the form of a spray, from a temporary blanking arrangement on the starboard main engine.  The fuel ignited when it came into contact with the hot surfaces of the starboard main engine.

SOLASStatus: WULANSARI: Unknown/unspecified, ZHE PU YU 42263: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: An collision accident occurred at about 0330 hours local time (Beijing time) , the 11th of November 2006, between a Singapore Chemical vessel “WULANSARI” proceeding from Ningbo to Singapore and a local fishing vessel “ZHEPUYU 42263” which was owned by Lin HaiQiang. “WULANSARI” left the accident site after the accident without permission and the accident resulted in the sink of “ZHEPUYU 42263”, six fishers lost.
Consequences1: Ship remains fit to proceed,Loss of life

Location: River Weser, on the Nordergründe at buoy A6
SummaryOfEvents:
The fishing vessel HOHEWEG with four crew members on board was on a voyage from the River Weser to the River Elbe estuary when at about 20h44 CET on 8 November 2006 approximately 1.5nm north of the Alte Weser navigation channel buoy A6 the radar echo as well as the AIS target of HOHEWEG disappeared from the screen.  The first distress message from HOHEWEG was transmitted by the EPIRB at 20:44:45h without stating a position, whereupon search and rescue measures were initiated.
After a targeted search, the wreck of fv HOHEWEG was located in approximately 8 metres water depth on the Nordergründe on 15 November 2006. Divers went down for the first time on 17 November 2006.
The body of the 38-year-old deckhand was washed ashore in the fore-tide terrain off Pellworm on 7 December 2006 and the body of the 47-year-old helmsman was washed ashore at Kaiser-Wilhelm-Koog on 8 December 2006.  The 18-year-old apprentice was only discovered off Heligoland on 10 June 2007 and the 27-year-old master is still missing.
The wreck of HOHEWEG was salvaged on 23 July 2007 and taken to Bremerhaven where after completion of the investigations, the fishing vessel was scrapped.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
On 8th November 2006 at 14.00 hours LT the container ship PERTH grounded after altering course too early as it entered Izmir Bay from the Izmir Korfezi.
The vessel's position was being fixed by one method only, and no parallel indexing or clearing bearings were used in passage planning.
Communications between the bridge team were poor and neither radar nor echo sounder were being monitored.
Vessel was refloated after 24 hours by salvage tugs. Weather remained favourable throughout and vessel was undamaged as a result of the grounding

Location: In Kasado Bay, Kudamatsu City, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 7th November 2006, in heavy weather and strong winds, the vehicles carrier MARINA ACE (54332 gt, built 1987), with 22 crew members on board (Filipino), ran aground on the shallows in Kasado Bay, Kudamatsu City, Yamaguchi Prefecture.
MARINA ACE was later refloated by tug boat. There were no injuries and no oil spill.

ShipsInvolved: JACOB SENIOR (IMO 8605399), V O S REBEL (IMO 7235692)
SOLASStatus: JACOB SENIOR: Unknown/unspecified, V O S REBEL: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 6th November 2006 the standby ship VOS REBEL was in the North Sea when she was struck by the fishing vessel JACOB SENIOR. The  Fishing vessel should have give way to the standby-vessel, but saw her too late to take action to avoid the collision. The accident ocurred near oil platforms with lots of backlight. The VOS REBEL was rendered unfit to proceed.

On 6th November 2006 the bulk carrier ROSELLA was approaching the Parana river pier at 22.36 hours LT. Due to the pilot's mishandling of the vessel's speed when approaching the pier, and also to his giving an unclear order about the rudder, there was no time to avert the accident. As a result, the vessel's starboard side hull made contact with the pier at Parana River 132Km, which caused heavy damage to the ship´s hull. No injuries were sustained and no pollution caused.

At 15.30 hours LT on 1st November 2006 the ro-ro vessel FINNBIRCH was en route from Helsinki to Aarhus when she capsized and sank in heavy weather in the Baltic Sea. The accident was investigated by the Swedish Accident Investigation Board and the report will in due time be forwarded to IMO.

Location: About 2.4 nautical miles notheast of King's point, N.L.
SummaryOfEvents: Shortly after 08:00 Newfoundland standard time on 01 November 2006, about 2.4 nautical miles northeast of King’s Point, N.L., the small fishing ship Cape Fin-Tose capsized while pumping mackerel from a purse seine belonging to the Cape alongside.  The fours persons aboard abandoned the ship into a small boat tied alongside. The overturned ship remained afloat for about two hours before sinking.

Location: Off Credan Head in the Waterford Estuary
SummaryOfEvents: On 1 November 2006, the FV “Boyne Harvester” had left Dunmore East to fish for cockles off Credan Head in the Waterford estuary. One crewman slipped and fell over the stern of the ship and was drowned.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On October 31st, 2006 at 11.49 hours LT the vehicles carrier YOHJIN  was entering Kiel Canal Holtenau Lock, with pilot on board. As a result of gusting winds, the vessel touched her port side on the lock's two wooden fenders, which left one of them slightly damaged and the other needed to be removed. There was no damage caused to the vessel, and no crew members were injured.

SOLASStatus: EBISU MARU: Unknown/unspecified, SEIL SUN: Unknown/unspecified
Location: About 2 km from He Saki Lighthouse, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: On 31st October 2006 the chemical tanker Seil Sun (741 gt, built 1985), with 9 crew members on board, and fishing boat Ebisu Maru (4.91 gt), with 2 crew, were in collision about 2 km from He Saki Lighthouse, Fukuoka Prefecture. Both damages were unknown, but master of Ebisu Maru went missing.

On 29 October 2006, at approximately 00:45 hours eastern standard time, the barge OTM 3072, carrying a  cargo of bulk wood chips, capsized while under tow by the tug Ocean Foxtrot in a strong gale about six nautical miles north of Bas-Caraquet, New Brunswick. There was no injury, but the ship was declared a constructive total loss.

On 28th October 2006 the bulk carrier WAVE BULKER was at sea in the north Pacific ocean. One of the crew members, wiper Nelson V. Apellido, had been celebrating his birthday and there had been a party with some drinks on board.  At 02.00 hours LT he was not in his cabin and could not be found. He was assumed lost overboard.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Location: Near Bisan Seto in the Inland Sea, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: On 27th October 2006 the container carrier Korean Express (3967 gt, built 1991) was en route from Kobe Port to Korea. The vessel ran aground at 23.50 hours LT on the shallows near Bisan Seto in the Inland Sea (lat 34 22 N, long 133 46 E). The vessel was refloated by Japanese salvor without any water ingress or oil spill, and resumed her voyage. There were 13 crew members on board, none of whom were injured.

On 25 October 2006, fully loaden, the container ship Beluga Stimulation was on voyage from the port of Rotterdam St. Petersburg via the Kiel Canal. The cruising speed was said to have been reduced since the weather continued to deteriorate. A strong gale from the west developed with gusts of wing measuring 11 Bft and a westerly swell with waves 7 to 8 m height. 

After various alarms from the bunker room between hold 2 and hold 3 had sounded during the night, the ship command decided to send the Chief and Second engineers to the bunker room to remedy the source of the alarms.

This took place at the start of the day shortly after 08:00 hours. Both engineers refrained from using a safety line so as not to be obstructed by it. Instead they gripped the railing whenever a wave washed over them. One of the waves hurtled the second engineer overboard around 08:25 hours. His immersion suit did not have a flotation device but kept him warm and a fender which also had been torn loose kept him afloat until he was saved.  The ship command promptly informed German Bight Traffic and requested assistance. 

On account of the bad weather conditions, the ship command reportedly decided that a return manoeuvre such as the “Williamson Turn” would be too dangerous for the ship, its crew and cargo. The Beluga Stimulation continued onwards without changing its course or speed.

After the second engineer had fallen into the water, he was rescue alive by the rescue vessel Bernhard Gruben and brought to a hospital in Wilhelmshaven. The hypothermia and external injuries were not life-threatening with the result that he was able to resume his work on the ship just a few days later

At approximately 06.18 hours LT on 26 October 2006 the Liberian flagged bulk carrier YEROTSAKOS was berthing at Myrtle Groove mile 56,6 when the German flagged Heidelberg Express lost power and steering and clipped the bow of YEROTSAKOS, destroying bulwark, railings, Panama chock, small mas and support wire of  forward mast. There were pilots on board both ships.
The pilot of the Heidelberg Express informed the pilot of the YEROTSAKOS that she had lost power and the YEOTSAKOS's pilot managed to put her astern about 12 metres, thus avoiding further damage. Following the incident the YEROTSAKOS received permanent repairs. There were no injuries reported. A Flag State investigation was conducted by obtaining the flag state report and follow communications for clarifications after review, as necessary.

On October 26th 2006 the Liberian oil tanker PETROKREPOST was manoeuvering to berth at the Valero terminal in St. Charles, Louisiana, when a failure of the coupling bolts between the intermediate shaft and til shaft occurred. The engine was at full astern when the failure occurred, which led to a movement of the tail shaft, approximately 14 inches outboard, and failure of the shaft seals. Water entered the engine room through the inner stern tube bearing seal. Flooding was controlled with diver assistance, and the water in the engine room was pumped to a cargo slop tank and ssubsequently to the ballast tanks. The vessel was later towed to a nearby anchorage where cargo was lightered and the shaft was secured and sealed. The vessel was then towed to Tampa Shipyard for permanent repairs.

On 25th October 2006 the Dutch tanker VISTEN was en route from Karlshamn, Sweden, to Gdansk, Poland, and the Swedish fishing vessel Eros was on her way to Karlskrona, Sweden to unload after fishing. The second officer on the VISTEN plotted the Eros to starboard at a distance of about 6 M. Later, the second officer got an engine alarm which caught his attention so that he did not maintain continuous control of the movements of the Eros. When the second officer returned to the radar screen the Eros was close. The second officer took evasive action, but it was too late and the ships collided. On board the Eros the master could not see any other ships in the immediate surroundings. When he turned to the chart table which was located on yhe port side in the aft part of the wheel house he then saw a "blue wall" very close. He realized that they were about to collide and shifted the helm to starboard. However, the collision happened before the turn started.

ShipsInvolved: EVER GAIN (IMO 8209092), XIN LIAN YUN GANG (IMO 9234355)
SOLASStatus: EVER GAIN: SOLAS, XIN LIAN YUN GANG: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: AT 05.29 HOURS LT ON 25th OCTOBER 2006, THE "M/V XIN LIAN YUN GANG" COLLIDED WITH THE PORT SIDE STERN OF THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP  EVER GAIN. AS A RESULT, THE BRIDGE PORT SIDE HULL AND DOOR WERE DESTROYED. THE CHIEF OFFICER RAN OUT FROM BRIDGE STARBOARD SIDE AND TURNED TO PORT SIDE BRIDGE DECK, WHERE IT WAS SEEN THAT FROM THE SECOND ACCOMMODATION DECK TO BRIDGE, THE CREW ACCOMMODATION WAS ALSO TOTALLY DESTROYED. 10 CREW MEMBERS WERE KILLED AND 3 WERE SERIOUSLY INJURED.

Location: At Kashima Port, Ibaraki Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 24th October 2006 the Bulk carrier Ellida Ace (85350 gt, built 1996),  ran aground at 20.00 hours LT at Kashima Port, Ibaraki Prefecture, while the vessel attempted to shelter offshore due to heavy weather.
As a result, Ellida Ace sustained tearing damage to its hull on the forward portion. There wre 20 crew members on board, none of whom were injured.

On 24th October 2006 at 18.45 hours LT the vessel was about to depart from the slipway with passangers and vehciles onboard. As the skipper went astern, he noticed at the last minute a yacht on his starboard quarter with the distance closing. In order to avoid a collision/near miss, he went ahead on his engine up the slip way and grounded the forward part. In attempting to get off the slipway, matters were compounded when the vessel slew across the slipway and fully grounded. The vessel was refloated on the next rising tide. No pollution was caused.

Location: At Kashima Port, Ibaraki Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 24th October 2006 the Bulk carrier Ocean Victory (88853 gt, built 2005), with 24 crew members on board, ran aground at 15.20 hours LT at Kashima Port, Ibaraki Prefecture, while the vessel was trying to shelter offshore due to heavy weather.
As a result, Ocean Victory sustained heavy tearing damage on its shell plate and the engine-room was soaked in seawater. None of the crew members were injured.

Le 22 octobre 2006, le porte-conteneurs Rokia Delmas appareille à destination du port français de la Pallice-La Rochelle. Les prévisions météorologiques sont mauvaises.
Le 24 octobre à 01:35 heures, à 20 milles de la bouée d'atterrissage de La Rochelle, le capitaine apprend que le port est consigné et que le navire devra attendre sur rade.
A 02:30 heures, le port de la Pallice lui indique sa position de mouillage, le navire se met alors à fortement rouler mais il a du mal à garder une stabilité de route en faisant des embardées de 20 à 30°. Suite à plusieurs défaillances des moteurs, à l'arrêt des trois groupes électrogènes, le navire dérive à trois nœuds vers les hauts fonds.
Avec beaucoup de difficultés, le premier lieutenant et le bosco parviennent à mouiller 6 maillons à bâbord, le mouillage de l'ancre à tribord étant impossible. Mais l'ancre bâbord ne croche pas et le Rokia Delmas va s'échouer une heure plus tard sur les hauts fonds du Nord du chenal, au sud de l'île de Ré, à la position 46°09.8 N et 01°24.8 W.
Les remorqueurs portuaires ne peuvent intervenir en raison des conditions de mer. Par la suite les membres de l'équipage sont tous évacués; le second capitaine, blessé est évacué vers l'hôpital de La rochelle. Aucune pollution n'est observée, en revanche une voie d'eau est rapidement détectée au niveau du pont 1 et de la salle des machines mais, grâce aux moyens mis en place très rapidement, toute pollution sera évitée.

Le navire ne pourra pas être déchoué. Déclaré perte totale par ses assureurs en novembre 2006, il sera déchargé et découpé sur place. Les opérations d'enlèvement de la coque et des superstructures du Rokia Delmas seront achevées le 18 décembre 2007.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: While approaching the port of Aarhus and awaiting a pilot boarding, the ship drifted on to a shallow patch and grounded. The ship was refloated on the next rising tide with tug assistance and proceed into port where it was ascertained the ship was fit to proceed.

SOLASStatus: FRIO CANARIAS: SOLAS, SARONIC BAY: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
AT 11.45 HOURS LT ON 22ND OCTOBER 2006 THE M/V 'FRIO CANARIAS' COLLIDED WITH M/V 'SARONIC BAY' DURING MANOUEVRES WHILST UNMOORING. 
WHEN THE PRESENCE OF OTHER SHIP FIRST BECAME KNOWN, THE "FRIO CANARIAS" WAS MOORED PORT SIDE, AND THE "SARONIC BAY"- STARBOARD SIDE. "FRIO CANARIAS WAS UNDER WAY, GYRO COURSE 120 DEGREES, SPEED ABOUT 5 KNOTS(GPS), FOR UNMOORING COURSE-130 DEG.
THE VESSELS WERE MOORED AT A MINIMAL DISTANCE BETWEEN EACH OTHER OF ABOUT 1M. DURING UNMOORING COURSE OF M/V"SARONIC BAY"120 DEGREES, M/V "FRIO CANARIAS" COURSE 135-140 DEGREES.

Location: about 42 miles off Costa Rica Cost
SummaryOfEvents:
On October 18th 2006, on board the vehicle carrier GRUS, Cadet Don Renin reported to the Bridge, that he was unable to locate Cadet Jason Sadhana who was scheduled to attend a GMDSS Training on Bridge at 13.00  ship's time.
At 13.00, the bridge was informed that the Cadet Jason Saldhana was missing and had not turned up for the scheduled training. Jason was last seen by one of the crew member heading out of the accommodation wearing jeans and a t-shirt.
At 14.20 an urgent message about the missing person was transmitted on VHF channel 16, and was repeated at intervals of 15 minutes. At 14.45 a message about a missing person was transmitted on Sat C.  It turned out that Cadet Saldhana had jumped overboard, and the lifeboat vessel Medi Tokio was lowered to rescue him.
The vessel Talabot protected the lifeboat giving the leeside, and  Cadet Saldhana was brought  aboard and given immediate first aid.
His condition was stable and there was no need for extra medical attention.

At 23.00 hours LT on 17 October 2006, the registered refrigerated cargo ship ROKO (5250 dwt, 3955 gt, built 1983, 07), IMO Nr 8205307, flag of Bahamas, call sign C6LU9, with pilot on board and 14 crew (Russian, Ukrainian and Lithuanian), and the passanger and cargo boat COSTA AZUL, flag of Brazil, 39.6 gt, call sign PS7622, with 12 seafarers on board (03 crewmen and 09 divers), were in collision inside Guanabara Bay, port of Rio de Janeiro, position point 22° 54,100”S/ 043° 08’,961 W while ROKO maneuvered to enter the harbor and COSTA AZUL crossed the Bay from Caju location towards Jurujuba. 
As a result of the collision, ROKO sustained scratches at the bow, and COSTA AZUL capsized and sunk, with 08 fatalities the 3 crewmen included. Only 04 divers survived.
In spite of no oil pollution occurring, signsof oil on the sea surface were observed, probably indicating that there was a minor leak of oil diesel. With the evaporation and immediate dispersion it was not possible to confirm if the oil was a result of the collision. 
After the removal of the shipwrecked hull the existence of oil in the tanks was verified and there were no damages that would indicate leaking. The most probable hypothesis is that the oil vestiges that arose in water were derived from residues in the vessel basement.
The vessel COSTA AZUL was submerged to a depth of 30 meters.  After several attempts, its wrecked hull was raised from the water early on  the day of 26th  October 2006.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Fawley Marine Terminal, alongside No.2 berth
InitialEvent: OTHER- major LPG leak during cargo sampling
SummaryOfEvents:
On 17 October 2006, the Hong Kong, China registered gas carrier ENNERDALE experienced a major leak of liquefied propane, while cargo sampling operations were taking place, alongside Fawley Marine Terminal (FMT).  The leak was sealed 29 hours later, after an estimated 66 tonnes of propane had been lost to atmosphere.
The fully pressurised gas carrier ENNERDALE arrived at FMT's No.2 berth at 2300 on 15 October 2006, to load liquefied propane.  Preloading checks were conducted and loading commenced shortly after.  At 1830 on 17 October the loading operation was halted, approximately 2 hours before cargo loading was due to be completed, to allow a 'freeze' test to be conducted.  A cargo surveyor came aboard and attached his cargo sampling equipment to the sampling point of tank No.1.  The cargo was then circulated for 2-3 minutes.  The process was repeated for tank No.2.  With the test results satisfactory, cargo loading continued and completed at 2100.
The cargo surveyor returned to the ship and went straight to the sampling point of tank No.1, where the chief officer was already preparing.  The cargo surveyor used a thread adapter to connect the sampling device to the ship's sampling connection.  The chief officer then circulated the cargo, using the deep well pump, to ensure a good representative sample was obtained.  The cargo surveyor flushed the sampling device through three times before filling it.  He repeated the process, taking four samples in total, before moving aft to the sampling point of tank No.2.  While the chief officer secured tank No.1, the cargo surveyor prepared to fit his equipment to the sampling point of tank No.2.  As he turned the sampling connection towards himself, the sampling valve assembly came off in his hand.
The chief officer saw and heard a leak and activated the emergency shut down (ESD) valves.  Attempts were made to refit the sampling valve but the 11 bar pressure of the cargo, and the formation of ice on the connection, made it impossible.  It soon became apperent that the ESD valve adjacent to the tank on the same line as the sampling connection was not completely shut.
The emergency services were alerted soon after the accident and the ship was doused in water sprays to disperse the gas cloud.  At 2200, the port of Southampton was closed to all traffic.  All ships at FMT were evacuated at 0000.  At 0530 on 18 October, with the situation stabilised, traffic restrictions were reduced to a 400m exclusion zone around ENNERDALE, which allowed the port to reopen to traffic.
After several options to stop the leak had been considered, it was decided to hot tap the cargo pipework and inject a sealing compound to stop the leak of gas.  A company regularly used at Fawley refinery, successfully drilled into the pipework at 1408 on 18 October.  The sealing compound was then slowly injected into the pipework, enabling the leak to be sealed and capped at 0240 the next morning.
ENNERDALE then sailed and anchored in the Solent, awaiting clearance to sail which was contingent upon class approval of the repair and the discharge port agreeing to accept the vessel.  This completed, she sailed at 1814 the same day.

Location: Port of Coatzacoalcos, Gulf of Mexico
SummaryOfEvents: The explosion occured at the Coatzacoalcos port, while the vessel was in ballast and out of service. A spark from maintenance work, which was being carried out onboard, ignited fuel vapours. Eight people dead, nine injured and others missing.

Location: KENNER BEND ANCHORAGE, MILE 114, MISSISSIPPI RIVER
SummaryOfEvents: WE WERE ANCHORED AT KENNER BEND ANCHORAGE ON THE AFTERNOON OF 16 OCTOBER 2006 WHEN LOADED VESSEL M/V ZAGORA, OUTBOUND UNDER PILOT ADVICE, LOST CONTROL OF HER COURSE AND VEERED TO STARBOARD. WE HEARD HER DANGER SIGNAL, AND SHE CONTINUED TO SWING TOWARDS US. WHEN SHE WAS VERY CLOSE WE SAW HER PORT ANCHOR LET GO, AND WE SOUNDED GENERAL ALARM AT APPROXIMATELY 14.55HRS. HER BOW COLLIDED WITH OUR STARBOARD SIDE IN WAY OF HOLD NO.7, CAUSING HEAVY DAMAGE AND RELEASE OF WATER FROM TOPSIDE BALLAST TANK NO.4 STARBOARD. WE IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED USCG, MUSTERED FOR DAMAGE CONTROL, AND SOUNDINGS FOUND NO WATER COMING IN, NO OIL POLLUTION AND NO INJURIES. DAMAGE SURVEYS ARE PENDING

SOLASStatus: FUKUYOSHI MARU NO.11: Unknown/unspecified, SUNRISE BEGONIA: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Off Suzaki, Shimoda City, Sizuoka Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 16th October 2006 at 01.30 hours LT the Chemical Tanker SUNRISE BEGONIA (4893 gt, built 1994), with 20 crew members on board, collided with general cargo ship Fukuyoshi Maru No.11 (199 gt), with 4 crew members, off Suzaki, Shimoda City, Sizuoka Prefecture.
As a result, SUNRISE BEGONIA sustained damage to its port on aft part  and fuel oil leaked through the hole that was made as a result.
On 15th October 2006 at 23.45 hours LT the M/V VAGABOND ran aground in inland waters.
ON 15TH OCTOBER 2006 THE 3RD OFFICER WORKING ON M/V SHOHO, WHOSE NAME WAS VILLNUEVA REIMEL, A FILIPINO, WAS FOUND MISSING AT APPROXIAMATELY 02.00 HOURS LT, AND ASSUMED LOST.

SOLASStatus: ESCORTE: Unknown/unspecified, JERRY G: Unknown/unspecified, SENECA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 07:32 hours on 13 October 2006, the bulk carrier Seneca, with a pilot aboard and assisted by the tugs Jerry G and Esctorte , attempted  to depart Oshawa Harbour in a strong breeze/gale, whereupon it ran over two navigation buoys before making bottom contact and striking the eastern at the harbour entrance.

SOLASStatus: KUNIHIDE MARU NO.3: Unknown/unspecified, OCEAN GLORY: SOLAS
Location: Off south-east of He Saki, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
At 01.33 hours LT on 13th October 2006 the General Cargo Ship (registered South Korea, 4,988 gt, built 1984), with 17 crew members (South Korean: 7, Chinese: 10), and fishing vessel (4.92 gt, built 1980), with 1 crew member (Japanese), were in collision off the south-east of He Saki, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan.
As a result of the collision, the KUNIHIDE MARU No.3 sustained extensive damage to its middle part, and was capsized to the starboard side. The OCEAN GLORY suffered scratches to the bulbous bow. The skipper of the Kunihide Maru No.3, who fell overboard, was later rescued by a fellow ship and taken to a hospital, but in vain. His death was determined, by an inquest, to have been from drowning.

ON 12TH OCTOBER 2006 AT 22.54 THE VESSEL DEPARTED QUAY NO. 35 AT THE PORT OF ALEXANDRIA, UNDER THE CONTROL OF HARBOR PILOTS. SHE SHOULD HAVE MADE A SWING TURN IMMEDIATELY AFTER MOORING LINES WERE CAST OFF AND HEADED TOWARD THE EXIT OF INNER HARBOR. HOWEVER, PILOTS USED TOO MUCH POWER AND ALSO LOST CONTROL OF THE TUG BOATS. AS A RESULT THE SHIP WENT STRAIGHT INTO QUAY NO.22 AT HER STERN DIRECTION. THE QUAY SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO AN AREA 17 METRES WIDE X 16 METRES IN LENGTH, AND THE VESSEL WAS DENTED IN AN AREA MEASURING 4 M X 1 M X 10CM.
THE VESSEL WAS DETAINED AT INNER ANCHORAGE UNTIL PORT AUTHORITY COULD ESTIMATE THE DAMAGE TO THE QUAY, COST OF REPAIR AND INCOME LOST WHILST IT WAS NOT IN USE. THE VESSEL WAS ALSO GIVEN A CLASSIFICATION SURVEY DURING THAT PERIOD. FINALLY THE VESSEL WAS RELEASED AFTER CASH WAS REMITTED AND RECEIVED BY PORT AUTHORITY AT NOON ON 22 AUG 2006.

ON 11TH OCTOBER 2006 AT 06.00 HOURS LT THE VESSEL WAS MANEUVERING TO BERTH UNDER PILOT ATTENDANCE, WHEN SHE HIT THE CORNER OF THE BERTH CAUSING DAMAGE TO HER PORT SIDE DECK 4, AND DECK 3.
SOME SCUFFING WAS OBSERVED ON HER AFT PORT SIDE SHELL PLATES GOING FROM FWD TO AFT, AS WELL AS AN INDENT ON THE SHELL PLATING.
THE SHELL PLATING WAS PUSHED INWARD ABOUT 400mm. AND A VERTICAL TEAR TO THE SHELL PLATING - ABOUT 1200mm AT FR.NO.63  - WAS FOUND.
THE OLYMPIAN HIGHWAY UNDERWENT TEMPORARY REPAIRS AT GALVESTON, ACCORDING TO NK SURVEY RECORD.
ON 31ST OCTOBER 2006 THE VESSEL HAD AN OCCASIONAL SURVEY AT ZEEBRUGGE WHERE A NEW CRACK WAS FOUND. THE NK SURVEYOR DEMANDED THAT THIS BE REPAIRED BEFORE SAILING. THESE REPAIRS WERE CARRIED OUT BETWEEN 1ST - 6TH NOVEMBER 2006 AT ZEEBRUGGE.

PLS FIND ATTACHMENT OF NK SURVEYOR CERTIFICATES..

The M/V GUNSUL discharged jet oil and left Port Incheon, S.Korea, in ballast bound for Port Ulsan, South Korea, at 10.15 hours (herein after all of times means KST) on October 8, 2006. 

After finishing gas-free work, the crew carried out tank cleaning and found a crack on the bottom plate of No.2 port C.O.T  at about 08.00 hours on October 9. The crew made emergency repairs and welded the crack.

At 11.00 hours on the same date, the crew left the working area for lunch. There was a sudden explosion on No.2 port C.O.T at 11:15, when the m/v was proceeding in the position of 34-25-12N, 128-20-10E, within the southern coastal area of Korea. 

The chief engineer was killed on the spot and the bottom plate of the C.O.T was damaged, creating a hole measuring of 2m X 80cm. 
Weather conditions were fine, with a light wind and calm sea.

Crew member returning to cabin from crew bar, and wearing leather soled shoes with a 4 cm heel, slipped and fell breaking the head of their left humerus. The deck was dry, and free from defects, and the lighting was adequate.

At 19.50 hours LT on 7th October 2006 a fire alarm sounded on the bridge of the OCEAN VILLAGE, a large passenger ship,  indicating a fire in an auxiliary boiler.  At the same time the 1st engineer, who was completing his rounds in the machinery space,  noticed a small fire in the boiler and immediately isolated the fuel supply.  The duty 1EO in the engine control room noticed the fire on his CCTV monitor as the 1st engineer tackle the fire with a foam extinguisher.

In the meantime the bridge contacted the engine control room, who confirmed the fire.  The duty 1EO activated the flexifog system which immediately extinguished the fire.  The total incident lasted 5 minutes. 

The onboard post-accident investigation found that the boiler burner had been cleaned and inspected the night before the fire, and that a fuel leak appeared to have developed at the fuel supply unions which led to the fire.

The fire resulted in superficial burning of paint work to the boiler front.

On 6th October 2006 the Bulk ore carrier Giant Step (98587 gt, built 1985), with 26 crew, ran aground off Kamisu, Ibaraki Prefecture at 17.20 hours LT. 
When the vessel was trying to move to shelter from heavy weather, she started drifting due to strong winds, and ran aground on the shallows.
Sixteen out of 26 crew members were rescued but another eight died. Oil and cargo (iron ore) leaked from the vessel.
Giant Step was carrying 190,000 tons of iron ore and was at anchor to wait for berthing to discharge off Kashima Port in Ibaraki from Australia.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: ON 6TH OCTOBER 2006 THE NEW VENTURE WAS MOORING AT THE PORT OF GALVESTON WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF TWO TUGS. THE  PILOT REQUIRED THAT BOTH TUGBOATS GAVE TWO LINES, BUT THE FORWARD TUGBOAT REFUSED TO GIVE THE SECOND LINE, WITH THE RESULT THAT THE FORWARD TUG SNAPPED THE LINE AT 09.45 HOURS LT AND VESSEL BOW DRIFTED TO THE STARBOARD, STRIKING THE OIL RIG Q4000. BOTH VESSELS SUSTAINED MINOR DAMAGE.

At 09.10 hours LT on 5TH October 2006, the Korean container vessel SINOKOR MASAN, owned by Sinokor Merchant Marine Co., Ltd., passed through the cultivating facilities of Zhaobei zui Weihai port, causing damage to numerous cultivating facilities. The vessel remained fit to proceed.

Location: between SWS Shanghai, China and the Port of Richards Bay, South Africa
SummaryOfEvents:
The MV ‘Mineral Libin’ was on voyage from SWS Yard-Shanghai, China for loading coal cargo from port of Richards, South Africa.
On 4 October 2006at 17:00 hours, ballasting of all tanks started with the aft booby hatch of cargo No. 6 inadvertently closed. 
At 02:30 hours on 05 October 2006 the bosun went towards No. 6   aft booby hatch and tried opening the cover out of his own initiative. He climbed on the top of the booby hatch cover to use his weight in order to counter the pressure and started kicking on the cleats with his foot. Seconds later he was thrown about 2/3 meters high and hit the air pipe went sans other neighbouring obstructions.
Despite a messman being available on board to handle the victim in a more professional manner, it was reported to the Master that the bosom had passed away.

At about 08:30 hours, the ‘Mineral Libin’ anchored in Xianzhi Men Northern anchorage, to wait for agents and other authorities.

At about 18:30 hours, the Master handed over the bosun’s body to the agent for further action as per instructions from the managers

Location: Saint Georges Channel, Southern Irish Sea
SummaryOfEvents: On 4th October 2006, during a coastal passage, the main engine of the FORTH FISHER was stopped at 23.30 hours LT following the discovery of problems within one of the engine's cylinder heads. The fault was diagnosed as a failed air start valve, which had jammed open, and had allowed exhaust gases into the air start manifold. As the weather was deteriorating, the ship's manager secured the services of a tug, which towed the tanker to a nearby haven for repair. Once at anchor, the faulty cylinder head was changed for an onboard spare. All other cylinder heads, along with the  turbocharger, were also inspected by endoscope but no damage was evident. The vessel sailed following a successful trial of the main engine. Onboard investigation showed that the air start valve had failed due to carbon deposits, which had allowed the valve to remain partially open. To prevent a similar occurrence, an inspection of the air start system has been icluded to a rounds check list.

After failing to prepare breakfast  in the crew mess room on 4th October 2006 a cabin boy was reported missing to the OOW of a general cargo ship at 07.10 hours LT. He had last been seen at 06.30 hours LT. The master was informed at 07.15 hours LT, and an internal search was started. The search was completed at 08.00 hours LT, but there was no sign of the cabin boy. A Pan Pan message was transmitted, and a telex message was sent via Inmarsat C to a nearby JRCC. The ship's DPA was also informed. The ship reversed course towards her 06.30 position, with all crew on deck as lookouts. A helicopter assisted the search between 10.00 and 10.30 hours LT, and two warships between 13.20 and 15.10 hours LT. The cargo ship continued the search until 23.25 when she was stood down by the JRCC. The cabin boy was not found. He had only been onboard for two days, but seemed anxious about the security of his job. It is not known how the cabin boy was lost overboard. He is missing, presumed dead.

InitialEvent: MATERIAL FAILURE(ENGINEERING MACHINERY, INCLUDING MAIN PROPULSION, AUXILIARIES, BOILERS, EVAPORATORS, DECK MACHINERY, ELECTRICAL ETC.)
SummaryOfEvents: MAIN ENGINE INTERMEDIATE SHAFT BEARING FAILURE.

On 2nd October 2006 the container ship UNI-PREMIER left the port of Surabaya on at 22:30 hours LT under pilot´s assistance with draft 8.65 meters. The ship sailed with full speed 12.4kts, course 040°(T), and was passing No.11 buoy which is the right hand buoy as per IALA "A" buoy system, but has no left hand buoy to match up. The width of channel is 100 m, the charted depth is 10.1m with sand and mud seabed, the tide is flood 1.5m, the current is 1.5 mile/hr and setting 180°(T). In the meantime, the inbound bulk carrier PEACH MOUNTAIN was seen on port bow, 1.1 miles off, fully loaded with phosphate, gross tonnage 27,235T, draft 10m, which was approaching buoy #9 with a speed of 10 Knots. At 23:36 hours LT, the fix displayed that the ship had arrived at the turning point, the next course was 020°(T); the inboard vessel was on the port bow at a distance of 0.5 mile, and the Master used engine slow ahead. At 23:38 hours LT, the Master used crash astern to avoid collision but it was too late. At  23:39 hours LT, the ship, heading 000°(t), speed 6kts, collided with the inbound vessel with angle of blow 30° between buoy#9 and #4.

SOLASStatus: PETITE FORTE: Unknown/unspecified, ST. MARY'S CEMENT: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Lock 4, Welland Canal St. Cathrines, Ontario
SummaryOfEvents: On 02 October 2006 during twilight at 06:15 hours daylight time, shortly having cleared the exit of the lock, the downbound tug Petite Forte, pushing the barges St. Mary’s Cement, drifted backwards and struck the arrester cable in Lock 4 of the Welland Canal. The tug’s mast and electronic navigation equipment were damaged. The shear pins and linkage for the lock’s ship-arrester cable needed to be replaced.

Location: 2 miles NW from Cape Henry, Chesapeake Bay
SummaryOfEvents:
The container vessel MAERSK DOHA sailed from Norfolk, Virginia, in the USA shortly after midnight on 2 October 2006.  At 0030 an engine room alarm sounded indicating that pressure in the steam system was low.  The crew investigated the cause of the alarm and discovered that steam was escaping from the auxiliary boiler air intake.  They shut down the burner and opened the furnace door.  Steam escaped, and when it had cleared they could see that the furnace tube was severely distorted and cracked.
There was some delay before the chief engineer was informed about the breakdown, and further delay before the problem was reported to the master on the bridge.  Although the vessel could have anchored safely to investigate the situation, it was agreed that the main engine could continue to run at low power, and the vessel proceeded to sea.
An Exhaust Gas Economiser (EGE) was fitted in the funnel uptakes to generate steam from the waste heat contained in the main engine exhaust gases, using water circulated from the auxiliary boiler.  At about 0200, a rapid rise in the temperature of the EGE was noticed and the chief engineer realised that there was a fire inside the EGE casing.  The bridge was alerted at 0230 and the vessel's emergency alarm was activated.  Radiant heat from the EGE ignited light fittings, cables and paint on bulkheads in the funnel uptakes, and the crew attempted to fight the fire with a water hose and a fire extinguisher.  They were beaten back by the heat and smoke and the engine room was evacuated.
The crew were mustered and firefighters re-entered the funnel uptakes and began to cool the EGE casing using water hoses; they were withdrawn when their team leader grew concerned that the structure might collapse.  The main engine room CO2 gas smothering system was activated, but failed to discharge correctly and, in any case, would have had little effect on the fire.   The fire was contained using water hoses to cool its boundaries and was finally extinguished, following advice received from the company head office, by drenching the EGE with water from the top of the funnel and through doors in the EGE casing.

On 30th September 2006 the chemical tanker ORAHOPE was at sea when vibrations were observed in the ship, and the speed was immeditately reduced. At 22.00 hours LT fire alarms were set off on the engine room's lower deck, and the main engine was immeditately stopped by the use of the emergency stopping device.

It was found that serious damage had occurred to the main engine, cylinder 6. The connecting rod had loosened from the crank and had damaged the piston and lining.

AT 15.30 HOURS ON 29TH SEPTEMBER 2006 THE BULK CARRIER "VOUTAKOS" WAS AT OPEN SEA WHEN THE MAIN ENGINE STOPPED FOR UNKNOWN REASONS.  AFTER CHECKING, IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE CAMSHAFT AND CHAIN DRIVING GEAR MECHANISM WERE SERIOUSLY DAMAGED. AS IT WAS NOT POSSIBLE TO MAKE THE REPAIRS AT SEA, THE MASTER REQUESTED ASSISTANCE TO THE PORT OF DESTINATION.

SOLASStatus: GENKI STAR: SOLAS, HAI GONG 403: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
ON 27TH SEPTEMBER 2006 THE TANKER "GENKI STAR" ARRIVED AT CJK ANCHORAGE IN THE EARLY MORNING, INTENDING TO LOAD CARGO IN PORT NANJING.
THE SHANGHAI PILOT (MR.R.ZHANG) THEN BOARDED THE VESSEL AND MANOUEVERED THE TANKER ALONG THE YANGZI RIVER. AT THAT TIME THE VISIBILITY WAS GOOD, WITH WIND FORCE OF ABOUT 4 NORTHWEST AND SAILING AGAINST THE CURRENT.
AT 17.30 HOURS LT, WHILST THE VESSEL NAVIGATED NEAR BUOY NO.61 WITH A SPEED OF ABOUT 6 KNOTS, THE BUNKER BARGE "HAI GONG 403" WAS SEEN AHEAD OF THE VESSEL'S  STARBOARD BOW, ABOUT 1 CABLE.  AS THE BUNKER BARGE WAS NAVIGATING PARALLEL WITH GENKI STAR,  THE PILOT CALLED THE BUNKER BARGE BY 2VHF BUT NO ANSWER WAS GIVEN BY THE BARGE.

AS BOTH VESSELS APPROACHED THE WUSONG KOU, THE HAI GONG 403  SUDDENLY TURNED HARD TO PORT IN ORDER TO ENTER THE HUANGPU RIVER, AND CROSSED THE BOW OF GENKI STAR. THE PILOT STOPPED THE MAIN ENGINE AND PROCEEDED FULL ASTERN IMMEDIATELY, BUT COULD NOT STOP COMPLETELY AND THE BUNKER BARGE WAS PUSHED BY THE CURRENT TO THE HEAD OF M/V GENKI STAR.  THE COLLISION OCCURRED AT 17.33 HOURS LT IN POSITION LAT:31º 23.8N LONG:121º 34.1E.

Location: St Peter Port, Guernsey, CHANNEL ISLANDS
SummaryOfEvents: On the afternoon of 26 September 2006, the passenger vessel THOMSON CELEBRATION prepared to depart from St Peter Port, Guernsey.  All passengers had been confirmed on board and the passenger tenders were recalled for recovery.  When TENDER 15 was being positioned under its falls, close to the side of the ship, the 1.5 knot tide affected the manoeuvre and the coxswain lost full control of the boat.  The tender was carried astern and against the ship's side.  A crew member had left his station at TENDER 15's stern to prevent the davit hook from damaging the tender.  He moved between the coach house and the ship's side and became trapped.  He received fatal crush injuries to his upper chest.

Vessel was on a laden passage from the FarEast to South Africa with deck cargo when it was struck with abnormal swell on its beam. As a result, the vessel rolled heavily and lost one container and 3 pontoons overboard. As the deck cargo shifted, the vessel damaged its rails and hatch cover.

ON 26TH SEPTEMBER 2006 THE M/V KENT MARINER WAS AT SUMMERSIDE PORT WHEN SHE SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO NO. 5 PORT SIDE BALLAST TANK IN WAY OF NO. 3 CARGO HOLD AT ABOUT  FRAME NO. 55. 
A HOLE OF ABOUT 10CM LENGTH WAS MADE BY STEVEDORES USE OF GRABS DURING DISCHARGING.

On 25th September 2006 the Miramar grounded when approaching Luleå, Sweden. According to the master he did not report the grounding as he had not noticed it. The grounding took place at 23.54 hours LT and the master was alone on the bridge. When leaving Luleå several days later the Coastguards stopped the vessel as they noticed an oil spill from her. The vessel was brought back to Luleå and a survey showed damages to 4 tanks. The vessel was later allowed for a single voyage to a shipyard for repair.

On 25th September 2006 the MV CONTI JORK completed cargo operations at 06.00 hours LT and sailed from berth No.37 at 08.54 hours LT. As she was sailing to berth S13 the MV CONTI JORK contacted the berth S13 at 09.23 hours LT. The ship remained fit to proceed.

A contact and pollution accident occurred when the British container vessel “HYUNDAI INDEPENDENCE” was entering the Wangbang Yongyue Shipyard at 15.45 hours LT on the 22nd of April 2006. As a result, the third oil tanker on the forward port side, which is about 120 meters to the head and 9 meters under the waterline, was broken and about 477 tons of fuel (IFO500) leaked out. Accident class: very serious.

At 09.15 hours LT on 25th September 2006 the general cargo ship ADINESIA was in the Port of Tokai when her starboard side poop deck and boat deck railings contacted BLUE LEO's port bow,  just below her portside anchor, causing scratches and indentions to contact position.

At about 15.40 hours LT on 22 September 2006, a flash fire erupted in the high-pressure welding oxygen system on board the ro-ro cargo ship SEAROAD MERSEY. The trainee engineer received burns to his arms from the flash-fire and from molten plastic spraying his skin when the hoses ruptured. He was wearing overalls at the time but the sleeves were rolled up. Consequently, the overalls did not protect his arms.
The fire occurred when the heat created by the compression of the oxygen within the system ignited a replacement hose that had been fitted into the system. The hose had a lining made from a material with a low ignition temperature that had been made in an oily environment. It was not fit for its intended purpose and did not comply with any standards for high pressure oxygen hoses.
The hose had been fabricated by a hose supplier who had not been trained about the hazards or standards associated with high pressure oxygen systems and had ambiguous information regarding the suitability of those materials for the purpose.
The report also found that the fixed oxy-acetylene system had not been inspected or maintained in accordance with marine orders.
The report makes several safety recommendations with the aim of preventing further incidents of this type.

On 22nd September 2006 (23:00 hrs), vessel sailed from Las Palmas, loaded with some 5,000 MT of bagged maize flour, bound for Lobito and Luanda, Angola. On 25th September 2006 (11:40 hrs), Chief Engineer who was at watch at that time, noted sudden drop of Main Engine  lub oil pressure and immediately stopped the engine for inspection and assessment of the situation. Vessel´s position, as recorded on deck logbook, 21º 44.0 N, 17º 27.2 W. At 13:00 hrs and following partial dismantling and inspection of the engine parts, Chief Engineer reported to the Master that engineer crankpin No 3 had sustained serious damage that could not be repaired at sea and vessel could not proceed at own power. Master notified Managers, requesting tug assistance whilst vessel was drifting some 28 miles off the coast of west Africa. Managers arranged for salvage tug, under L.O.F. contract. Vessel was to be towed at Dakar, Senegal, beind the closest port (with  repair  facilities), to the area of the casualty and to the direction of ports of destination (south). 
On 28th September 2006 (10:20 hrs), towage of the "ARION" to Dakar commenced by salvage tug "LEOPARD". On 2nd October 2006 (13:50 hrs), the tow arrived at Dakar anchorage and "ARION dropped anchor. At 14:00 hrs the tow line was let go and re-delivery Certificate was signed by the Masters of the "ARION" and T/B "LEOPARD". On 3rd October 2006 (18:50 hrs), vessel berthed at Dakar port berth 82 and Owners´Representatives along with technicians and surveyors of all parties concerned boarded the vessel for initial assessment of the engine damage. On 4th October 2006 (early a.m.), damage repairs commenced. On 14th October 2006, all repairs were completed to the satisfaction of Class attending surveyor and vessel sailed from Dakar (own power), resuming her voyage to Luanda, Angola.
On 22nd September 2006 at 10.35 hours LT the bulk carrier  “ANANGEL DESTINY” came into contact with cables, which dragged by MV “BIN HAI 511” , heavily damaging two cables.

On 22nd September 2006 the the chemical tanker GOLDEN GEORGIA was at Batangas Bay Terminal offloading its cargo of 4,000 metric tons of caustic soda onto another tanker owned  by Mabuhay Vinyl Corporation. At 09.30 hours LT 400 litres of caustic soda spilled into the waters of Batangas Bay Terminal wharf Baun town, Batangas province in southern Luzon island, Philippines.  Initial reports indicated that the local vessel's cargo tank had overflowed during the offloading operations, spilling caustic soda into the Bay. There were no injuries to the crew of either vessel. The Coast Guard said that it was fining Mabuhay Vinyl and Ginga Falcon for the Chemical spill.

At 03.00 hours LT on 22nd September 2006 the general cargo carrier Arina grounded on Understen, Alands Sea, west of the light house. The OOW fell asleep during watch and there was no look out. The vessel was refloated by help from 2 tugs and went to Gävle, Sweden for discharge. She was then allowed for a single voyage to ship yard in Klaipeda for repair.

On 20th September 2006 the UK-registered dry cargo carrier was on passage from the UAE to Brazil, when the incinerator was prepared for use.

At 09.00 hours LT the incinerator was opened and slag and ash were removed and alarms tested in accordance with the pre-firing routine. At 10.00 the incinerator was flashed up and set in auto mode - all parameters were checked to be correct. At 12.55 the 3rd engineer went to the incinerator compartment to check on an abnormal alarm that had sounded in the engine control room. He found that there were small flames coming from the combustion chamber air inlet vents located at the bottom of the incinerator. On seeing this, the engineer activated the fire alarm in the compartment.

The engineer quickly extinguished the fire using a first aid extinguisher.

On investigation it was found that there had been an excessive build up of slag in the combustion chamber from the area of the waste burner. The burning slag fell to the bottom of the chamber and caused the flames to appear at the vents.

THE 28th SEPTEMBER 2006 AT 04.05 HOURS LT THE BULK CARRIER LOTUS BLOSSOM ANCHORED AT MILE 113 KENNER ROAD. ON THE 29th SEPTEMBER 2006 AT ABOUT 00.18 HOURS LT THE VESSEL WAS TURNING VERY SLOWLY TO PORTSIDE CLOSE TO A STATIONARY GROUP OF BARGES AND TOUCHED ONE OF THEM VERY SLIGHTLY. NO DAMAGE WAS SUSTAINED TO EITHER THE BARGE OR TO THE LOTUS BLOSSOM, AND THERE WAS NO PERSONAL INJURY.
AT ABOUT 04.25 HOURS LT THE PILOT ON BOARD SHIFTED THE LOTUS BLOSSOM AWAY FROM THE STATIONARY BARGES.
AT 04.50 HOURS LT THE ANCHOR WAS TAKEN UP AND AT 05.10 HOURS LT THE ANCHOR WAS DROPPED AGAIN TO A SAFER ANCHORAGE POSITION, AND THE PILOT LEFT  AT 05.40 HOURS LT.
ALL MACHINERY AND EQUIPMENT WAS TESTED AND FOUND TO BE IN NORMAL CONDITION

ShipsInvolved: AAA FUEL (-), AAA UFULI (-), OCEAN RULER (IMO 8408600)
SOLASStatus: AAA FUEL: Unknown/unspecified, AAA UFULI: SOLAS, OCEAN RULER: SOLAS
Location: In Saiki Bay, Oita Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
General Cargo Ship Ocean Ruler (registered Maldives, 1179 gt, built 1984) with 10 crew (Maldivian), was anchoring to shelter from a typhoon in Saiki Bay, Oita Prefecture, Japan, towing Ro-Ro Cargo Ship AAA Ufuli (99.67 gt) with 5 crew (Maldivian), and Oil Tanker AAA Fuel (78.93 gt) unmanned. Then AAA Ufuli was drifted and capsized after tug line was cut due to strong wind, although AAA Fuel evacuated by a tug boat.
AAA Ufuli sank and 1 crew died, although patrol ship was dispatched and saved 4 lives.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

Location: Off Hesaki Lighthouse, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: At 19.50 hours LT on 17th September 2006, whilst sheltering from a typhoon, the general cargo ship Hang Lim Queen (built 1988) anchored off Hesaki Lighthouse, Fukuoka Prefecture, and ran aground in shallows due to strong winds. The Vessel was refloated by salvage vessel. No injuries or oil spill observed.

Location: Notre Dame Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: On 17 September 2006, the small fishing vessel Lannie & Sisters II was crossing Notre Dame Bay in good weather. Two crew were on board. There was a steady ingress of water coming from the stuffing box and problems with the vessel's transmission, but the last VHF communication with the vessel indicated all was well. The vessel was discovered partially submerged the following morning. The body of one of the crew was recovered, the other is missing and presumed drowned.

SOLASStatus: ASIAN EXCELSIOR: Unknown/unspecified, RUI AN 22: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 23.53 hours LT on the day of September 16, 2006,the Singapore vessel ASIAN EXCELSIOR collided with the Chinese vessel  RUI AN 22  near the sea area of the pilot station in Fangcheng Port(21°22.95′N、108°20.96′E),China. It caused M/V RUI AN 22 to capsize (wreck position: 21°23.03′N 108°21.00′E ) and damaged the port bulbous bow of  M/ V ASIAN EXCELSIOR. All 10 crew members of M/V RUI AN 22 were saved during the rescue operations.

On the evening of 15 September 2006, TASMAN TRADER was moored alongside Aotea Quay in Wellington harbour.  Stevedores, employed by the Loading Company, were discharging, amongst other things, bundles of flat steel bars from No. 3 hold, bay 11, which was situated on the port side of the lower hold.
Whilst discharging bundles of flat steel bars, weighing about 2.2 tonnes, one of the flat webbing slings being used to lift the bars out of the hold failed.  As a result of this, the steel bars fell from the top of the hatch opening onto the tank of the lower hold, narrowly missing two stevedores working below.

On 14th September 2006 a crew member on board M/V SC BALTIC who was tidying up the tween deck during discharging bales of paper was hit by a falling bale of paper that weighed approximately 600 Kg. 
The injured crewmember and the fork-lift truck driver were the only people present at the time of the accident. The fork-lift truck driver did not see the bale falling down, but he became aware of the accident when he heard shouting from the injured crewmember. 
The crewmember had sustained fractures to both legs. The master called for an ambulance, and the injured crew member was taken to a hospital near by.

The m/v Kew Bridge arrived at Ranpar port pilot station on 13 September 2006 at 10.45 hours to discharge a cargo of Butane. The terminal is located in the Pawas Bay (port in Maharashtra, India) and exposed to the sea as it doesn't have a breakwater. The length of berth is 204 Mtrs as against the length of the vessel which is 154 mtrs. The terminal is closed during bad weather seasons, and handles a maximum length of 180 mtrs. The vessel berthed starboard side, but arrived without a large scale chart, which was to be put on board through the pilot. This was not done, and the vessel berthing became delayed. A tugboat later delivered the chart. Meanwhile, weather conditions deteriorated slightly to 15 knots and beam swell 2 mtrs. While berthing the vessel experienced heavy squally weather with strong winds and high beam swell, and she swung to port rapidly. The tugs failed to hold her in position and finallly ran aground on 14 September 2006 at 17.55 hours LT. There was no loss of life and no incidence of pollution.
The vessel was refloated during high tide on 9 October 2006 at 23.27 hours LT.

The fishing ship Sian Elizabeth departed from the Fisher Fleet in Kings Lynn at 11:00 hours on 14 September 2006 in fine weather, having landed the previous catch. The vessel sailed, with three crew on board, to return to the cockle beds west of Hunstanton.  
An untrained crewman of 17 year old, had joined the ship the previous day, this being his first job since leaving school.
Shortly after the start of dredging, the untrained crewman started to clear the cockles from the chute into the hold as he had the previous day. As he was scrapping the cockles down the chute with his right hand, he placed his left hand on the riddle frame assuming there was enough space to grip between the supporting frame and the rotating drum.
 
The unguarded riddle construction formed a shear trap that caught the crewman’s left thumb and pulled his left arm into the riddle, causing serious injury.

On 14th September 2006 an accident occurred in the Main Engine Room, bottom plates, Starboard side, between No. 1 and 2 boilers of the passenger liner QUEEN MARY 2.
Three men were burnt/scalded by an unexpected release of very hot water. One man later died of his injuries.
During the night, No 4 economizer circulating failed due to a leaking mechanical seal, and the discharge pressure dropped off. To avoid damage to the boiler, No 4 diesel was stopped and a Gas Turbine was started. 
The isolation valves to and from the pump were closed and locked and work on draining down the economizer began. The pump casing vents were also opened to let the pump drain down. After the vessel's arrival in port, the day work maintenance team began to remove the pump for repair. It was noted that the pressure in the pump was zero and the drains had stopped running.  At this time the vent pipe was removed from the volute casing and the casing was open to atmosphere.
When the pump impeller casing was moved back from the volute casing (which was left in place bolted to the pipework), a quantity of very hot water / steam issued from the volute casing splashing up over the mechanic, who was lifting the impeller casing out, inflicting scald burns over the front of his body, arms and legs. 
Water also splashed over the Senior Maintenance engineer and the other mechanic, who were standing to each side, inflicting small scald burns to their faces.
Although this was originally reported as a hazardous incident, the man has since died from his injuries, and the incident has therefore been upgraded.
Standard and reasonable precautions were followed prior to carrying out this maintenance, (which has been done many times in the past). The system had been vented and proved zero pressure. Due to the design of the pipe work system, the suction lines to the pumps which are situated between the boilers on the tank top level, comes from the top half of the vertical boiler just below the working water level. 
This height from the pump suction to the top of the pipe where it comes out of the boiler shell is 5 meters, X DN150mm bore. This constitutes a static head of water of 0.5 bar with no boiler pressure acting on it.  The volume of water in the pipe would be 88 ltrs when full.
When the water is draining from the pump casing, the weight of water and the level going down the pipe would pull a vacuum in the top section of the pipe, till the vacuum generated was able to support the remaining volume of water left in the pipe, which would then be much less than 88 ltrs. At this point the water would be suspended in the pipe with the bottom end open to atmosphere till the vacuum broke and the water gushed out. This time is indeterminable, but in this case it occurred almost instantly. 
A report from owners stated that that additional drain/vent valves were fitted to the economiser circ pump system at various points. These will allow safe drainage AND venting, ensuring that the long vertical suction legs cannot trap water under a standing vacuum effect.
Additional valves were fitted on suction side of all 4 econ circ pumps that will ensure a minimum of 2 valve separation when overhauling these pumps.

On 13th September 2006 the FRIO PACIFIC was proceeding with sea pilot assistance Mississippi River Gulf Outlet Canal from Pilot Station to berth of port of New Orleans. When the ship was in area of lake Athanasio (light buoys No. 71-72) we started our manoeuvres. At 18:55 hours LT  a strong squall blew up with wind N direction force 35 m/sec in gusts, with thunderstorms overhead. Visibility was about 0.1 mile. The ship lost steering control, and began to drift fast to left side of fairway. I ordered bosun starboard anchor to avoid further movement of ship to a coastal line. At 19:09 the starboard anchor was dropped, and at 19.15 hours LT the ship ran aground distance 0.12n. mile off shore in position with coordinates 29º 43.87N 089º 28W.01W. The main engine was stopped.

ON 13TH SEPTEMBER 2006 THE M/V "SALAR" WAS ANCHORED AT AJMAN PORT. AT APPROXIMATELY 08.00 HOURS LT  MR. PRADEEP KUMAR INFORMED THE MASTER THAT HE HAD SIGHTED MR.SANAT KUMAR SINGH'S DEAD BODY FLOATING IN THE WATER BETWEEN THE TUG "AYAT 1" AND THE CONCRETE FACE OF THE QUAY. BY THAT TIME POLICE HAD ALREADY REACHED THE LOCATION AS SOMEBODY HAD ALREADY NOTIFIED THEM.
THE MASTER'S REPORT IS ATTACHED HEREWITH.

At 17.30 hours LT on 10 September 2006, the Hong Kong registered bulk carrier CRECIENTE berthed in Port Hedland, Western Australia, to load a cargo of iron ore.
At about 02.45 hours LT on 12 September, the almost fully laden ship broke away from the wharf under the influence of a strong ebb tide.
Despite the use of several tugs and the ship’s engine, it was not possible to manoeuvre the ship back alongside the wharf. The harbour master decided to hold the ship in the deepest part of the port’s entrance channel until the next high tide.
By about 06.15 hours LT on 12 September, the ship was firmly aground in the channel and, at about 09.50, it was successfully refloated.
The ATSB investigation found that the effective holding capacity of the ship’s mooring winch brakes was reduced by the number of layers of mooring line on the winch drums and the poor condition of their brakes. The investigation also found that it was highly likely that the brakes had not been sufficiently tightened and that the mooring winches were not effectively monitored in the time leading up to the incident.
The investigation also found that neither the port authority nor the ship’s master had identified the possibility of the ship breaking away from its berth and appropriately assessed the risks associated with this potential hazard. 
The report issued two recommendations and five safety advisory notices to address the identified safety issues.

THE SHIP`S COURSE COULDN'T BE MAINTANED BY AUTO STEERING FROM WATCHING OFFICER ON BRIDGE ON 11TH 2006 AT 17:50 HOURS IN POSITION LAT 08-21S, LONG 132-28W. WE IMMEDIATELY CHECKED AND TESTED STEERING EQUIPMENTS ON BRIDGE AND STEERING ROOM, STEERING STAND ON BRIDGE CHANGED STEER TO HAND AND NON-FOLLOW UP CONTROLLER FROM AUTO STEER, HOWEVER WE WERE NOT ABLE TO ACQUIRE AN EFFECT WITH A RUDDER, THEN CHECKED AND TESTED STEERING GEAR AND STEERING PUMPS, ANY TROUBLE WAS NOT FOUND IN RUDDER, EQUIPMENT, IT LAPSED INTO THE STATE WHERE AN EFFECT WITH A RUDDER CANNOT BE ACQUIRED. ALTHOUGH THE EFFECT IS NOT ACQUIRED. IT IS PROCEEDING WITHOUT STRAYING OFF A SCHEDULE COURSE GREATLY. ON 12TH SEPTEMBER 2006, AT 06:35 HOURS IN POSITION LAT 08-32S, LONG 130-29W, SINCE THE SUNRISE THA MAIN ENGINE STOPPED, AND THEN LAUNCHING SUPPLY WORK BOAT FOR CHECKING THE RUDDER. AS A RESULT OF CHECKING A RUDDER, IT WAS FOUND THAT THE RUDDER HAS FALLEN OUT. WE DID WATCH SEVERE AND CONTINUED NAVIGATING BY OWN STRENGTH. IT MET WITH THE OCEAN TUGBOAT ON 27TH 0030 HOURS, AND SHIPS COMMENCED TOWING BY TUGBOAT TO JAPAN. ON 16TH OCTOBER 2006, 1510 HOURS, ARRIVED ATKOKURA.
I HEREBY THEREFORE, THE NOTE THIS PROTEST AGAINT OF DAMMAGES OF RUDDER, RESERVING MY RIGHT TO EXTEND THIS PROTES.

At 09.15 hours LT on 11 September 2006 the bulk carrier ALIKI L was manoeuvring to shift anchorage position due to dragging, when the vessel was observed to vibrate slightly.  At about 09.45 hours LT after the starboard anchor was dropped to the planned anchor position, the chief engineer reported to the bridge some ingress of water in the engine-room starboard void space.  At 10.15 hours LT, the chief engineer reported that the manhole of the void space was closed and the ingress of water contained.

At 10.45 hours LT all water ballast and fuel oil tanks and cargo hold bilge wells were checked and found intact except for no. 5 starboard double bottom ballast tank.  It was also noticed that the sounding was gradually increasing.  After activating the SOPEP, the water ingress was brought under control a few hours later.  At 15.25 hours LT, the cargo discharge operations were resumed normally.At 1045 all water ballast and fuel oil tanks and cargo hold bilge wells were checked and found intact except for no. 5 starboard double bottom ballast tank.  It was also noticed that the sounding was gradually increasing.  After activating the SOPEP, the water ingress was brought under control in a few hours later.  At 1525, the cargo discharge operations were resumed normally.

SOLASStatus: MERCANDIA IV: Unknown/unspecified, SUNDBUSS PERNILLE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
In dense fog MERCANDIA IV had just left Helsinore and SUNDBUSS PERNILLE was on her way to enter the port.
The port bow of MERCANDIA IV hit the port side of SUNDBUSS PERNILLE. MERCANDIA IV had some scratches and a dent and fracture in the port bow port. She returned to Helsingoer. SUNDBUSS PERNILLE had a dent in her port side and her wheelhouse smashed. 4 passenger got minor injuries when the vessel heeled over when being hit. SUNDBUSS PERNILLE sailed into the port on her own.

Prior to incident, the general cargo ship BALSA 59 was lying at Sorel Anchorage, with both Port & Starboard  anchors with 3 shackles in the water on the Port Chain & 2 shackles in the water on the Starboard Chain.

On 10 September 2006 the docking Pilot was on board and at 23.28 hours LT we started to heave-up the Port Anchor, but the Anchor Shackle was caught at the lip of the Hawsepipe, which added undue strain on the chain, which slipped from the wildcat, and when the chain was caught again on the wildcat the sudden jerk caused the anchor to break its swivel and drop into the water.

0500: Vessel is approaching Sharjah Port. Gera tested as per BCL9.
0530: Have arrived at Sharjah Pilot Station. Have tested ME Astern-NO REMARKS.
0600: Pilot Capt. Mukhtar is on board.
0610: Entered the channel.
0630: Have stranded by port forepart between Buoy No. 6 an No. 8 at psn Lat. 25 22, 44 N Long 055 22,29 E Approx speed abt 1,9 knot. Distance to head of breakwater abt 3 cbt.
0631: ME stopped. Commenced sounding of tanks. Commenced sounding of water around the vessel.
0633: Tug LAYYAH started pushing at portside forward.
0640: Tugs AL HAMRIYAH and Sharjah 1 started pushing at portside midship and aft have started to pump ballast water from PS to STB heeling tanks initial report to manager QA Team Captain Ganesh Upadhyay of MOSM ( Singapure).
0646: Completed to pump ballast water from PS to STB heeling tanks. list 2 degrees to STB.
0652: Made tug LAYYAH fast STB aft/ships line.
0654: Ships line parted.
0703: Made sopundings of water depth around the vessel.
0710:Report to Captain Ganesh Upadhyay and Captain Anil Puri regarding further progress.
0711: Made tug LAYYAH fast STB aft/ ships line.
0712: Have decided to postpone any power until the tide will rise in order to prevent damage of the vessel.
0715: Have completed sounding of all tanks - have no changes if compare with departure figures.
0955: Vessel has commenced slight movement.
1000: Vessel has self-floated with 0 list. Resumed entering the port. Made tug LAYYAH fast aft PS.
1025: First line Ashore.
1036:Finish with engine. Made fast STB side alongside, 4 + 2 each

InitialEvent: informed about the incident were ( death of crew)
SummaryOfEvents:
At approximately 06.30 hours LT on September 10th 2006  the Mess man on board vehicles carrier TRANS FUTURE 7, Joel J. Libatique,  made a wake up call to the Chief Cook Samuel G. Villarica over the phone and by knocking on the cook´s cabin door, but nobody answered his calls. He informed the Chief Officer and went to the cook´s cabin to open it with the ship´s master key where he found the Chief Cook lying on his cabin floor face down, with his head to his left side over his right arm.
There was no sign of movement, pulse or breathing, and his legs were cold and pale.

The Gulizar Ana was on ballast voyager from Deliskelesi, Turkey to Galati, Romania –Port on Danube River- for loading of about 3000 tm of steel coils. On 8 September 2006, before entering on Sulina Cannel, the Gulizar Ana has discharged ship’s ballast water from ballast tanks No.2 P/S and 4 P/S.

On 9 September 2006 at 18:10 hours the ship berthed at Galati, berth No.50 alongside of floating cane “Dobrinesti 1 and Dobrinesti 2”.
In the same day at 20:00 hours the loading commenced.  After loading of the 5th steel coils on 9 September at 20:55 hours, the ship began to lean on starboard side till its accommodation has propped on main deck of floating crane “Dobrinesti 2”

The list of the vessel has been of 51, at this angle the river water was at not more that 20 centimetre of hatch coaming, engine room and starboard side crew quarter have been flooded.
Immediately after the incident, four steel coils have been discharged and rescue operation started.
On 21st September 2006 rescue operations have been completed and vessel brought on seaworthiness condition.

SOLASStatus: CAPITAL QUEEN: SOLAS, SHUI YANG JIANG 698: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 9th September 2006 at 12.00 hours LT the M/V CAPITAL QUEEN departed in ballast condition from Zhang jia gang  port in Chang Jiang river, CHINA, en route for JAPAN under pilot command. The keelboat “shui yang jiang 698”, carrying a full load of sand, was sailing downstream. The two vessels were therefore sailing in the same course, and the “Capital Queen”was overtaken because the pilot of “Capital Queen” did not keep effective watch. At 17.08 hours LT a collision occurred, resulting in the sinking of the keelboat “Shui Yang Jiang 698”. One of her crew members died as a result.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
At about 05:54 pm on 9 September 2006, the vessel KLENODEN sailing under Finnish flag collided with the German container vessel HANJIN CAIRO which was moored at the Predöhlkai.
The cause for the collision were problems with the variable pitch propeller system of KLENODEN, which have been attributed to an assembly error during previous maintenance work.  As a consequence, the vessel's command was no longer aware of the pitch of the propeller blades.  An emergency anchoring performed could not prevent the collision.
The bow of KLENODEN was heavily incised along an area about 8.5m long and 3.6m high, and the foremast was bent.  
The stern of HANJIN CAIRO was dented by the impact at about 5m above the waterline, with a hole of about 10cm x 10cm in the hull. In addition, an area about 80cm wide and 3.5m high was ripped from the bulbous bow.
After the collision, KLENODEN was towed to her berth with the assistance of tugs.

SOLASStatus: NIKOLAOS K: Unknown/unspecified, PENG HE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On 8th September 2006 at 18.28 hours LT the bulk carrier MV NIKOLAOS K collided with Chinese MV PENG HE, which was mooring at berth NO.2 of Xiji coal wharf Huangpu new port, Guangzhou China.
As a result of the collision the  port bow of MV NIKOLAOS K pointed at an angle of 35 degrees between the two vessels – on the starboard quarter - with the consequence that MV PENG HE's accommodation and hull area were partly damaged.
MV NIKOLAOS K also sustained slight damage to the port bow, but was fit to proceed to anchorage in the port of Guangzhou.

The jack-up barge Octopus was being towed from Kirkwall to Seal Skerry Bay in the Orkney Islands by the tug Harald, to act as a platform for the installation of a prototype tidal turbine. The tug and tow altered their route to pass to the west of little Green Holm Island, due to the strong tidal streams experienced during the passage, a route not usually used by deep draught ship. As the tug and tow rounded the south of Little Green Holm Islands the barge, which was being towed with its legs extended to depth of 13m, grounding on an uncharted bank of 7.m.

Octopus sustained buckling damage to 4 barge legs, resulting in substantial cost and project delays. There were no injuries and no damage to the tug Harald

SOLASStatus: RED NACRE: Unknown/unspecified, SKY DUKE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On 8th September 2006 at 11.43 hours LT the Bulk Carrier RED NACRE  (38364 gt, built 1999) and Container Ship Sky Duke (3992 gt, built 1996) were in collision in Kobe Port without injuries or oil leak. RED NACRE  sustained a crack on the starboard side, causing it to list to the starboard but arrived at Kobe Port under its own power for discharge. After completion of the discharge operation she was towed to a dockyard in Yura for repairs. 
The Sky Duke did not suffer serious damage.

SOLASStatus: IRENE OLDENDORFF: Unknown/unspecified, LIANG ZHU: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 7th September 2006 the bulk carrier “IRENE OLDENDORFF” was on the Chang Jiang river in China, when at 19.45 hours LT it was involved in a collision with MV “LIANG CHU”, which was being towed by “YUN TONG 7”.

AT 2050　04TH　SEP，2006, WHEN M/V DOLPHINA LEFT SHANTOU PORT, CHINA, HER SUPERCHARGER OF MAIN ENGINE EXPLODED AND CAUSED FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM, THEN THE VESSEL WAS OUT OF CONTROL AND  GROUNDED, THANKS TO RESCUE ORGANIZED BY SHANTOU MARITIME ADMINISTRATION, THE FIRE WAS PUT OUT QUICKLY, THE VESSEL WAS OUT OF GROUND AFTER 2 HOURS, AND THE ACCIDENT CAUSED 2 CREWMEMBERS INJURY.

VELOS passed The Skaw at 0300 hours LT on 3 September 2006 on a voyage from Ventspils, Latvia to China with at cargo 63.927,24 MT of Muriate of Potash in bulk. 

After passing the Skaw VELOS continued on a south westerly course along the west coast of Jutland, Denmark. 

At about 0635 hours VELOS touched the ground with a speed of approx. 11 knots, which resulted in severe bottom damage. The forepeak tank and DB tanks No. 1, 2, 3, and 4 port side were flooded within minutes. 

There was no pollution or personal injury to any of the crew of 25 persons.

About an hour after having touched the ground the situation on board was stable. All possible sources of leaking had been checked, and no critical flooding was found. VELOS, which was afloat immediately after having touch of ground, anchored near by the grounding position and was moved to more safe anchorage the following day.

Location: Off Lifou, Îles de Loyauté en Nouvelle-Caledonie
SummaryOfEvents:
Le petit pétrolier français à double-fond Saint-Vincent, appartenant à la société néo-calédonienne CMTP revenait au moment  des fait sur Ballasts lourd  de Santo (Vanuatu) à Nouméa.

A l’appareillage, la mer est forte, mais les conditions météorologiques  s’améliorent quand le navire double  le cap des Pins à Lifou, au large des Îles Loyauté. 
Le deux septembre 2006 vers 17:00 heures à milles nautiques dans le sud de l’île de Lifou et à demi-journée du canal de la Havannah , à l’entrée  Sud-Est du lagon de la Nouvelle-Calédonie, le navire prend soudainement une forte gîte sur le bâbord. En une trentaine de minute, il engage, se couche et coule. Le canot à chute libre ne pourra pas être mis en œuvre du fait de la gîte excessive, et seul le radeau de survie pneumatique bâbord sera  utilisé. L’équipage au complet abandonne le navire vers 17:30 heures et passe la nuit dans ce radeau de survie  pneumatique  bâbord  sera utilisé.
L’équipage au complet abandonne le navire  vers 17:30 heures  et passe la nuit dans ce radeau.

L’alerte n’est reçue pas le MRCC de Nouméa en tout début de soirée  et les secours sont organisés par  le MRCC dans  le cadre de l’Action de l’Etat en mer. L’hélicoptère PUMA de l’ETOM commence  les recherches  sur site au lever du jour. Les naufragés sont retrouvés à 07:05 heures après une heure de recherches puis  hélitreuillés sains et saufs en deux rotations d’hélicoptère le 3 Septembre au matin.

On 2nd September 2006 the UK flagged vehicle carrier MORNING MIRACLE was at Port Suez anchorage area waiting to join the northbound convoy. At 05.45 hours LT, during a turn with a pilot onboard the ship, she experienced steering problems - steering was in hand control - and the rudder remained at 5 degrees to starboard. No alarms were heard but the alarm status was recorded on the data logger system.  The AB on the helm immediately informed the pilot and officers but the pilot did not hear him as he was talking on the vhf radio at the time.  The officer of the watch checked the steering motor indications, both motors indications showed them to be "on".  The 3/O immediately contacted the engine room and the duty engineer went to the steering gear compartment.  He also informed the captain who was in his cabin at the time. The engineer moved the rudder a few degrees using the local emergency control in the steering gear compartment and steering was re-instated.  In the meantime the 3/O had started the bow thruster to assist in steering.  Unfortunately the pilot operated the thruster control, but the motor tripped on overload because the motor was not at the correct operating speed.  However, at 08.23 hours LT the ship touched bottom.  A standby tug put a line aboard and the vessel was immediately hauled off.  The port authorities, class and ship's staff thoroughly checked the steering system but no defects were discovered. There was no damage to the hull and the ship was able to resume its passage after hull checks.
