A manufacturer’s representative found a faulty PCB on the steering Follow Up (FU) unit which was the cause of the initial failure.  The 3/0 was unfamiliar with the method of changing from FU to Non FU in the event of an emergency, but had he done so  the grounding would not have occurred.

The company has since conducted further training with the bridge team to ensure that they fully understand the alternative methods of steering.

While approaching Xiamen, the ship Pu You Hao crossed from starboard to port closely ahead of ANL Australia and continued on a similar course. Without warming Pu You 10 Hao altered course to starboard. The ships sterns came into contact. ANL Australia immediately called the other ship but received no reply.

On 30th July 2006 the general cargo ship NAMA was en route from Port Karachi to Port Kakinada. At 16.00 hours LT in position GPS Lat: 16 20.2 N Lon: 082 22.5 E, she wasl heading 002 deg, speed 12 knts. when a floating platform with 2 tugs appeared crossing our course to starboard/ from shore to open sea / at a distance of 6 nm. Due ahead of the platform there were a lot of fishing boats. NAMA altered her course to port,  heading 355 degress in order to pass aft of east moving platform.
At 18.50 hours LT GPS lat: 16 43.3 N lon: 082 23.5 E, the vessel grounded in shallow waters. In spite of efforts to refloat, the vessel remained grounded in sandy water 3.0 nm east of coast. Bad weather in the next few days shifted the vessel closer to the coast. Further efforts to refloat the vessel on 1st July 2006 were also unsuccessful and the starboard anchor chain was broken by swell blows  10 m far of anchor. The salvage tug boat MAHO OYA  arrived on 9 th August 2006 at 19.00 hours LT and on 10th August refloating efforts were again made using the engine and tug boat. The vessel was refloated at 08.50 hours LT on 11th August and she proceeded to Kakinada port where she dropped anchor at  12.25 hours.

At 1400 on 28 August 2006, MASSIVE TIDE departed Dampier with a load of bulk cargo for the drill rig Ensco 106.  After clearing the berth, the master handed over the watch to the second mate who then remained in charge of the watch for the transit to the drill rig.
The master took over the watch when the ship reached the drill rig at 1950 and the second mate remained on the bridge to operate the bulk-board for the cargo transfer.  After completion of cargo operations, the master handed the watch back to the second mate, and then went to bed.
At 0100 on 29 August, the ship departed the drill rig.  The second mate checked the global positioning system (GPS) unit, and then set the autopilot to follow a course of 129° (T).  The weather was good with light winds, slight seas and visibility of about eight miles.
At 0200 and 0400, the second mate recorded the ship's GPS position in the deck log book, but did not plot either position on the navigational chart.  At about 0400, the bridge lookouts changed watches but the second mate decided to leave the chief mate in bed until the ship reached the Dampier Sea Buoy.
At 0445, MASSIVE TIDE was making good a speed of 9.8 knots when it grounded on the shoals approaching the western shore of Rosemary Island.
The crew were called out and checks of the ship, its machinery and the surrounding area revealed that no damage or pollution had occurred.  Immediate attempts to refloat the ship were unsuccessful and plans were put in place to try again on the next high tide.  At 1035, MASSIVE TIDE floated free without assistance.

On 25th August 2006 the M/V ISLAND SEAL ran aground in the Virgin Isles at 17.30 hours LT. This resulted in cracks to the fore peak tanks at starboard and port side. The vessel finally sank in Brandywine Bay.

SOLASStatus: CSCL NINGBO: SOLAS, JIN HAI DA 18: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At about 23.15 hours LT on 23rd August 2006, the Hong Kong registered container ship CSCL NINGBO collided with the Chinese registered cargo ship Jin Hai Da 18 at approximate position 24º10.5’N 118º17.0’E.  At the time of the accident, the weather conditions were fine with east-northeasterly wind at force 3. The sea was slight and the visibility was about 7 nautical miles. The current was setting northwest at the rate of 2.8 knots. CSCL NINGBO sustained minor damages to the hull on the port side and Jin Hai Da 18 immediately sank after the collision. Five crew members were rescued and three crew members went missing, presumed dead.

SOLASStatus: CSCL NINGBO: SOLAS, JIN HAI DA 18: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At about 23.15 hours LT on 23rd August 2006  (15.15 UTC) the HONG KONG registered container ship CSCL NINGBO collided with the Chinese registered JIN HAI DA 18 at the approximate position 24°10.′41N/118°17.′02E . The M/V JIN HAI DA 18 sank immediately after the collision. Five crew members were rescued, one crewmember died and another two were missing.

SOLASStatus: DELTA ST. PETERSBURG: SOLAS, ELBE 3: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 12:15 hours ( all time in CEST – Central European Summertime  UTC + 2 hours), approximately 0.5 nm north of Elbe  Buoy 1, the pilot tender Elbe 3 heeled so far to port on casting  off from the ship Delta St. Petersburg that it capsized and floated upturned. 
All three persons on board were rescued.
One of the persons was injured and was admitted to the municipal hospital Cuxhaven, where he was treated as an in-patient.
The pilot tender was salvaged and set into operation again after extensive repairs.
There was no visible damage to Delta St. Petersburg.
No environmental damage was reported

ON 22ND AUGUST 2006 THE PANAMANIAN FLAGGED M/V "GRANITNYY BEREG" (IMO 7638167) COLLIDED WITH M/V "KLOSTERTAL" DURING MOORING OPERATIONS AT PORT SANKT PETERSBURG (RUSSIA). THE M/V "KLOSTERTAL" WAS MOORED AT THE BERTH NO 5-6.
AFTER INVESTIGATIONS MADE BY AQUASHIP LTD IT WAS ESTABLISHED THAT M/V "GRANITNYY BEREG" WAS PROCEEDING TO THE KBZ BERTH NO 17 WITH PILOT ON BOARD. TUGBOAT "VETRA" WAS FASTENED ON THE FORECASTLE AND SECOND TUGBOAT "MUSSON" WAS PROCEEDING NEAR AFT OF THE VESSEL. AT 12.34 HOURS LT, AFTER CHANGING COURSE AND WHILE SAILING IN THE CHANNEL, TUGBOAT "VETRA" QUICKLY TURNED TO STARBOARD AND INFORMED THE MV "GRANITNYY BEREG" THAT TUGBOAT RUDDER WAS OUT OF ORDER.
CREW OF THE TUGBOAT TRIED TO RELEASE TUG LINE BUT EMERGENCY RELEASE DEVICE WAS OUT OF ORDER AND MV GRANITNYY BEREG BEGAN TO TURN RAPIDLY TO THE BERTH NO 5-6 WHERE MV "KLOSTERTAL" WAS BERTHED.
AT 12.35 HOURS LT THE MASTER OF M/V "GRANITNYY BEREG" SENT ORDER TO ENGINE ROOM "FULL SPEED ASTERN", AND LET GO PORT ANCHOR.
AT 12.39 HOURS LT, IN SPITE OF THE MEASURES TAKEN MV GRANITNYY BEREG HER STEM HIT THE CONSTRUCTION STANCHION OF THE MV "KLOSTERTAL" ON THE PORT SIDE 3, FIVE METERS ABOVE THE WATERLINE.
DAMAGES TO THE MV "KLOSTERTAL" WERE MINOR AND VESSEL SAILED A FEW HOURS LATER.
AT 14.20 HOURS ON 22ND AUGUST 2006 THE M/V "GRANITNYY BEREG" COMPLETED BERTHING AT BERTH NO 17.

Location: At the  A-2 Roadstead of the port of Daesan
SummaryOfEvents: The 2.645 G/T tanker Heung Gook No.9 powered by one 1.765 kw diesel engine unloaded  naphtha at the Samsung Chemical wharf in the port of Daesan and anchored at the A-2 Roadstead at the same port  at 09:10 hours on 22 August 2006. While Tank No.4 on the portside was gas-freed, a fire broke out on the deck at 11:40 hours on the same day, in position 37°03.00 N and 126°23.14 E. The fire left one crew member dead and two injured

Location: South of the Isle of Wight
SummaryOfEvents:
The yacht OUZO sailed from Bembridge, Isle of Wight (IOW), bound for Dartmouth, Devon on the evening of 20 August 2006.  She had her three regular crew members on board who were intending to take part in the Dartmouth Royal Regatta.
The body of one of the crew members was found in the sea just before midday on 22 August about 10 miles south of the Nab Tower.  At about 1900 on the following day, the bodies of the other two crew were recovered from the sea.  They had all been wearing inflated lifejackets and good quality yachting clothing.  Despite extensive surface and sub-surface searches no trace of the yacht has been found.
The last record of the yacht was at 2230 on 20 August when she went out of range of the Southampton/Portsmouth VTS radar system in Sandown Bay.  At this time it is believed that the yacht was sailing close hauled in a south-south-westerly direction.
Voyage data recorder (VDR) records from ships that had been in the area during the night of 20/21 August were recovered and analysed by MAIB inspectors in order to use the radar information to trace the movements of the yacht.  In the course of this analysis, it became apparent that the ro-ro passenger ferry PRIDE OF BILBAO had had an encounter with a small yacht about 6 miles south of St Catherine's Point, IOW, in the early hours of the morning of 21 August.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The container ship, which was on a voyage from Antwerp to the East Coast of The USA via Aarhus, Denmark and was shortly after noon on 20 august 2006 approaching the Port of Aarhus and passing an area with relatively shallow water. The ship’s maximum draught was 10,3 meters. According the passage plan the ship should pass just south of a ground with a depth of 10 meters and less which was clearly marked in the chart. Both AIS and the ship’s electronic chart have shown that the ship at the time of the grounding was north of the planned route. The vessel touched the ground with a ground speed of approx. 13 knots, and it later turned out that the ship’s bottom had been severally damaged in the forward part of the ship. The ship was able to continue to the Port of Aarhus. The ship was alongside at 1500 hours. The ship afterwards had to return to Antwerp and later Hamburg for discharging of some of the cargo and for repairs. The repairs are expected to be concluded October 2006.

At about 08.45 hours LT on the 16th August, 2006, the British bulk carrier CAPE KESTREL, which was navigating from MA ZHI anchorage to Singapore, made contact with the XIA ZHI MING fairway (AP: 29°47′.6N/122°15.2E). The accident resulted in damage to the submarine cable.

ON 15TH AUGUST 2006 WHILE PASSING THE TRAFFIC SEPARATION SYSTEM VLIELAND, THE CHIEF ENGINEER NOTICED AN "EXHAUST GAS HIGH TEMPERATURE ALARM" BEFORE THE TURBOCHARGER. HE IMMMEDIATELY CALLED THE BRIDGE AND ASKED FOR A MANUAL SLOWDOWN. AFTER ABOUT 15 MINUTES, THE CHIEF ENGINEER INFORMED CREW THAT REPAIRS TO THE MAIN ENGINE WERE NECESSARY, WHEREUPON THE VESSEL LEFT THE TSS AND ANCHORED: LAT 53º17.84N, LONG 004º24.4E. AT 20.00 HOURS LT.

THE CREW OPENED ALL MAIN ENGINE CRANKCASE COVERS. THE CHIEF ENGINEER FOUND THAT THE CONNECTING ROD BEARING SHELLS OF UNIT NO 2 HAD ROTATED WITHIN THE POCKETS, AND A LOT OF WHITE METAL PARTICLES WERE FOUND WITHIN THE CRANKCASE.

THE BEARING SHELLS OF UNIT NO 2 WERE REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH A SPARE SET. THE WHITE METAL PARTICLES WERE REMOVED FROM THE CRANKCASE AND THE CRANKPIN WAS POLISHED PRIOR TO FITTING THE SPARE SET.

AFTER MOUNTING THE SPARE SET, THE ENGINE WAS CLOSED AGAIN AND TRIALS WERE CONDUCTED. AFTER THAT, THE CRANKCASE WAS OPENED AGAIN FOR INSPECTION. THE WHITE METAL OF THE BEARINGS AGAIN APPEARED MELTED. THE ENGINE WAS CLOSED AGAIN. THE OWNER WAS INFORMED AND TOWAGE WAS ARRANGED TO IJMUIDEN. THE VESSEL ARRIVED IN IJMUIDEN ON 17TH AUGUST 2006 AT 09.55 HOURS LT AND NECESSARY REPAIRS WERE CARRIED OUT IN THE PRESENCE OF CLASS SURVEYORS.
On 15th August 2006 the bulk carrier MIDAS  was at sea in extremely heavy weather. As a result of this, some of her cargo was damaged, and damages were also sustained to her hull and machinery.

Location: West of the Great Nicobar island in the Indian Ocean
SummaryOfEvents:
On the 14 August 2006, BRIGHT ARTEMIS received a distress signal from AMAR, a cargo ship which was on fire. The BRIGHT ARTEMIS proceeded to the position, when AMAR was swept by a wind wave and struck BRIGHT ARTEMIS.  
The BRIGHT ARTEMIS received a gash of about 1 metre in height and 5 metres in length on the starboard side about 1.7 metres above the water line puncturing two cargo tanks
. 
AMAR crew members on board were rescued by another vessel and are confirmed to be safe. There is no report of any engine malfunctions or any injuries from the Bright Artemis.

On 13 August 2006 the tanker DILESI  was at Lagos outer anchorage awaiting berthing instructions by the local port authorities in order to discharge her cargo, when the Master advised the office that 4 crew members (Master, C/O, 4TH Engineer and Bosun) had been suffering from intermittent fever during the previous week. Immediately the company requested the Master to arrrange throug the local Agent, Deino Maritime, for the said crew members to visit a local Lagos Hospital for further investigation. The Master immediately acted as requested.

At about 18.00 hours LT  on 11/8/2006 the Bosun went to the Master complaining about a nose bleed, and the master advised him to stop working, to rest and then go back ashore for a further Medical check.

On 12/8/2006 at 12.00 midnight the C/O complained about chest pains. The Master advised him to stop taking the medicines. As the fever continued, on and off, the Master decided that the C/O should go back to hospital for further Medical examination. On the same day at 16.30 hours LT the said 4 crew members boarded a service boat in order to go ashore. On the way to Lagos port the propeller of the service boat broke down. Under the circumstances, they could do nothing but wait for a passing vessel/boat to pick them up. In doing so, too much time elapsed and as a result the team arrived at Lagos port late at night, when the Master decided to secure them all toa hotel accommodation to safely rest till the morning hours, when he planned to take them to the Lagoon Hospital for medical assistance.

On 13/8/2006 at 08.00 the Master went to wake up the C/O and he noticed that his mouth was trembling and that he was breathing with difficulty. The Master then went to wake the rest of the crewmembers, Bosun & 4th Engineer to take them all to hospital. at 10.30 hours LT the Master found the C/O dead. They asked the Hotel Staff (lodging house) to call for a doctor. They transferred the C/O immediately to the Military Hospital Ikoyi Lagos where they confirmed he was dead on arrival. The Autopsy results given by the Military Hospital Ikoyi Lagos showed Septicaemic Shock.

On 12th August 2006 the M/V SPRING AUSTER was en route from Sakai to Yizheng,China (via Chanjiangkou). It was reported that  the AB went missing between 1800 and 2000hrs that night, and was assumed lost.

M.T. BITUMEN EXPRESS called at port of Jiaxing on 05th Aug, 2006 .At 1130 LT 11th Aug, 2006, M.T. BITUMEN EXPRESS hit on the Hangzhou Bay Bridge in the position 30°32.98′N/121°03.39′E due to the anchor dragging. Result in serious damage of the Hangzhou Bay Bridge on standing pier and bridge deck, ship’s bow mast and radar mast which standing on the top of the bridge, ect.
The tanker BITUMEN EXPRESS called at the port of Jiaxing on 05th August 2006. At 11.30 hours LT on 11th August 2006, the M.T. BITUMEN EXPRESS hit the Hangzhou Bay Bridge in the position 30°32.98′N/121°03.39′E due to the anchor dragging. This resulted in serious damage to the Hangzhou Bay Bridge on the standing pier and bridge deck, the ship’s bow mast and radar mast.  

The tanker BITUMEN EXPRESS called at the port of Jiaxing on 05th August 2006. At 11.30 hours LT on 11th August 2006, the M.T. BITUMEN EXPRESS hit the Hangzhou Bay Bridge in the position 30°32.98′N/121°03.39′E due to the anchor dragging. This resulted in serious damage to the Hangzhou Bay Bridge on the standing pier and bridge deck, the ship’s bow mast and radar mast.

Location: South China Sea, south of island Guimaras
SummaryOfEvents:
SOLAR 1 was en route to a power plant at Zamboanga in the southern island of Mindanao. Because of rough sea, SOLAR 1 sunk at about 500 km southeast of Manila. 18 people of the 20 on board were rescued. Two are still missing. 
The sunken MT Solar 1 single-hull tanker spilled oil in a 15 square nautical miles.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Pollution,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents:
At 2325 on 10 August 2006, the 4,966gt general cargo ship Midland 2 arrived at the pilot station off Plymouth harbour. The ship was fully laden with a cargo of fertiliser, loaded at Safi, in Morocco. 

Before boarding Midland 2, the designated pilot had decided that tug assistance would not be required for berthing, because the north-westerly winds were light and the ship should be quite manoeuvrable as she had two propellers and a bow thruster. After the pilot had boarded the ship, in a position south-east of Penlee Point, he handed the master a two-page Plymouth Pilotage Service passage plan, on which he had marked the proposed route across Plymouth Sound. The pilot and master discussed the vessel’s speed, and it was confirmed that the ship had two fixed propellers and a bow thruster. The master did not give the pilot a ship-specific pilot card, and he did not tell him that there were two steerable nozzles around the propellers which were linked to a single centreline rudder. This unusual steering arrangement was originally designed for this class of ship, to facilitate navigation on major rivers in the Soviet Union. However, these river ships now operate on ocean going routes. 

The engines were placed on full ahead, giving a speed of about 7.5 knots. The pilot made his routine reports to the VTS when passing Penlee Point and the breakwater. The master was stationed at the two telegraphs, and the chief officer acted as helmsman during the passage across the sound.  The pilot gave the helmsman courses to steer and direct helm orders. The two officers did not monitor the ship’s position either by radar or by electronic chart. A passage plan from the pilot station to the berth at Victoria Wharf had not been prepared by the ships’ officers. 

The ship left the Western Channel at the New Ground buoy and set a direct course towards the Cobbler Channel. The engines were slowed down to half ahead, giving a speed of about 4.5 knots. The pilot judged the ship’s progress across Plymouth Sound by observing the navigational lights of the buoys around Mallard Shoal, the end of Mount Batten Breakwater and Fisher’s Nose. As the ship travelled  across the Sound, she was set by the ebb tide to starboard to such an extent that she eventually passed very close to the end of Mount Batten Breakwater and on a heading of north. To make the turn into Cobbler Channel, the pilot gave increasing amounts of starboard helm, which included the nozzles, until it reached hard to starboard. The head needed to reach 048.5˚, and, realising that it was not turning quickly enough, the pilot asked for full ahead on the port engine, full astern on the starboard engine, and the bow thruster to full to starboard. He also ordered the pilot boat to push on the port bow. Although the head began to turn, it was apparent that the ship was closing the shore line immediately to the east of Fisher’s Nose Point, and the pilot asked for full astern on both engines. Midland 2 gently grounded forward on a mixture of mud and sand. However, the falling tide precluded refloatation attempts, even with the assistance of two tugs, until the tide had risen sufficiently enough after low water. A diving survey of the hull found that there was no damage to the ship.

At 21:55 (local time) on 10 August 2006 an engine room fire broke out onboard “Ice Flake” during the passage from Maputo to Cape Town.  Although the fire was quickly brought under control, the engine room was severely damaged and the ship was subsequently towed into Durban for repairs.
The engine room was equipped with a fixed Halon fire fighting system.  Several of the Halon bottles in the engine room failed to discharge
No personal injuries or pollution of the marine environment resulted from the incident.

On July 31st 2006 at approximately 15.30 hours LT the M/V DAYANA weighed anchor off the port of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, en route to the city of Colon, Panama, with 15 crew members on board, none of whom were in good health.
The ship had not been previously inspected by the local authorities, or undergone any of the appropriate checks before weighing anchor. 
There was insufficient fuel and food on board for the onward journey to Panama, and water was gradually entering the ship by the stern main incline which had a broken security pin. The entrance of salt water caused the ship to list dramatically and eventually capsize on 10th August 2006 at 07.30 hours LT. 
13 crew members were rescued, but one died as a result of the incident and a further crew member could not be found.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

Location: 20 km off Cape Irozaki, Shizuoka Prefecture
SummaryOfEvents:
The 499-ton SHINFUTABA, owned by a Hiroshima-based company, with a crew of five was loaded with sand when it hit the 6,306-ton Panama-registered DEWI PARWATI, with 19 crew members in dense fog.
SHINFUTABA sank at 01.40 am. As a result of the collision, and in the area where SHINFUTABA sank, a 24-ton oil slick measuring 100 meters by 250m was spilled.
All five crew members of SHINFUTABA were rescued by the DEWI PARWATI, and one slight injury has been reported amongst the crew.
On 17th August 2006 the M/V FANTASY turned downriver at the above-mentioned location and subsequently ran aground at approx. 17.57 hours LT. Harbour and River pilots were on board at the time.

SOLASStatus: ASIAN VISION: Unknown/unspecified, HAMBURG EXPRESS: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: A Danish container vessel was going to overtake a vehicle carrier from Panama in a narrow area near Antwerp, because the Danish vessel was asked to go into a lock before the Panamanian vessel. There were pilots on board both vessels. The communication between the pilots were Dutch. The pilot was handsteering on board the Danish vessel. It was agreed that the Danish vessel should overtake the Panamanian vessel on the starboard side. During the manoeuvre the Panamanian vessel turned to starboard. The cause is not known to the investigation division. The Danish vessel suffered serious damage on bridge and accommodation.

On 4th August 2006 the Bahamas general cargo ship WESTWOOD ANETTE was unberhing with the assistance of tugs. At 14.25 hours LT the starboard side of the vessel contacted a dolphin. The shell plating was holed in two places in way of No. 4 starboad oil tank, resulting in an escape of oil. The vessel immediately returned to the berth, and oil was transferred from the damaged tank. The owners of the vessel immediately engaged a contractor to clean up the oil spill.

The Chief Officer took over the Officer of Watch at 0400 as usual. Between 0405 and 0410 he was supposed to alter course 15 degrees to port i.acc. with the voyage plan. He sat in the chair and did not alter course and the vessel grounded. An alcohol test proved that the Chief Officer was intoxicated.
After lightering part of the load of split the vessel was refloated the next day at 1630. The damage was limited to some dents in the bottom.

At 0600,3rd Aug, 2006 M/V YONG AN 4, on her voyage from CHITTAGONG, BENGAL to Guangzhou, China, when sailing at pearl river estuary, her main engine went wrong. Due to the strong typhoon, the rescue operation was unsuccessful. At last, under the influence by absence of power and strong typhoon, MV YONG AN 4 got stranding and grounding at 21°36′.52N/112°47′.83E.

“DUK YOUNG 101”WAS TOWING THE BARGE “DUK YOUNG HO”FROM TOKYO TO ZHANGJIAGANG ON 28th JULY, 2006. 
AT 22.10  ON 2nd  AUGUST 2006, “DUK YOUNG 101” COLLIDED WITH A CHINESE VESSEL WHICH WAS NAVIGATING ON THE DOWN BOUND TRAFFIC LANES OF AUXILIARY ROUTES WHEN THE TUG WAS PASSING THROUGH NO.33 BUOY (ABOUT 1000 METRES AWAY FROM NO.33 BUOY)IN THE YANGTZE RIVER. AS A RESULT OF THE COLLISION THE 'DUK YOUNG HO' SUSTAINED A HOLE OF 9 M2  ON HER STARBOARD SIDE ABOVE THE WATER LINE, AND THE COLLISION ALSO CAUSED DEFORMATION TO THE DECK OF CHINESE SHIP.

Location: North entrance to channel at Kochi Port
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: On 23rd July 2006 the container ship OEL VISION left Colombo en route to Kandla (India) at 23.00 hours LT. On 28th July she encountered rough weather and 3 nos. containers on top of No. 3 hatch uprooted from the bar and shifted towards starboard side. The vessel was diverted to Port of Refuge Pipava as per company's instructions. On 30th July 2006, ingress of water was noted inside No. 1 cargo hold. Main engine stopped at 15.45 hours. Unsuccessful attempts were made to tow the vessel away from Bombay High Oil Rigs. Progressive flooding took place in cargo hold and the vessel sank on 2nd august 2006 at 03.42 hours LT near the Rigs.

HSC on passage between Dublin and Holyhead struck an unknown object while at normal service speed at position approximately 13nm west of Holyhead.  HSC came to a stop and identified that stbd T-foil had been sheared from actuation mechanism, pushed up and penetrated hull.  Water ingress was assessed as minor and flooding was controlled, T-foil was locked in central position and vessel continued passage at reduced speed to Holyhead.  No injuries or pollution reported.  HSC was later dry-docked for repairs.

At 08.10 hours LT on 29th July 2006 the general cargo ship C.S. OCEAN  dropped starboard anchor 4 shackles into the water (LAT. 45-39.98N LON. 122-45.77W). At 18.00 hours LT the current was such that the vessel started to swing to portside, and stopped turning at 21.00 hours. The vessel remained steady and without moving from that time onwards, and seemed likely that the vessel had grounded in the shallow water of the anchorage.
One U. S. Coast Guard boat checked the condition of the vessel at 12.30 hours LT on 30th July 2006, and advised the master that the vessel might be grounding by VHF telephone. The U. S. Coast Guard ordered the pilot and tug boat to assist in refloating the vessel through the agent, and the vessel was refloated successfully under the assistance of pilot and tug boats at 16.30 hours LT on 30th July 2006.
The driver NK surveyor and P&I surveyor came on board and checked the underwater line, hull, rudder and propeller etc at 09.40 hours LT on 31st July 2006. They found there was no obvious damage and no personal injury had occurred, but there was some unexpected damage to the vessel's underwater line, hull, rudder and propeller.
Despite all safety regulations being observed, and every precaution taken,  the vessel grounded due to the strong current and insufficient space.

SOLASStatus: JI DA 106: Unknown/unspecified, ORIENTAL PEARL II: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: As she was entering Dandong port, China, the M/V“ORIENTAL PEARL II” collided with the outgoing ship “JIDA 106”of Chinese registry in the port's traffic channel. As a consequence  of the collision,  the M.V. “JIDA 106” sank, but there were no injuries or loss of life.

On the 28 July 2006 at 04.30 hours LT the CHRESTENA II grounded off the port of Portbandar as a result of dragging her anchor.  The vessel grounded during the SW Monsoon and the prevailing onshore winds and swell made the likelihood of re-floating the vessel before the end of the monsoon unlikely.
A damage survey was conducted from which it was determined that the vessel was holed below the waterline in way of Nº's 2 - 5 double bottom tanks and in way of the Engine Room.  A salvage feasibility survey was undertaken and it was considered that the cost of salvage could exceed US$ 5,000,000.  Given the damage to the vessel and cost of salvage it was apparent that the vessel was a Constructive Total Loss.

En route with a full load of soyabeams SYLVE sailed on an unaltered course for about 6 hours before she sailed on shore. The Officer of Watch fell at sleep approx. 2 hours before the grounding and therefore missed the planned change of course. He was tired after the passage of the Kiel Kanal. The vessel was lightered and refloated 3½ days after the grounding.
As a consequence the vessel got 2 cracks in no. 2port and 1 crack in no. 1port.

The incident occurred when discharging seawater from the ballast tanks located in the bottom of the ship.  In the process of the adjustment work, the ship rolled on swells of the sea and suddenly listed in the space of 10 minutes.

All crew were successfully evacuated. One person on the salvage team died.

Vessels portable gangway slipped from the ships side as a crew member was boarding the vessel, and the man fell into the sea between the ships side and the jetty. The man was quickly retrieved from the water by a line handling boat and was transfered to hospital via a local ambulance. He returned to the vessel a short while later after being found to have sustained no injuries.

On 23rd July 2006 trailers, vans and cars were beign loaded onto the roro vessel TOR FUTURA  in the Port of Immingham.  At 02.00 hours LT a crewmember was seriously injured when he was hit by a car and trapped up against a van on the ship’s main deck. The car was being reversed on the deck when the driver, who was a port operative (stevedore), lost control of it. 
The injured crewmember was hospitalized. He had suffered fractures on both legs.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: GAILLARD CUT CANAL IN TRANSIT OF PANAMA CANAL
SummaryOfEvents:
On 22nd July 2007 the tanker GAZ HORIZON lost power and suffered a blackout at 13.50 during transit of the Panama Canal.
The vessel was stopped by using (dropped) starboard anchor with six shackles in the water, and a tug.

On 22nd July 2007 the bulk carrier SALIH ran aground in waters off the coast of Istanbul. At 10.10 hours LT the ship owner reported the incident, and claimed that it was due to a temporary steering failure caused by failure of the pilot control system of the steering stand. There are two pcs of pilot control system at the steering stand, and No. 1 had broken down. The helmsman was negligent in allowing the ship to be led outside the navigation channel and not taking prompt remedial action. 

the Hull underwriter's surveyors agreed on the probably cause submitted by the shipowners.

July, 21 2006/0925 Vessel on arrival Maas Center buoy in position lat 51º55.7N, long 003º42.8 E.
Master proceed to anchorage are/ 1013 Master ordered half astern and main engine do not. once Master received chief enginer information (main engine does not work properly) Master decide to drop the anchor / 1250 Chief engineers informs that cylinders N 1,3,4,5,6,7 from main engine has pinston rings damages.

ON 18th JULY 2006 AT 08.40 LT M/V SIRTE STAR LOST POWER BECAUSE OF A MACHINERY FAILURE, GOING ADRIFT NEAR CANNITELLO (ME).
THE VESSEL TRIED TO START THE ENGINE AGAIN AT 09.55 HOURS LT,  BUT WITHOUT SUCCESS, AND  THE MASTER OF SIRTE STAR REQUESTED ASSISTANCE FROM A TUGBOAT. THE MACISTONE TUG JOINED THE VESSEL AT 10.30 HOURS LT AND TOWED IT TO MESSINA PORT. AT 16.40 HOURS LT THE VESSEL ARRIVED TO PORT AND BERTHED NEAR THE SMEB BASIN.

That at about 0700hrs 18th july 2006, anyhow proceeding with utmost caution and care to avoid SW`y heavy rolling with slow speed untill Ocean tug assist, after then vessel arrived safely at jeddath at local time 0150hrs on the 10th Agust 2006 with Ocean tug"GAL ROSS SEA" In view of the foregoing weather condition and troubled engine encountered fearing and suspecting damages to her cargo, unseen damages to the ship`s bottom, gears, propeller, rudder, hull, properties of the above. That I, the Master hereby note this Protest against any losses, claims and to her other unseen damages that could be attributed to this incident, at the same time reserving the right to extend at a time and place convenient.

ON 18TH JULY 2006 THE CONTAINER CARRIER NYK KAI ARRIVED CRISTOBAL FROM SAVANNAH AT 07.33 HOURS LT. THE VESSEL HAD EARLIER REPORTED AN ENGINE ROOM FIRE WHILST EN ROUTE TO CRISTOBAL, WHICH HAD BEEN EXTINGUISHED BY SHIP'S PERSONNEL AND VESSEL WAS THUS ABLE TO CONTINUE PASSAGE TO CRISTOBAL WITHOUT ASSISTANCE.

SOLASStatus: KU SAN: Unknown/unspecified, YUSHO OCEAN: Unknown/unspecified
Location: 2.3 miles off from Aoshima light house, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
ON 14TH JULY 2006 AT 02.35 HOURS (LMT) THE M/V KU SAN, LOADING 2,769 M/T OF STEEL, LEFT PORT POHANG IN KOREA FOR PORT SENBOKU IN JAPAN. SHE WAS PROCEEDING ON A COURSE OF 071 DEGREES AT A SPEED OF 8.6 KNOTS UNDER THE COMMAND OF THE SECOND MATE AT 04.00 HOURS ON JULY 15 AND ALTERED HER COURSE TO 063 DEGREES TO KEEP TO THE RECOMMENDED ROUTE.
AT 15.20 HOURS THE DUTY OFFICER CHANGED THE STEERING SYSTEM FROM AUTO MODE TO MANUAL AS VISIBILTY WAS DOWN TO LESS THAN 300 METERS, AND CONTINUED TO PROCEED. 
THE DUTY OFFICER THEN OBSERVED THE M/V YUSHO OCEAN (GRT 2524, PANAMA REGISTERED GENERAL CARGO SHIP) ON HER BOW PORT 8 MILES OFF ON THE RADAR. WHEN THE DISTANCE WAS CLOSE TO 300 METERS, THE OFFICER OF KU SAN WORRIED THAT THERE COULD BE A COLLISION AND TOOK HARD TO STARBDARD. AT 04.53 HOURS, THE BOW PORT OF KU SAN COLLIDED WITH THE BOW OF YUSHO OCEAN IN THE POSITION OF LAT. 33-45-42N, LONG. 132-26-18E ABOUT 2.3 MILES FROM AOSHIMA LIGHTHOUSE IN JAPAN. 

AS A RESULT OF THE COLLISION, THE KU SAN SUBSEQUENTLY SANK BY FLOODING WATER FROM THE BREAKAGE OF PORT SIDE, AND THE YUSHO OCEAN SUFFERED DENT DAMAGE AND BREAKAGE ON HER STEM. THE VISIBILITY WAS RESTRICTED TO 300 METERS. WINDS AND WAVES WERE CALM.

Location: In Tokuyama-Kudamatsu Port, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 14th July 2006 at 21.55 hours LT LPG Carrier Oriental Miho (registered Panama, 3,419 gt, built 2006), with 15 crew members (South Korean: 1, Filipino: 14), ran aground on the shallows in Tokuyama-Kudamatsu Port, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan.
As a result, Oriental Miho sustained damage to starboard-side fuel tank and oil spill was observed. Vessel was refloated and repaired. No injuries were reported.

Location: 50 miles west of Ferrol, Finisterre traffic separation scheme
SummaryOfEvents: At 06.33 hours GMT 14th July 2006 a fire broke out in the engine room of the Liberian liquified gas tanker SIGAS EILDON, which was carrying 3,157 tons of polymer proplyene. The vessel lost power shortly afterwards and neither of the vessel's two fire pumps were operable due to a lack of electrical power. At 07.06 GMT, after accounting for all crew members and sealing the engine room, the fixed carbon dioxide fire fighting system in the engine room was activated, and the fire appeared to be extinguished at 08.15 GMT. At 10.27 the engine room was unsealed and ventilated.  Two Spanish coast guard tugs later arrived on the scene, and the vessel was taken under tow and anchored in Ares Bay off La Coruna. At 17.00 GMT on 16th July she was shifted from anchor to berth at Ferrol, and finally was towed to Stade for discharge of cargo and repairs on 26th July 2006.

ON 13TH JULY 2006, M.T. BENEGAS CAUGHT FIRE WHILST DISCHARGING CARGO ALONGSIDE A TIMBER JETTY AT AQABA, JORDAN. TWO CREW MEMBERS ON THE NAVAL BOAT WHICH WAS MADE FAST TO THE "BENEGAS" SUBSEQUENTLY DIED AS A RESULT OF THE FIRE. A CASUALTY REPORT OF THE INVESTIGATION WAS CARRIED OUT ON BOARD THE PANAMÁ REGISTERED VESSEL.

SOLASStatus: LASS URANUS: Unknown/unspecified, XIN FU ZHOU: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
On the 12 July 2006 towards 14:206 hours, the dry bulk cargo ship Lass Uranus, proceeding down the Elbe River under German flag, collided with the Chinese flagged lager container ship Zin Fu Zhou, also proceeding down the Elbe, between buoys 132 and off Finkenwerder.
Both vessel retained buoyancy and were able to proceed without assistance.
There were no personal injuries and no environmentally harmful substances were released as a result of the casualty.

ON 12TH JULY 2006 VERY STRONG TIDAL CURRENTS OF ABOUT 6 KNOTS FROM ASTERN CAUSED THE M/V 'ATLANTICA I' TO DRIFT RAPIDLY TOWARDS THE ANCHORED VESSEL 'M.V. MARIS'. ATLANTICA I WAS HARD TO PORT AND HALF AHEAD AND BECAUSE OF STRONG CURRENT COULD NOT MANOUEVERE CLEAR IN TIME. CAPTAIN E. PEERA GAVE FULL ASTERN ON THE ENGINE AND ORDERED THE ANCHOR TO BE LET GO, BUT IT WAS TOO LATE. JUST BEFORE THE TWO VESSELS COLLIDED THE CAPTAIN FELL UNCONSCIOUS ON THE BRIDGE, LEAVING THE VESSEL WITH THE OOW/THIRD MATE & HELMSMAN ON THE BRIDGE. AT APPROX 12.00 HOURS LT ATLANTICA I COLLIDED WITH OUR BULBOUS BOW / STEM AGAINST M.V. MARIS IN HER PORT BOW / FOREPEAK AREA. 
AT APPROX. 12.02 HOURS LT THE CHIEF OFFICER ARRIVED ON THE BRIDGE AND TOOK COMMAND, DROPPED THE ANCHOR / SECURED THE VESSEL, GIVE FIRST AID TO THE CAPTAIN AND REPORTED THE INCIDENT TO THE PORT CONTROL, ASKING FOR URGENT MEDICAL ASSISTANCE.

ShipsInvolved: BAO LONG MEN (IMO 7906942), CHANG HANG JIANG YANG (-)
SOLASStatus: BAO LONG MEN: SOLAS, CHANG HANG JIANG YANG: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 11th July 2006 at 19.57 hours LT the general cargo vessel “BAO LONG MEN” was proceeding to anchorage when she collided with “ CHANG HANG JIANG YANG”, which was at anchor.

On 11th July 2006 repair works had been carried out on electrical equipment in a small space of approx. 1.8 x 2.2 x 2.7 metres near the aft stern thruster. Some contact cleaner had been used, sprayed out from an aerosol can (approx. half of the content of a 500 ml can). 
The contact cleaner is extremely flammable, and the aerosol can was labelled with the relevant symbol and text for that and with precautions etc. in 7 languages (see note). 

The space was ventilated naturally via the entrance approx. 0.7 x 1.5 m in top and an opening of 0.8 x 1.5 m in the bulkhead, 0.7 m above the bottom.

Besides the repair work on the electrical equipment some welding was to be carried out in the same space. One hour later two crew members entered to prepare for the welding. A little earlier, they had smelled some vapours from the contact cleaner. But they did not smell anything when preparing for the welding.

When one of the crewmembers was testing the welding equipment, an electric arc was made, and a deflagration occurred at 16.40 hours LT. The crewmembers were hit by flames. 

The injured crewmembers were taken to the engine department’s changing room, where they were given first aid, and ambulances were called to take them to hospital.

Dans la nuit du 10 au 11 juillet 2006, le chalutier Owen est en pêche au chalut de fond dans le secteur  des Heaux de Bréhat. Alors qu’in effectue son quatrième trait, le chalut sur le fond, le navire prend une forte gîte puis est envahi par l’arrière  et sombre rapidement.

Les deux hommes d’équipage, qui ont pu prendre place dans le radeau de sauvetage, sont recueillis sains et saufs quelques heures plus tard par un navire de pêche du quartier de Paimpol

On 11th July 2006 a fire broke out on board the cement carrier GLORY MOON. Fire damaged accommodation and associated electrical control system, fire protection and safety construction items, navigational and radio equipment to be specially examined and dealt with as found necessary. Vessel to proceed to Labroy Shipyard. Batam under tug assistance for repairs.

At about 15.40 hours LT on 10 July 2006, while the bulk carrier ENTERPRISE was in the Bass Strait, Australia, an alarm sounded indicating that the main engine lubricating oil pressure was low. When the duty engineer started changing over to a second filter, lubricating oil pressure was lost; causing the engine to stop and the ship to black-out. The engine was restarted and the passage was resumed. 
At 18.05 hours LT, the main engine low lubricating oil pressure alarm sounded again. At 20.00 hours LT, after further inspections had been undertaken, the chief engineer advised the master that the main engine could not be run due to probable bearing damage and that the ship would need to be towed to the nearest port for repairs. The main lubricating oil pump was also found, at this time, to have failed.

The ship was towed into Melbourne, arriving on 15 July, where all main and bottom end bearings were inspected. A large gouge mark was found on one bottom end bearing. 

Further investigations revealed that the gudgeon pin in number five piston had failed when a pre-existing, undetected flaw led to fatigue cracking of the gudgeon pin. The engine manufacturer had not provided sufficient guidance for monitoring the fatigue life of gudgeon pins or for inspecting gudgeon pins for cracks. 

The investigation also found that maintenance planning for the main lubricating oil pump was inadequate in that maintenance was not undertaken according to the manufacturers instructions, despite the fact that the pump had failed previously. 

The execution of routine maintenance on the lubricating oil filter was also inadequate in that the spare filter was not ready for use. The shipboard procedures did not identify the error and the procedures for operating and monitoring the filter were also ineffective.

On 6th July 2006 the fishing vessel ANSGAR was en route to her homeport of Harlingen after a night of fishing.  The skipper was alone on the bridge and detected the platform TYRA WEST E on radar at a distance 10 miles, but he then dozed off. He was woken at approximately 02.20 hours LT  when the vessel hit the southwest leg of the platform at a speed of 9.5 knots. She sustained major damage to her bow, though she was able to continue to Harlingen. The platform was damaged above the water level but the safety of the platform was not endangered.
At 22.38 on 5th July 2006 the m/v FIDELITY 1 ran aground on the river Parana, near Rosario.

SOLASStatus: LADY MOURA: Unknown/unspecified, NEW FLAMENCO: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: ON 4TH JULY 2006 THE 'NEW FLAMENCO'  WAS MANOEUVRING AND CARRYING OUT A BERTHING OPERATION AT IBIZA, BALEARIC ISLANDS.  DURING THE MANOEUVRE THERE WAS AN APPARENT FAILURE OF THE ENGINE CONTROLS FROM THE BRIDGE, AND THE ENGINES FAILED TO RESPOND. THE MASTER DROPPED ANCHORS TO CONTROL THE SPEED OF APPROACH TO THE BERTH, BUT THE VESSEL OVERSHOT ITS APPROACH POSITION AND COLLIDED WITH A YACHT THAT WAS TIED AT THE END OF THE BERTH. THERE WAS NO INJURY TO ANY PERSONNEL AND THE DAMAGE TO VESSEL WAS MINIMAL. THE VESSEL WAS ATTENDED BY CLASS SOCIETY AND PERMITED TO SAIL WITH IMMEDIATE REPAIRS.

SOLASStatus: KEN ZUI: SOLAS, PORT ARTHUR: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 4th July 2006 at 02.10 hours LT the m/v Port Arthur collided with the bulk carrier KEN ZUI, damaging her port quarter.

At 15.54 hours LT on 2nd July 2006 the M/V JIN CHENG ZHOU 18 was approaching to dock at Xinhui Port in China when, due to failure of propulsion machinery, the vessel contacted the dock facilities, causing damage to the dock and the vessel.

On 1st July 2006, as stated in the Master´s report, he altered course in order to avoid the congested group of trawling and fishing boats surrounding the Akashi Kaikyo Channel. However, because the group of boats continued to move closer to the port side of the vessel the Master altered the ship more to starboard to avoid a collision. This maneouvre caused the vessel to run aground.
REPORTED DEAD IN HOSPITAL IN ADEN, CREW WAS FOUND INJURED AND HIS RIGHT ARM WAS AMPUTATED BY DR. M. LINGSTADT (SURGEON) ON FGS SCHLESWIG HOLSTEIN ON 5.7.06 AND FINALLY DEAD AT HOSPITAL.

On 30th June 2006 at 05.30 hours LT the container ship EVER PEACE made contact with South Wharf 32  during berthing operations at Port Melbourne. The owner later requested that an Occasional Survey of the Hull be carried out. The results were as follows:-
Survey:
We were advised that the sterm had penetrated the concrete wharf capping in way of the 7.6m draft mark. The Fore Peak tank was opened and the stern and bulbous bow internal scantlings examined and found in order. A further inspection was carried out using a boat to confirm only minor scrapings to the hull plating at the point of contact on the stem. Divers from Undersea Marine Pty Ltd, conducted an examination of the bottom. Minor scrapings and loss of paint each side of the bulbous bow extending between 4 and 7m from the stem at the 3m draft mark were found. The bow thruster, protective grill and hull plating appeared to be free of any contact or damage from wharf debris.

SOLASStatus: ASTRO LUNA: SOLAS, YM EARTH: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On June 29th 2006  at 20:53 LT,  the crude oil tanker  “ASTRO LUNA” under GREEK FLAG, [(147007 gt), built 1995)] and container Carrier “YM EARTH” under PANAMA FLAG, [(17153 gt, built 2003), collided in Singapore waters.  The collision took place at about 1.5 nautical miles off St. John’s Island/ Singapore Straits. “ASTRO LUNA” was in ballast condition and  “YM EARTH” was loaded with containers. As a consequence of the collision, no injuries or pollution to the environment were reported. After of the collision, the above ships proceeded to the port of SINGAPORE for minor temporary repairs.

ShipsInvolved: CHANG JIANG BRIDGE (IMO 9043770), CMA CGM CAPELLA (IMO 9104914)
SOLASStatus: CHANG JIANG BRIDGE: SOLAS, CMA CGM CAPELLA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On 28th June 2006 at 16.40 hours LT whilst M/V CHANG JIANG BRIDGE was lying safely moored at sect Shangahai, the Hamburg registered container carrier CMA CGM CAPELLA, call sign DICB, came into contact with the stern of CHANG JIANG BRIDGE stern to stern.  The mooring ropes of CHANG JIANG BRIDGE became entangled with the other vessel's stern railing and stern light frames.  Two of CHANG JIANG's  mooring lines parted.

All hand were called on deck for mooring stations, and proceeded to aft mooring deck, and vessel was re moored.

A long dent was observed at the ship's stern & part of the stern railings under the extended platform were bent. Dents were also noted on the stern plates/frames from the inside of steering gear.

Location: North coast of Uma Shima, Kurushima Kaikyo, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 28th June 2006 at 02.11 hours LT the container ship Syms Songshan (registered Antigua and Barbuda, 9,957 gt, built 2005), with 16 crew members on board (German: 2, Filipino: 11, Ukrainian: 3), ran aground on the north coast of Uma Shima, Kurushima Kaikyo, Japan. 
As a result, Syms Songshan suffered dents together with cracks in the forward bottom plating.  She was refloated by a tugboat which had come to assist her and subsequently underwent a temporary repair.

On a voyage from the eastern Baltic to Eldekheila, Egypt with 74,389 mt of coal the bulk carrier was passing south of the island Bornholm, Denmark. The bulk carrier was passing in a distance of 10 NM from the Island and passing Roenne Bank on thrue course 288 deg. speed 13 knots. The ship grounded on a sandbank suddenly and unexpected for the bridgeteam.

The MV CONRAD OLDENDORFF sailed from Gdansk, Poland on 27 June 2006 at 02.30 hours LT bound for El Dekheila, Egypt, loaded with a cargo of 74,389mt of Polish coking coal. The vessel had a mean draft of 14.31m. From the time of departure until 12.00 hours LT, the master of the vessel visited the bridge on several occasions.  The weather and visibility were good and the vessel was making 13.8 knots. At 12.00 hours LT the master made a note on the chart in use at the time to be called when the vessel was 5.5 miles from Ronne Bank.  He then left the bridge.  The vessel reached the indicated position at 15.30 hours LT and the master was called on the bridge. The master checked the vessel’s position on the chart and remained on the bridge. At 15.55 hours LT, the master noted that the autopilot was applying port rudder and that the engine revolutions started to drop.  The master instructed the helmsman to change over from auto to manual steering and to put the wheel hard to starboard.The vessel continued to turn slowly to port for a few seconds and then stopped.  At the time the vessel’s heading was 2740(T).  The master perceived that the vessel had run aground. A damage assessment was initiated by the crewmembers and no water ingress was reported.  Sounding of the seabed around the vessel indicated a depth of water ranging from 13.90m to 18.90m.  At the stern area the water was 18.90m deep.  The master attempted to refloat the vessel by own means, but was unsuccessful. The relevant Danish authorities were also notified of the grounding and assistance was requested to refloat the vessel.  A salvage company was contracted and a salvage plan drawn up and approved by the Danish authorities.  Lightering of part of the cargo and bunkers was carried out. On 01 July 2006 at 21.00 hours LT, the vessel was re-floated with the assistance of two tugs and shifted to a safe anchorage.  An underwater inspection confirmed that the vessel did not suffer any damages due to the grounding. Cargo was reloaded onto the vessel and her voyage was resumed on 02 July 2006 at 18.00 hours LT.

Location: Port of East London, South Africa
SummaryOfEvents: On 26th June 2006 at approximately 18.25 hours LT the Liberian container vessel SAFMARINE AGULHAS left the port of East London, South Africa. The pilot disembarked soon afterwards, whilst the vessel was still within the protection of the breakwater. Soon after that, the ship's main engine stopped due to loss of power, and strong onshore winds pushed her towards the western breakwater. After many attempts, the Chief Engineer and Second Engineer succeeded in starting the engine from the engine control room, but the vessel had already grounded on a sandbank 200 metres from the tip of the southern breakwater. Attempts by two harbour tugs to attach lines to the vessel and tow it off the sand bank in high tide failed when the towing wire parted. Further unsuccessful attempts to refloat were made by Tug Smit Amandla on 29th and 30th June. On July 2nd 2006 a 400 ton crane arrived to help with lightering the cargo, and a dozen railway tanker trucks were secured to take on as much of the vessel's 800 tones of heavy fuel and diesel oil as possible. Cargo removal operations continued until July 24th when the vessel, moving about in the high swell,  was deemed unsafe for salvaging divers to enter the flooded cargo holds - about 20 tons of heavy fuel oil and 100 containers remained on board. The vessel by that time was so badly damaged that it was considered to be a write-off, and on August 5th 2006 the SAFMARINE AGULHAS finally broke in two

At 09.03 hours LT on June 26 2006 the passenger vessel M/V “SEWON 1” was entering Qing Dao harbour and the m/v “Qing You 3” was out bound from the harour at 36°02′.2N 120°17′.3E, when they collided in very dense fog. The accident resulted in the lower part of the fore peak tank of M/V SEWON 1 being broken (allowing ingress of sea water), and  the  No. 1 starboard cargo bunker tank of M/V  “Qing You 3” was also broken, causing bunker oil to leak into the sea.

InitialEvent: Stowaways founded dead on cargo container
SummaryOfEvents:
On June 26, 2006 at approximately 06:10am, tank cleaners Oliver P. Roxas and Pancho D. Patco, who were sweeping the main deck, informed the Bosun Fernando S. Alvarez of noises coming from container #SMLU831110-9. The Bosun informed the Captain and the Chief Officer. The Captain, Bosun Alvarez and O/S Nuñez went to the cargo hold to investigate the noise.
The noise turned out to come from people(stowaways) inside the container. O/S Nuñez managed to communicate from outside the container in their native language(Spanish) with the stowaways. He learned that there were four of them but two had died. At this time the seals on the container were still instact.
The Captain decided to cut the seals and to open the container. When the container was opened they discovered four men inside. Two of the men showed no signs of life. The remaining two showed signs of exhaustion, exposure to heat and dehydration, but were still alive.
The survivors were immediately given water, attended to, and placed in a spare cabin. The two deceased stowaways were left inside the container for further investigation by authorities upon arrival in Miami. Immediately after the discovery, the port agent, Charters-Seaboard Marine and DPA from Seaboard Ship Management Inc. were informed, for further notification to the Coast Guard and other relevant Authorities.
On arrival, the 2 stowaways survivors were transferred to a local hospital and the 2 deceased stowaways were transferred off the vessel to the Coroner´s Office.

On the 26 June 2006 Stolt Perseverance was under outbound pilotage in the Mississipi River. At approximately 04:00 hrs the pilot requested a course change from 155 degree to 160 degrees. The ship continued to turn to starboard despite increasing amounts of port rudder being applied.

 The ship made contact with a barge and tug moored at a rain warf. The tug subsequently sank and the barge broke free from its moorings.

No personal injuries or pollution to the marine environment were reported.

On 26th June 2006 the chemical tanker BOW EUROPE was anchored at Houston when it was noted that machinery damage had occurred.

1. According to the crew's investigation and opinions:

There was an adherence of a high-viscosity substance between all plungers and barrels, when the 1st. stick of FO pump racks had ocurred. It was therefore assumed that the start failure and sticking of the FO pump racks were caused by the adhesive substance, which created a rough surface on the plungers.

2. An overhaul was carried out (plungers and barrels were dismantled from each FO pump) and flashing for FO piping by MDO was finished.
All FO pump racks became smooth after all the plungers and barrels had been dismantled. Unit No. 5 was checked but no abnormal condition was found. (This was coinfirmed with C/E) The adherence of a high-viscosity substance was observed around the top of the plungers, as well as hard scales. The same problem was seen on the barrels and around the inner surface of the barrels. When the plungers were inserted into the barrels the movement of the plungers became very hard, and they could not be turned by hand.

On 26th June 2006 the M/V CRIMSON VENUS was under pilotage in Parana river out bound from the port of San Lorenzo when she ran aground approximately 312 nautical mile from the mouth of the river. Visibility was diminished by drizzle and because the Green buoy light at 316.2 miles was not working.

On July 25th 2006 at 21.30 hours LT, the PICO EL AGUILA's main engine stopped due to compression failure of cylinder No 1.
On July 28th 2006 at 08.15 hours LT the vessel's main engine stopped due to compression failure of cylinder No 3.
On July 27th 2006 at 12.20 hours LT the vessel was sailing in position Lat 32º34.0 N long 048º15.0 W. Following instructions from Atlas Marine Instruccions the Master ordered to  change the course to 075º and proceed to Punta Delgada (Azore Island).

On 25th June 2006 at 06.00 hours LT the Liberian tanker ARABIAN SUN was en route from Tuticorin, India to Sharzah, U.A.E. when she experienced engine failure. The tug Svitzer Muharraq escorted the vessel to Mumbai High oil field and subsequently the vesel was towed to Fujairah anchorage by tug Svitzer Wijsmuller Salvage for repairs. Flat State investigation was conducted by obtaining flag state report and follow up communciation for clarification, as appropriate.
On 25th June 2006 the vehicles carrier SHENANDOAH HIGHWAY ran aground and as a result shel berthed at Port Canal with 24 hrs 48 min delay.

Location: NAGANG SHUI DAO RIVER, CHANGXING DAO ISLAND
SummaryOfEvents:
This is inform that 24.06.06 16551 encountered with summer season thundestorm locally Named"Leizon" with squall wind 55-60 Knots of Beaufort Scale and 1657 lt all mooring ropes Were torn off simultaneously on fore 9 ropes, on aft 10 ropes and the vessel self saild from yard berth to down river.
1700 lt dropped starboard anchor and pay away 6 shackles on deck.
At 1705 lt the vessel touched neighbour down river concrete corner of pier named "JIAN-NAN" by port quarter of hull and received hole 145 x180mm with dent 400x500mm, frame No.16,4m Above waterline, vessel free of ballast, for/0.45maft/7.1m, main engine immobilized.
All tanks, engine room compartment under water line were checked sounding and found:
The fresh water boiler tank port side damaged and all water flowed out, the vessel not intake Any water from river. At1748lt the pilot embarked and vessel with assist of two tugs was Towed to anchorage with latitude 31º21.2N, longitude 121º43.2E for repair mooring ropes and Preparation yard berth. The yards platform with shore ladder remained on board, the tower Contruction of Shore ladder dropped in river near the yard berth.
At present moment awaiting clear the pier from mooring ropes and hoist the yard ladder tower.
On the vessel repair mooring ropes and preparation for reberthing.
The AP tank, engine room compartment, adjoining tanks were re-inspected and not any leakages appeared.

ON JUNE 21ST 2006, AT 12.56 P.M. A COLLISION OCCURRED BETWEEN M/V MOBY FANTASY AND M/V NURAGHES. WEATHER CONDITIONS WERE: ABSENCE OF WIND, CALM WATER, AND STRONG FOG (VISIBILITY < 100 MTS.).
THE M/V MOBY FANTASY HAD JUST LEFT FROM OLBIA PORT AND WAS PROCEEDING TO CIVITAVECCHIA PORT AT A SPEED OF 18,2 KNOTS, AND M/V NURAGHES WAS ON THE OPPOSITE ROUTE AT A SPEED OF 25 KNOTS. M/V MOBY FANTASY'S BOW HIT THE NURAGHES' STARBOARD SIDE. HEAVY DAMAGES RESULTED TO THE HULLS AND SUPERSTRUCTURES OF BOTH SHIPS. THE M/V NURAGHES WAS ABLE TO ENTER OLBIA PORT USING ITS OWN MEANS OF PROPULSION, WHILE M/V MOBY FANTASY HAD TO BE TOWED TO GOLFO ARANCI PORT BY A LOCAL TUGBOAT.

The master of an offshore supply vessel went to the bridge to relieve the first officer at 2000.  The weather was southerly 25 knots and there was a 1-2 metre swell running.  At 2050, when the vessel was making a turn the ship gave a shudder and there was a large bang heard.  Both engines were brought to stop but the port engine had already shut itself down.  The fire alarm followed at 2055.  The chief engineer reported to the bridge that the port engine had suffered a crankcase failure and that a connecting rod had failed and had passed through the crankcase.  The crew were put on standby but there was no danger of a fire.  The master informed the company technical super indent of the situation.  An assessment was made to continue operations on a single engine until the vessel was relieved the following morning.  The casualty then made its way to an east Scottish port for repairs.  

On investigation it was found that the lubricating oil nipple at the top of the connecting rod had become blocked.  This cause the piston to overheat seizing it in the cylinder.  The connecting rod then failed causing it to project through the crankcase.  The engine had been installed since build and it was decided to replace the unit.

Location: Obat Jetty, Kirikiri Lighter Terminal Apapa
SummaryOfEvents:
On 18th June 2006 the tanker M/V TUTUMA was berthed when it was found there was a leakage of PMS into pumproom from a second cargo pump that had been opened up for repairs while discharging cargo. This leakage had spread into the engine room/ machinery space via the cargo pump shaft hole, producing an eventual build up of gases and fumes. On discovering this leakage 6 all machinery in the engineroom was shut down and an agreement reached with the terminal operators to use shore air pumps to evacuate the leakages from the engine room. This operation was being carried when the air pumps also failed. The air pumps were then connected to the ship's air compressors, which were to be powered by shore power. 
On the 20th June 2006 at about 10.00 hours LT the shore power was swithed on which was followed by switching on one of the engine fans in an attempt to evacuate the fumes. This was immediately followed by an explosion and fire, which spread rapidly from the engine room to the accommodation spaces, resulting in the death of two crew members, serious injuries to a further two, and five crew members went missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SOLASStatus: DONG QU NO.1: Unknown/unspecified, NEW FERRY 85: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At about 10.12 LT on 19th June 2006, the Chinese-registered Passenger high-speed craft (HSC)Dong Qu No1, with 86 passengers on board, collided with HONGKONG registered passenger high-speed craft NEW FERRY 85 near east of No.1 buoy at the channel of Jiuzhou port. The location of the collision was in position at 22°10′.25N/113°38′.52E. Dong Qu No.1 was hit at starboard quarter and sunk soon after collision. Due to effective salvation, no passengers or crew members were injured in the collision accident. NEW FERRY 85 sustained minor damage above the waterline at starboard bow. There was no reported injury on board NEW FERRY 85.
Consequences1: Ship remains fit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

ShipsInvolved: DONG QU YI HAO (-), NEW FERRY 85 (IMO 9323209)
SOLASStatus: DONG QU YI HAO: Unknown/unspecified, NEW FERRY 85: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At about 10.12 hours LT on 19 June 2006, the Hong Kong registered high speed passenger craft New Ferry LXXXV collided with the Chinese registered high speed passenger craft Dong Qu Yi Hao in the position 22° 10.3’N 113° 38.6’E. The weather was cloudy with heavy showers and there was a southwesterly gentle breeze. New Ferry LXXXV sustained structural damage to its starboard bow while Dong Qu Yi Hao sank shortly after the collision. There was no casualty and no pollution resulting from the collision.

ON 19TH JUNE 2006 AT 08.18 HOURS LT THE BULK CARRIER 'BRILLIANT SKY' WAS BERTHING UNDER PILOT WHEN SHE MADE CONTACT WITH A DOLPHIN, WHICH INJURED THE DOLPHIN AND ALSO CAUSED DAMAGE TO SHIP´S SIDE SHELL PLATING ON WAY TO HOLD N° 3 P/

SOLASStatus: GOLDEN VOYAGE: Unknown/unspecified, HANJIN SYDNEY: Unknown/unspecified
Location: In the specified sea area for traffic safety of the Port of Kwangyang
SummaryOfEvents:
The Korean registered cargo ship Hanjin Sydney was on passage from the port of Pohang in Republic of Korea to the port of Kwangyang  in Republic of Korea at 06:12 hours on 16 June 2006.
At 09:15 hours on 18 June 2006, the Korean registered container ship Golden Voyage was on passage from the port of Ulsan in Republic of Korea to the port of Kwangyang in Republic of Korea.
At 06:43 hours on 18 June 2006, the two ship collided 0.6 miles north-west from Samyeo in the specified sea area for traffic safety of the Kwangyang Bay “34°48.19 N and 127°48.28 E”. The Hanjin Sydney suffered indentation in the starboard shell plating of the bow. The Golden Voyage suffered damage in the handrail and others of the portside stern.

At around 1700 on 17 June 2006 on a fine, calm day the crew of the fishing vessel PAMELA S were preparing to lay a line of whelk pots in Carmarthen Bay when the vessel suddenly, rapidly and without warning, capsized an sank.
Two people were on board at the time : one crewman on deck aft, and the skipper in the forward wheelhouse.  The crewman shouted a warning to the skipper as water began to flood onto the deck aft as the vessel started to capsize to port.
Seawater began to flood through the wheelhouse door, threatening to trap the skipper inside, but the crewman made his way forward to the wheelhouse and pulled him clear.  The vessel then capsized rapidly to port and, as the men clambered onto the upturned hull, she sank by the stern, sucking the men under the water as she went down.
The men surfaced together and initially congratulated themselves on having survived the sinking.  They could see a large navigation buoy, DZ1, denoting the MOD firing range off Pendine beach, approximately 0.5 mile away, which they started to swim towards.  However, the tidal flow carried them away from the buoy.
Although the sea was calm, the water temperature was 12.7°C and the men began to tire as they continued to swim.  After some time, the crewman became exhausted and slipped below the water, but the skipper managed to pull him back to the surface and resuscitate him.  Later, the crewman went under for a second time, and although the skipper was again able to bring him back to the surface, the skipper was unable to resuscitate him and, as darkness fell, he had to leave him.  As he did so, he secured a plastic fender, which had floated free from the vessel, to the crewman's clothing and then started to swim towards a light he could see on the shore.  Extraordinarily, almost 10 hours after the sinking, the skipper staggered ashore at Pendine beach in the early hours of 18 June.  He was discovered by a member of the public, who fortuitously was a trained first-aider and who kept the skipper warm until medical assistance arrived.
Despite an extensive search for the crewman, his body was not found until 27 June when it was recovered from the water off Pendine beach.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

THE VESSEL SAILED FROM YANTIAN, CHINA 16th JUNE AND LADEN WITH 1480unit / 15065.7 MT OF CIONTAINERS WHILE NAVIGATION IN THE VICINITY OF CHANGJIANG KOU TRAFFIC SEPARATION SCHEME ON ZERO VISIBILITY, STARTED TO SOUND THE FOG SIGNAL AND ON MANUAL OPERATION STEERING. AT 1232hrs ENGINE ON MANEUVERING FULL AHEAD, AT 1245 hrs REPORTED AND CONFIRMED PILOT BOARDING TIME WHICH IS 1400hrs BECAUSE OF ANOTHER VESSEL WILLIAMSBORG BRIDGE HAVING THE SAME ARRIVAL AT PILOT STATION, THEN PILOT ADVISED TO PROCEED FIRST TO THE PILOT STATION. AT 1313hrs ENGINE ON HALF AHEAD AND 1314 hrs ENGINE ON SLOW AHEAD.
AT 1317hrs WHILE VESSEL ENTERING PRECAUTIONARY AREA B WITH SPEED OF 8 kts ON COURSE 250deg, PILOT ADVISED THAT PILOT OPERATION IS SUSPENDED AND VESSEL HAVE TO PROCEED TO CHANGJIANG KOU ANCHORAGE No. 1 AT 1320hrs WHILE AT PRECAUTIONARY AREA B4 MILES OFF TO PILOT STATION SPEED 8kts, VESSEL PROCEEDING TO ANCHORAGE ON HARD STARBOARD TO STEER ON NE DIRECTION, THEN AT THAT TIME SMALL SHIP (BARGE TYPE) WEI LUN 32, HEADING 180deg ABOUT 3.7 MILES SPEED ABOUT 9 ktS COMING FROM THE NORTH.

BUT FOR UNKNOWN REASON SUDDENLY SMALL SHIP CHANGE HER COURSE TO PORSIDE AND KEEP APPROACHING ON A CLOSE QUATER SITUATION, FOG HORN SOUNDED SUCCESSIVELY IN ORDER TO ATTENTION, BUT SMALL SHIP STILL APPROACHING ON THE PORTSIDE UNTIL THE BOW OF SUCCESSIVELY IN ORDER TO ATTRACT HER ATTENTION, BUT SMALL SHIP STILL APPROACHING ON THE PORTSIDE UNTIL THE BOW OF THE SMAL SHIP HIT THE PORTSIDE HULL OF THE VESSEL NEAR THE MID SECTION IN POSITION LAT 31º06.ON AND LONG. 122º29.3E.

THE VESSEL IN LOADING CONDITION (COAL IN BULK) UNDER LOCAL PILOT ORDERS, ARRIVED AND ANCHORED IN “SAN NICOLAS”  No 3 SOUTH ANCHORAGE ( PARANA RIVER/ ARGENTINA) ON 16-06-06/17:32 HRS L.T.
IN POSITION LAT: 33° 22’,1 S AND LONG: 060° 07’,4 W,  WHERE  SHE  GROUNDED ON THE BOTTOM OF THE RIVER.
AFTER A NUMBER OF ATTEMPTS USING THE VESSEL’S ENGINE, RUDDER, ANCHORS AND TUGS SHE REFLOATED ON 22-06-06/08:34 L.T.
