On 16 June 2006, during Kota Pahlawan’s voyage from Singapore to Australia, a foul odour was noted coming from two containers on board the ship. The containers were packed with xanthates, dangerous goods which produce carbon disulphide vapours and can spontaneously combust.
Later that day, the master informed the ship’s charterer of the ‘incident’ and that the odour indicated that the packaging of the xanthates was not ‘gas-tight’, in accordance with international rules. He also asked for the containers to be discharged at Brisbane, the ship’s next port of call.
At 0411 on 18 June, the master reported the incident as a defect to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA). At 0720, the ship embarked a coastal pilot and started its transit of the Great Barrier Reef.
At 0907 on 19 June, AMSA issued a defect report and started collecting information about the incident. At 1252, the pilot disembarked from the ship after it had completed its transit of the northern part of the Great Barrier Reef Inner Route.
The ship berthed in Brisbane on 22 June after an ‘emergency’ was declared in the port. All eight xanthates containers on board the ship were discharged and purged with nitrogen gas to mitigate the risks posed by the foul smelling, highly flammable and toxic carbon disulphide vapours. On 24 June, the master was asked to reload the containers. He agreed on the condition that AMSA provide a written acceptance of the proposal with regard to ‘compliance’ with international rules.
By 04.00 hours LT on 25 June, the xanthates containers had been reloaded onto the ship before it sailed from Brisbane. On 6th July 2006 the ship discharged the last of the xanthates containers in Freemantle.

Location: Zhang Jiang Gang Port in China
SummaryOfEvents: On 15th June 2006 the MV CHEMBULK Hong Kong was en route from Jiangyin HONG KONG to ZHANGJIAGANG China, when at 14.21 hours LT it collided with bulk carrier MV TAIGLAD, which was anchoring at Tongsha anchorage place. The collision damaged No. 6 ballast tank of MV CHEMBULK, Hong Kong on the port side. No pollution occurred as a result of the accident.

Vessel arrived at river berth to discharge cargo. The usual mooring arrangements for this berth are for the ships to take shore ropes as head, stern and breast ropes. However, this time used all ships ropes aft. These broke, and the stern of the vessel swung into the river. Held only by her head rope and forward breast rope, she continued to swing until she landed against the ship on the next berth.

ON 13TH JUNE 2006, THE CRUDE OIL TANKER LEANDER APPROACHED OPL ANCHORAGE AREA TO THE EAST OF PASIR GUDANG FOR THE PURPOSE OF SLOPPING. AT 05.56 HOURS LT THE VESSEL MADE CONTACT WITH THE ANCHORED M/T BORGA, CAUSING MINOR INDENTATION TO SHELL PLATING IWO 3STB WB, WB TANK ABOVE THE WATERLINE AND TO OUR KNOWLEDGE DAMAGE TO THE FCSL BULWARKS ON THE BORGA.

FOLLOWING THE INCIDENT OUR VESSEL ANCHORED AND INFORMATION WAS EXCHANGED IN ADDITION TO CARRYING OUT NECESSARY NOTIFICATIONS.

CLASS HAS SINCE ATTENDED THE VESSEL AND A CC HAS BEEN ISSUED ( SEE ATTTACHED).

An elderly male passenger (dob 2/9/1923) was playing table tennis when he slipped and lost his balance. He fell to the deck causing a fracture to the left neck of the femur at his hip. He was wearing trainers and the deck was dry.

On 10th June 2006 the fishing vessel WILHELMINA was being used in a salvage operation in the North sea. However, due to the additional heavy weights she became unstable and capsized. One crew member was killed as a result.

SOLASStatus: BELLE NAUTICA: SOLAS, JUSHO MARU: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Off east coast of Kunisaki Peninsula, Oita Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: In waters off east coast of Kunisaki Peninsula, Oita Prefecture, Japan, the Jusho Maru (Japanese registered vessel of 4.9 gross tons) with 1 crew (Japanese) was sailing on a course of 267º, at a speed of 7.4 knots over the ground, and the Belle Nautica (Panamanian registered vessel of 17,979 gross tons) with 20 crew (Chinese) was sailing on a course of 191º, at a speed of 13.3 knots over the ground.  At 0426 hours (UTC+9H) on June 10, 2006, they collided at a position 128º, 4.3 miles from Kunisaki Ko Furuichi C Breakwater Lighthouse.  As a result of the collision, although the Belle Nautica suffered only slight scrape damage in the stem, the Jusho Maru was severely damaged and had to be taken out of use, with the skipper of the Jusho Maru declared dead—after having been taken to a hospital—because of drowning.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: M/N SANSOVINO, COMING FROM ISOLE EOLIE WITH 223 PASSENGERS AND 42 VEHICULES, ATTEMPTING TO MOORING AT PIER N. 18 OF NAPLES HARBOUR, DURING THE MOORING OPERATIONS,BECAUSE OF A BLACK OUT OF THE MAIN ENGINE, HIT THE ABOVE MENTIONED PIER.

Location: 100 nm S.W. of Cape of Good Hope, South Atlantic Ocean
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
The SETSUYO STAR, a Cape sized, dry bulk carrier, was on passage from Brazil to China in June 2006, fully laden with a cargo of iron ore.  While on passage, following a period of adverse weather, the crew detected that there was a gradual increase in the hold bilge soundings within No.1 cargo hold; water ingress was also detected into the duct keel of the vessel.  Further investigation revealed substantial structural damage to the single side shell structure of cargo hold No.1 initially detected on the Port side, but subsequently repairs were required on both the Port and Starboard sides.  Seawater was entering the hold through a crack in the side shell plating, approximately 400mm in length and a number of side frames were detached.
The vessel, which was approximately 100 nautical miles to the south west of the Cape of Good Hope when the damage was confirmed, immediately put engines to stand-by and diverted towards Cape Town to seek shelter and a port of refuge.  The vessel was granted access to sheltered waters by the South African Maritime Safety Authority (SAMSA), surveyed and temporary repairs were made to the vessel at False Bay.  The temporary repairs were approved by Class BV and enabled the vessel to complete the intended voyage to China, where the cargo was discharged and permanent repairs were then carried out in dry-dock.

Location: Tomie Wan in Fukue Shima, the Goto Islands
SummaryOfEvents:
While sailing northward in waters south of the entrance to Tomie Wan of Fukue Shima, Nagasaki Prefecture, in order to seek shelter there from heavy weather, the Grand Lucky, a Cambodian flag cargo vessel of 1,144 gross tons, went aground on a shallow reef—at a position 066º, 1.6 miles from Kasayama Hana lighthouse—extending from Bahan Se, at 1530 hours on June 8, 2006. 
As a result of the grounding, the vessel sustained holes in the bottom of her hull.  She was subsequently washed ashore and had to be pulled off the coast by a salvage boat.  She was, however, declared a constructive total loss.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Serious injuries

SummaryOfEvents:
On the evening of 7 June 2006, the general cargo ship SKAGERN and the container ship SAMSKIP COURIER collided in the Humber estuary in dense fog.  Fortunately there were no injuries on either vessel.  
SAMSKIP COURIER sustained minor damage to her bow but was able to continue on her voyage to Rotterdam.
SKAGERN was extensively damaged forward and required major repairs.
Both vessels had experienced pilots on board at the time of the accident and SKAGERN in particular was a regular visitor to Hull.

On 7th June 2006 the HOHEBANK, a UK flagged general cargo vessel, had offloaded its cargo of wood pulp at a small Cumbrian port.  Loaded with ballast she had embarked a pilot for the outbound stage of the voyage.  The channel was narrow and mainly dried at low tide with the exception of a large 4 metre deep lake that remained at low tide.

Having left port the engineer felt that the engine was sounding "rough" and he informed the master of his concerns.  He then contacted the DPA to advise them of the situation.  The technical superintendent advised the captain to anchor and examine the main shaft thrust block.  

The engineer found that the oil in the trust block had become very heavily emulsified.  Because of the poor lubrication qualities the white metal faces of the thrust pads had wiped.  This caused the main shaft to move, and as the engine is directly connected to the propeller shaft the main engine main bearings wiped, scoring the crankshaft.

Further investigation revealed that the saltwater cooling coil in the bottom of the thrust block housing had suffered a leak.  This caused the oil to become emulsified destroying its lubricating properties.

It is noted that the coil was replaced by a Swedish yard as part of the refit package in October 2005.

The vessel was towed to Workington for engine inspection by the manufacturers, and the classification society.  The salvage association also conducted an investigation into the failure.  Following the engine assessment it is intended to tow the vessel to Birkenhead for full repairs.  

Both the master and chief engineer confirmed that there was no engine, thrust block or other alarms to raise their concern.  However, the engineers should have checked the level of the thrust block oil charge every 2 hours and there is no evidence to suggest they did.  Had they done so they may have noticed the increased level and emulsification and could possibly averted the damage.
REPORT DETAILING THE LOSS OF CONTROL

Location: East side of Dundonald Chanel, Bermuda
SummaryOfEvents:
On June 2006 at about 08 :19 hours local time the Norwegian crown, a Bahamas registered passenger ship with 1104 passengers and 537 crew on board grounded on the east side of the Dundonald Channel while shifting from St. George  to Hamilton. The ship was under the direction of a pilot, the weather was blustery with rain squalls and the visibility at the time of the grounding was reduced to approximately 300 metres in rain.  

Norwegian Crown lay aground over approximately half of its length for about 10 hours before being refloated with the assistance of three tugs from the Department of Marine and Ports Services, Bermuda. There were no injuries to passengers or crew; no pollution and the Norwegian Crown suffered relatively minor indentations in the bulbous bow area of the forepeak tank. Damage to the reef in the vicinity of the grounding was said to be significant and is the subject of two reports; one by the Department of Conservation Services and one by the Bermuda Institute of Ocean Science.

On 6 June 2006 at 00:45 hours, a deckhand on board the United Kingdom registered scallop dredger Danielle became trapped by a rope that was being used on a winch whipping drum.  He sustained serious arm and chest injuries and was evacuated by RNLI lifeboat and ambulance to hospital; where subsequently his arm had to be amputated.

A special purpose vessel was coming in to port with the Pilot on board and heading towards the designated berth.  At 7 minutes past midnight the fire detection system went off indicating a fire in the aft engine room in the vicinity of No 5 engine.  The vessel sought and got permission to berth at the nearest available berth.  The pilot called the shore fire brigade and they were on board at 25 minutes past midnight.  A conscious decision was taken by the Master and Fire Chief not to release CO2.  The fire was extinguished with water spray 50 minutes past midnight.  An extraction fan was started to clear the smoke which caused re-ignition of the fire probably caused by the fresh air intake and electrical sparking in the lighting circuits.  The electric circuits were isolated locally by the ship's staff and the fire was re-extinguished by 01:21.  The damage was quite extensive but was limited to the aft engine room and particularly to engine 5.  The most likely cause of fire was a ruptured low pressure fuel pipe which sprayed marine gas oil on to hot and exposed surfaces on the exhaust piping.
Cargo1: Multipurpose offshore support vessel - no cargo

SOLASStatus: FELUCCA: Unknown/unspecified, JONATHAN SWIFT: Unknown/unspecified, STENA ADVENTURER: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 3 June 2006, at 16:44 hours the fishing ship “Felucca” departed from Dublin Port bound for Killybegs. The vessel had been in Dublin for general maintenance at the dry dock. Whilst departing, the vessel suffered an engine power failure and grounded on the south side of the channel about 250 metres to the west of No. buoy in Dublin Port. After one unsuccessful attempt, the vessel’s engine was refloated. Two passengers ferries - the Stena Adverturer and the Jonathan Swift - were inbound in the channel and approaching the fishing ship, which proceeded back under its own power to its original berth. There was no pollution or hull damage suffered in the incident.

COLLISION POSITION: LAT 34-02.60 N , LONG 077-56.40 W
0445:CHECKED DAMAGE CONDITION AND NO ANY OIL POLLUTION OVERBOARD.
DAMAGE PART: POSITION ABOUT 12 METERS FROM KEEL AND STARBOARD COFFERDAM TANK AND STARBOARD N|. 1 BUNKER TANK AND DAMAGED PARTAS WERE FOUND WITH BIG CLEVIS CUTTED (LENGTH 2,5 METERS x BREATH 20 CENTIMETERS) AND BIG DENT PARTA AT N|. 1 FO TANK ON STARBOARD SIDE.
0725:ANCHOR AT OUTER HARBOUR ANCHORAGE FOR INSPECTION OF CONCERNED PARTIES.

At 09.50 hours LT on 2nd June 2006 the general cargo ship CICLOPE was at the port of Vancouver on the Columbia river when a load of lumber caught fire in the hold of the ship. More than 40 firefighters managed to extinguish the fire, and nobody was hurt in the blaze. Firefighters and crew members closed the hatch and gassed the hold with carbon dioxide to displace oxygen and starve the fire, which may have been started by a spark from a welding torch wielded by a longshoreman repairing a ladder in the hold. Firefighters and port officials did not believe the vessel itself was seriously damaged, and she was fit to proceed.

Location: MIRTOO PELAGOS - AEGEAN SEA - 16 n.m. SE OF HYDRA ISLAND (GREECE)
SummaryOfEvents:
On 1st June 2006 the combined chemical and oil tanker "Alios Artemis", under GREEK flag , Agioi Theodoroi for Iraklion, and general cargo ship "Han" (PANAMA flag, 2453 gt, built 1978), Turkey for Casablanca, collided at 13.58 hours LT 16 nautical miles south-east of Hydra island, Mirtoo Pelagos(AEGEAN SEA). 
M/V "Han" sank following the collision. 
Seven of the vessel’s crew were rescued, one was found dead and five are still missing.  
An accident investigation is under way.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Off north-east coast of Eilean Trodday, Scotland
SummaryOfEvents:
The Banff registered stern trawler BROTHERS BF138 sailed from Gairloch with a 2-man crew at about 0225 on the morning of 1 June 2006.  At about 0520 the vessel grounded and then sank off Eilean Trodday, a small uninhabited island off the north coast of Skye.  No "Mayday" message was broadcast.
The skipper's father called the emergency services, reporting the vessel overdue that evening after the families were unable to contact either the skipper or the crewman by telephone.
Over the next 36 hours an extensive air and sea search which involved numerous resources, including helicopters, a nimrod aircraft, lifeboats, fishing boats and auxiliary coastguard search teams, was carried out.  Just before midday on 3 June a local fishing boat reported that the missing boat had been found on the seabed just off Eilean Trodday.  A short while later they reported that a quick search of the wreck by a local diver had failed to find any sign of the trawler's crew.
The search for the missing crew was continued during that day and the following day.  It was called off 4 days after the boat had sailed from Gairloch.
The body of the crew member was found on the north-west coast of the Scottish mainland on 18 June, 17 days after the vessel had sunk.  However the skipper was still missing at the time of writing this report (January 2007).
It is believed the vessel probably grounded due to one of the crew falling asleep in the wheelhouse, which allowed the vessel to sail past her intended fishing grounds and onto the shore at Eilean Trodday.  Both crew would have been suffering the effects of fatigue brought on by a number of long days at work, with only short, broken sleep periods.  Both crew had also drunk some alcohol before the vessel left the harbour.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: BUSAN EXPRESS: SOLAS, JANG HO GRACE: SOLAS
Location: 12 km North from Okino Shima island, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
M/V BUSAN EXPRESS LEFT PORT PUSAN IN THE REPUBLIC OF KOREA FOR  PORT TOKUYAMA IN JAPAN AT 1925 HRS(LMT) ON MAY 31 2006. AT 0150 HRS ON JUNE 1, SHE WAS PROCEEDING ON A COURSE OF 123 DEGREES AT A SPEED OF 10.5 KNOTS UNDER THE COMMAND OF THE SECOND MATE. AT THAT TIME THE OFFICER OBSERVED ANOTHER VESSEL, M/V JANG HO GRACE (GRT 1,257, REPUBLIC OF KOREA REGISTERED GENERAL CARGO SHIP) ON HER STARBOARD BOW 5 DEGREES 5 MILES OFF. THERE WAS ALSO A VESSEL NAVIGATING BY HER SIDE ON HER STARBOARD STERN IN RESTRICTED VISIBILITY. 

WHEN THE DISTANCE WAS CLOSE TO 0.8 MILES, M/V BUSAN EXPRESS ALTERED ON A COURSE PORT 130 DEGREES AND THEN 110 DEGREES TO AVOID THE RISK OF COLLISION WITH THE OTHER SHIP. AT 0200 HRS, THE BOW OF M/V BUSAN EXPRESS COLLIDED WITH M/V JANG HO GRACE IN THE POSITION OF 34°21.30'N, 130°07.00'E ABOUT 12KM NORTH FROM OKINO SHIMA ISLAND, FUKUOKA PREFECTURE, JAPAN. 

AS A RESULT OF THE COLLISION, THE BOW OF BUSAN EXPRESS WAS DENTED AND JANG HO GRACE SANK ON THE SPOT. JAPAN COAST GUARD RESCUED ALL THE CREW OF JANG HO GRACE.

On 31st May 2006 on board the vehicle carrier ATLIXCO exhaust Gases were noticed to have entered into the Main Engine Cooling System, causing low cooling water pressure NO 3 Unit.
Action taken: Speed was reduced and Engine Stopped
After Engine stopped cooling water entered into NO 3 Cylinder Unit.
Engine was turned by turning gear, and water removed.
The following temporary repair was made so vessel could proceed to Anchor:
Replaced 2 O rings on liner insert on cylinder cover and replaced fuel injector.
At Anchor NO 3 Cylinder cover was replaced with spare.

SOLASStatus: ARCTIC STAR: SOLAS, CHANG TAI: SOLAS
Location: Lian Yun Gang Port in China
SummaryOfEvents: At 04.00 hours LT May 31st 2006, MV.ARCTIC STAR left No.2 berth of LIANYUNGANG Port in China. At 04.20 hours LT, whilst turning,  the ship's bow hit MV.CHANGTAI which was mooring at the same berth aft wards. This resulted in damage to the starboard side of the No. 2 cargo hold  in MV.CHANGTAI, leaving a big hole into which water flooded, damaging the cargo.

On 29th May 2006 the fishing vessel POOLSTER was in the North sea at the start of the fishing week, when she collided with the m/v JAKORIWI. The collision was a result of inadequate look-out caused by lack of attention. The lights in the wheelhouse also impaired visibility outside.  The JAKORIWI was rendered unfit to proceed.

Location: At 2.5 miles from AR Men's Lighthouse
SummaryOfEvents:
Le vendredi 26 Mai 2006, le ligneur Liberté quitte le port d'Audierne en fin de nuit, afin d’aller pêcher le bar  sur la chaussée de sein, se trouvent à bord le patron et un passager. Le ligneur  Korrigan appareille en même temps avec également un passager. Les deux navires communiques par VHF  et se croisent sur les lieux de pêche ; le temps est calme mais la Zone est recouverte  de brume. A son retour au port, peu après midi, le Korrigan constate que le  Liberté n’est pas  rentré et fait  de ses inquiétudes.  

Les recherches entreprises immédiatement permettent de retrouver le corps du passager.

L’épave du Liberté sera localisée le lendemain, le corps du patron n’a pas été retrouvé.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 25th May 2006 at 15.00 hours LT the general cargo vessel PORTLAND sank in waters off the Canary Islands. The most probable cause of the sinking was the cargo of cement shifting as the ship rolled - the sum of the angle of roll of the vessel and the angle of repose of some of the untrimmed surface of the cargo must have exceeded 30o, allowing part of the cement to shear off and slide to the starboard side, amplifying and accelerating the rolling motion. With this gravity shifted to starboard, the vessel could not roll back upright.
The Chief Officer and the Second Engineer both lost their lives.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 25th May 2006 the carrier ETERNAL GRACE grounded at the above-mentioned location. The vessel suffered paint scratches on bottom flat shell plating from frame number 245 to frame number 258, but no indentation or deformation was found.
The classification society surveyor accordingly considered that the vessel still maintain the class without conditions.

Location: About 170 miles South West of the Scilly Islands
SummaryOfEvents:
The Irish flagged 25 metres stern trawler “Dinish” left the Spanish Port of Vigo on 23 May 2006 for its first fishing campaign under its new owners. The ship was heading for fishing grounds off the south west coast of Ireland, where it had been operated by its previous owners. 
At about 20:00 hours (UTC 22:00 ships time) on 24 May 2006, a call was made from the “Dinish” to La Coruna Radio saying that the ship was taking in water. The crew reported flooding in the engine room and attempts were made by the crew to control the level of flooding, however these efforts were unsuccessful.
Two liferafts were launched from the ship and six of the crew got in to one raft.
At approximately 20:30 hours (22:30 ships time) the ship capsized and sank about 170 miles south west of the Scilly Isles.
Rescue services were tasked along with other merchant ship close to the last known position of the “Dinish”.  Six survivors were taken on board the merchant ship “Stena Contest” from one of the rafts and the Skipper of the “Dinish” was taken from the water by the merchant ship “Stolt Capability”. One other crewmember was taken from the water by a rescue helicopter and pronounced dead on arrival at Cork University Hospital. A search operation was mounted; however the remaining two crewmembers are not accounted for.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On May 24, 2006 at 10:15 LT, M/T ADELE (IMO No.: 8113736) leading on course 000º, bound Thessaloniki Port (GREECE), grounded on “Megalo Emvolo” shallow waters.
All actions required to check any damage were taken, no hull damage occurred no pollution took place. Safety tug called and remained for assistance in the area until refloating.   The vessel refloated by cargo transfer on May 25, 2006, 18:00 LT and proceeded safety to the port.

At 09.55 hours LT on 22nd May 2006, the Chinese general cargo ship DONGFANG 28 owned by Ningbo Beilun shipping Co., Ltd, collided with the Malta container vessel PHILIPPINE STAR, in CHENGSHANTOU waters (37º35′.8 N / 122º40′.0 E), causing multiple damage to the hull and equipment of MV DONGFANG 28 .
At 02.58 hours LT on 24th May 2006 the container ship HUB BINTULU and MV XING CHANG 3 collided during restricted visibility at CHANG JIANG KOU water area.
AFTER CROSSING OSTER BRIDGE,  BEING OVERTAKEN ON STARBOARD SIDE WITH CLEARANCE CABLE SWUNG HARD OVER TO PORT SIDE CAUSING CONTACT WITH MSC EYRA .

On 22nd May 2006 at 23.30 hours LT the general cargo ship was in a collision which resulted in the vessel's Starboard bow shell plating being indented between frame 124-127 (below the castle deck). The hole damage in frame measured 126 100 mmlx 5mm/w.

ON 22ND MAY 2006 THE M/V ORANGE SEAWAY WAS IN A COLLISION AND SUSTAINED DAMAGES TO HER STARBOARD BOW SHELL PLATING INDENTED BETWEEN FRAME 124-127 (BELOW THE FORE CASTLE DECK). THE HOLE DAMAGE IN FRAME MEASURED 126 100 MMLX 5MM/W

InitialEvent: Accidental release of lifeboat and Loss of life
SummaryOfEvents: On the morning of 22 May 2006, while at anchor in the Bay of Sept Îles, an abandon-ship drill was carried out on board the bulk carrier Sea Urchin. At 11:50 eastern daylight time, during the recovery of the starboard lifeboat, the hook-release gear mechanism opened. The forward mechanism unable to take the full load also, opened. The lifeboat then fell 11 meters, stern first, into the sea, fatally injuring one of the five crew  members on board.

A FIRE WAS REPORTED ON BOARD THE BULK CARRIER 'PELANDER' ON 22ND MAY 2006 AT 11.25 HOURS LT.  THE FIRE, ON DECK 7, HOLD NO.2, WAS SUCCESSFULLY EXTINGUISHED BY THE VESSEL'S MAIN FIRE FIGHTING SYSTEM CO2. 5 UNITS OF CARGO WERE  DAMAGED, BUT THE VESSEL'S WATERTIGHT INTEGRITY AND SEAWORTHINESS WERE NOT AFFECTED AND THE VESSEL SAILED TO, AND SAFELY ANCHORED AT RAFFLES ANCHORAGE, SINGAPORE AT 2200 HRS LT ON MAY 23, 2006.

Whilst departing Ajman using the designated channel the vessel grounded and sustained serious damage to No 2 double bottom fuel tank, number 1 fresh water tank, and a compartment adjacent to the thruster tunnel. There were no injuries to personnel and no pollution was evident. The channel was buoyed, and the master was using the buoys as visual reference and his primary method of fixing and monitoring. Way points had been entered into the GPS.

Location: Southampton Water, 3.3 cables south-west of Hamble Point  Buoy
SummaryOfEvents: At approximately 14:29 hours on May 20th 2006, the IMX 38 yacht, Roaring Meg of Cowes, owned by Sail (UK) Ltd, was crossing Southampton Water towards the River Hamble. The wind force was 6-7 gusting 8 from the west-south-west. The yacht made two accidental gybes. The first resulted in one of the yacht’s crew sustaining multiple fractures to one of his legs, and the second caused another crew member to suffer a severe head injury.

SOLASStatus: THEOFANO M: Unknown/unspecified, WOO LIM: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: MV THEOFANO M collided MV WOO LIM which was at anchor when she proceeded inbound

The M/V GAZ HORIZON was berthed at Perama Port, Piraeus on 19th May 2006, where she was undergoing repairs. At 09.20 hours LT a fire broke out at the fore part of the vessel, specifically at the rope storage space. The fire was extinguished by crew members and  no injuries werw reported. Minor material damages were sustained.

InitialEvent: MOBILE CRANE FELL OVER THE SIDE
SummaryOfEvents:
THE INCIDENT OCCURRED ON BOARD THE 'MARINIA' AT 13.28 HOURS LOCAL TIME ON THE 18th MAY 2006, WHEN THE MANITOWOC CRANE, WHICH WAS UNDERGOING A QUADRENNIAL LOAD TEST, FELL OVER THE PORT SIDE OF THE VESSEL. ONE CREW MEMBER WAS INJURED WHEN HE WAS STRUCK BY A CANVAS FIRE HOSE. THE HOSE WAS BEING USED TO FILL THE LOAD BAG WITH WATER.

THE SEAMAN SUSTAINED A FRACTURED LEFT LEG AND WAS MEDIVACED ASHORE AND HOSPITALISED. THE TESTS WERE BEING CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE BARGEMASTER, WITH THE GERMANISCHER LLOYD CLASSIFICATION SOCIETY SENIOR SURVEYOR IN ATTENDANCE.

THE INITIAL AND INTERMEDIATE TEST HAD BEEN CONCLUDED SUCCESSFULLY AND TEST WAS BEING PREPARED.  BEFORE THE FINAL TEST COULD BE CONCLUDED THE CRANE TOPPLED OVER. THE OPERARTOR MANAGED TO JUMP FROM THE CAB IMMEDIATELY BEFORE THE CRANE WENT OVER THE SIDE RAIL AND INTO THE SEA.

On May 18th 2006 the vehicles carrier SALZGITTER was berthed at Miami port to replace a corroded safety railing at no. 10 deck on break of forecastle. At 07.30 hours LT the Chief Officer ordered that the railing be fabricated in E/R workshop, and instructed that a fire extinguisher and a bucket of water be ready if needed.      At 08.10 hours LT the stevedores came on board and commenced loading. At 09.00 hours LT the repair team went ahead with the planned work, but due to a misunderstanding began before the scheduled time. This was not noted at the time, as everyone was busy with cargo work. At 10.52 hours LT the fire watch noticed that the mooring rope was on fire on forecastle, but was unable to put it out. At 10.55 hours LT the Master was informed of the fire and a general alarm was sounded at 11.00 hours. The crew were mustered and commenced fire fighting, and the stevedores disembarked the vessel.
At 11.05 hours the Miami fire brigade and the agent were informed of the incident, and at 11.15 hours the fire was extinguished by the ship's crew. All adjacent cargo spaces and areas were checked to confirm the fire was out. At 11.18 hours the fire brigade boarded the ship, but they disembarked at 11.18 hours after ensuring the fire had been completely extinguished. At 11.55 hours the coast guard personnel boarded the vessel to carry out an investigation, and the repair team were interviewed. At this point the stevedores resumed their cargo work.
At 13.15 hours the investigation was concluded and USCG disembarked after issuing three deficiencies which needed to be rectified prior to the vessel's arrival in San Juan. These were:
 A. Rubber gasket of FPK store and BT room emergency escape to be renewed.
 B. 2 Nos. mooring ropes to be renewed.
 C. Forecastle ligt cable and junction box to be renewed.

By 15.10 hours LT the work had been completed and at 16.06 hours LT the ship sailed from Miami. Ship and US CG did not involve class as there was no structural damage or breach of vessel's seaworthiness.

On 16th March 2006, while loading scrap into No.4 Hold at Long beach No.118 berth, smoke was observed on board the M/V GLOBULUS.
A crew member used a water spray to extinguish the fire, and the Master informed the local agent of the incident. However, the fire dept. decided to fill up water to a level of 11m-00.

On 17th March at 02.15 hours LT the smoke in the c/hold No.4 was stopped and no more water was poured into the hold.
At 02.40 hours LT, all firefighters, USCG and other concerned parties onboard disembarked but the USCG  advised master to keep watching c/hold 4 for any sign of fire. The height of the water then in the c/hold N0. 4 was 6m from the c/hold bilge tank. The USCG returned next day for further investigation.

The Ro-Ro ferry was leaving Stromness in the Orkney islands with 31 passengers and 40 crew onboard.  The only electrical power source was provided by a single shaft generator.  As the ship entered the channel the shaft generator supply breaker failed while port helm was applied.  Pitch was taken off the twin controllable pitch propellers but the vessel's stem touched the bottom.

About 30 seconds later the emergency generator was connected to the switchboard and electrical power was re-established.  The master took the ship out into the channel and then returned to port.  Once secured alongside a divers inspection was conducted, the only damage recorded was superficial paint detachment.  Internal inspections revealed no damage.
The cause of the breaker failure has not been determinate and the failure could not be replicated.  The management company are reviewing their guidance on the electrical generation configuration on entering confined navigational areas.

On 06 May 2006, the ship Pompei left Singapore, bound for Nakhodka (Russia). This voyage crosses the South China Sea and the North Western Pacific region which is known for the formation of the most, the largest and most intense tropical cyclones of the world between the months April and December.
On 13 May, the ship began to struggle with the typhoon Chanchu, which was approaching from the ESE on that day.

After two days of heavily pitching and rolling, the port side engine and bow thrusters broke down.
22 hours later, in phenomenal seas and swell, southerly winds up to 180 km/h, the starboard engine also failed, and the ship was no longer under command.
Rescue coordination Centre Hong Kong was contacted, which send an air craft.
On that time the ship had a black out and starting the emergency generator was not possible anymore.
On 18 May, a rescue aircraft, the tanker “Munnin” and two tugs were underway.
At 16:00 hours, a towing line was secured and the voyage proceeded towards Hong Kong dry dock where she arrived on 20 of May.
All was scheduled to sustain the crew on arrival.

As a male passenger was moving along and out of a bench set, he placed his left hand on the sofa next to him. The cushion moved and he dislocated his left shoulder, of which he had a history. A recommendation was made to fit an additional two brackets underneath the cushion support to prevent sideways motion of the seat.

A 70 year old male who was fitted with an artificial leg, was walking along the buffet deck having just left the open deck area of a passenger liner.

His right foot slipped on the deck which he believed may have been wet.  He fell to the floor striking his left wrist which suffered a fracture.  The passenger, who was suffering from osteoarthritis, had fractured his wrist on a previous occasion.

It is possible that the ship's movement and the passenger's limited mobility may have combined to cause him to slip and loose his footing. 

The passenger stated that he had difficulty walking due to his artificial leg and additional knee problems.  The crew were unable to find the apparent wet patch on the deck that the passenger said he may have slipped on.

An elderly female passenger was leaving the bathroom and missed the step down into her cabin. She fell forward landing heavily with her shoulder striking the bulkhead and her head hitting the floor. She then landed heavily on her hip causing a fracture of her pelvis.
THE VESSEL WAS STOPPED AND ANCHORED TO CARRY OUT ROUTINE CHANGE OF CYLINDER LINER.  IT WAS NOT  AN INCIDENT AND DID NOT POSE ANY THREAT TO SAFETY OF NAVIGATION OR MACHINERY.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
AT 13:00 HRS LOCAL TIME ON 11TH MAY 2006,WHILST AT THE PORT OF BARCELONA, A FIRE WAS DETECTED ON THE BRIDGE OF MSC NURIA.
FIRST INDICATION THAT THERE WAS A FIRE ON THE BRIDGE WAS FOLLOWING A SMELL OF SMOKE FROM THE MASTERS CABIN, WHEREUPON THE MASTER IMMEDIATELY RAISED THE ALARM, CREW MUSTEREDED AND EMERGENCY FIRE FIGHTING TEAM WERE ACTIVATED.
DENSE WHITE SMOKE WAS OBSERVED FILLING THE BRIDGE.  THE FIRE FIGHTING TEAM SUBSEQUENTLY BROKE INTO THE BRIDGE BY BREAKING A BRIDGE WINDOW DUE DOORS LOCKED FOR SECURITY REASONS AND, THEREAFTER, EXTINGUISHED THE FIRE AT 13-:25 HRS WHERE SMOKE WAS DISPERSED.  NO INJURIES TO CREW ON BOARD.  THE LOCAL FIRE BRIGADE ARRIVED AT 13:40 HRS,  THE FIRE HAVING ALREADY BEEN EXTINGUISHED. 
EXACT CAUSE OF FIRE TO ASCERTAIN, HOWEVER, THERE HAS BEEN SMOKE DAMAGE AND LIMITED WATER DAMAGE TO THE BRIDGE.  INITIAL INFORMATION RECEIVED SO FAR WOULD INDICATE A REPAIR PERIOD IN THE REGION OF 2-3 WEEKS, HOWEVER, THIS IS SUBJECT OF FUTHER INVESTIGATION AS TO THE EXTENT OF DAMAGE TO THE ELECTRIC AND NAVIGATIONAL EQUIPMENT.

On 11th May 2006 the 80m dry cargo vessel DOUWENT was on passage via a canal in good weather and good visibility.   The vessel made fast in the lock, starboard side to, with bow and stern moorings out.  A pusher unit tug, with two barges lashed in line, with an approximate length overall of 180-190 metres, was entering the lock to berth on the port side, when the starboard bow of the first unit came into heavy contact with the cargo vessel's port quarter and transom, causing buckling and splitting to the shell plating. The cargo vessel subsequently sailed from the lock to a lay by berth just outside the lock to allow a survey of the damage to be completed.  No damage was reported to the barge or tug.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
On 10th May 2005 the Gibraltar Port Control found some oil stains on the water when the bulk carrier CALIFORNIA  was departing from the port, and stopped the vessel at 20.00 hours LT. The vessel re-anchored in the port at 23.10 hours LT on May 10. During an onboard investigation, the  cause of the leak was found to be a small crack between the No. 12 starboard side fuel tank and the topside water ballast tank No. 6/7. Fuel had leaked into the ballast tank, and subsequently flowed into the inlet/oulet pipe, and because this pipe´s valve was open, fuel leaked into the sea causing the oil slick. The valve from the ballast tank inlet/outlet pipe was shut immediately, and a stopper was put on the pipe.
The Captain appeared in the local court on May 12th, and was fined 500 pounds. The crack was temporarily repaired by steel with a rubber seal. The repairs were inspected and passed by class surveyor and Port Control surveyor. The vessel sailed from Gibraltar on May 24th 2005.

Alors qu’il était en action de pêche à la drague à la coquille Saint jacques, le chalutier GWEL.VO immatriculé au Havre, a sombré le 09 mai 2006 au Nord Est du cap d'Antifer, au large de la commune de Saint Jouin de Bruneval (76), avec trois marins à bord. Deux sont morts, un est porté disparu.
Le navire a disparu des écrans radar de la station du port autonome du Havre vers 04h06 heure locale.
La balise de détresse est récupérée en mer le 09 mai à 06h14 à la position 
49° 44'633 N et 000° 01'594 E.
L’épave sera localisée le 10 mai dans la soirée par le chasseur de mines CASSIOPEE. Elle repose par 36 mètres de fond orientée sud-sud ouest au 205, les dragues se trouvant à 170 mètres dans l’Est de l’épave.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
At 0330 ship's time (0230 UTC) on 6 May 2006, the Cypriot registered cruise ship THE CALYPSO suffered an engine room fire while on passage from Tilbury to St. Peter Port, Guernsey, with 708 passengers and crew on board.  
Initial action by the watchkeeping engineer officer was effective in eventually extinguishing the fire although the vessel lost all but emergency electrical power and was left drifting in the south-west lane of the Dover Straits Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS), 16 miles south of Beachy Head.  The vessel's starboard main engine had been very seriously damaged and she was towed to the port of Southampton by a Maritime and Coastguard Agency's emergency towing vessel.
The subsequent investigation discovered that the fire had been caused by a failed low pressure fuel pipe flange on the starboard Wartsila Vasa32 main engine.  The lack of an effective guard allowed fuel to spray onto the adjacent turbocharger and/or exhaust piping causing spontaneous ignition.  
During the investigation into the cause of the fire, after the vessel's arrival in Southampton, CO2 from a bank of cylinders was accidentally released into the engine room.  In the event, three crew were lucky to escape without loss of life or serious injury.

ON 6TH MAY 2006 THE M/V "DUBAI TRANS" WAS AT SEA IN THE GULF OF OMAN EN ROUTE TO THE PORT OF DUBAI. AT AROUND 02.00 HOURS LT SHE WAS HIT BY A CYCLONE  AND EXPERIENCED MAIN ENGINE FAILURE.  THE CAPTAIN GAVE ORDERS FOR THE CREW OF 21 TO ABANDON THE VESSEL AND LOAD THE LIFE BOATS BUT THE WERE UNABLE TO DO SO BECAUSE OF THE ROLL OF THE VESSEL. INSTEAD THEY USED THE TWO LIFE RAFTS ON THE PORT SIDE BUT DUE TO THE HIGH SEAS THE CREW WERE THROWN INTO THE WATER.  ELEVEN CREW MEMBERS WERE RESCUED, BUT THE OTHER TEN WERE NOT FOUND.

InitialEvent: MAIN ENGINE FAILURE / LOSS OF STERN ANCHOR
SummaryOfEvents:
MAIN ENGINE FAILURE TO MANOEUVER DUE TO IMPURITY OF FUEL OIL. CONSEQUENT LOSS OF STERN ANCHOR IN ORDER TO STOP VESSEL. 
TUG BOAT ASSISTANCE FOR SAFETY REASONS.

DURING A USCG INSPECTION ON 5TH MAY 2006 THE M/V PACIFIC POLARIS WAS FOUND TO HAVE  A HIGH CONTENT OF OXYGEN IN CARGO TANKS (ABAOUT 12-15%).
VESSEL WAS ORDERED TO RE BERTH TO RE-INERT CARGO TANKS.
AT 08.00 HOURS LT EOSP AND NOR TENDERED/ AT 09.00 HOURS LT POB / AT 11.12 HOURS LT ALL MADE HER FAST / AT 11.35 HOURS LT USCG. CUSTOM. IMMIGRATION ON BOARD. 
AT 11.40 HOURS LT STARTED INSPECTION / 12.25 HOURS LT FOUND HIGH CONTENTS OXYGEN IN CARGO TANKS / 12.34 HOURS LT STOPPED INSPECTION AND U.S. COAST GUARD AWAY / AT 12.55 HOURS LT PILOT ON BOARD / 13.12 HOURS LT LAST LINE OFF / 13.40-16. 25 HOURS LT RE- INERTING AT OUTER HARBOUR / 19.00 HOURS LT RECEIVED MSG OF ADMITTED ENTERING PORT THRU AGENT / 2218LT ALL LINE MADE FAST
ON 6th MAY 2006 AT 08.10 HOURS LT USCG ON BOARD AND RESUMED INSPECTION 
AT 10.10 HOURS LT CLEARED USCG INSPECTION AND ACCEPTED
NO PERSONS WERE INJURED.

InitialEvent: CASUALTY NOT LISTED ABOVE. A PERSON FALL DOWN TO THE BOTTOM OF THE CARGO HOLD DURING HATCH COVERS OPENING OPERATION
SummaryOfEvents:
IN ORDER TO CARRY OUT ATTACHING THE HOISTING CHAINS DURING HATCH COVERS OPENING/ CLOSING OPERATION.
- OR LIST TRE(3) CREW MEMBERS SHOULD BE INVOLVED:
EXQUARATOR DRIVER AND TWO(2) CREW MEMBERS, ATTACHING THE HOISTING CHAIN FROM BOTH STRIP SIDE, DOING SO, TALKING ON TOP OF HATCH COVER CAN BE AVOIDED.
ClassificationSociety1: Polski Rejestr Statkow (Polish Register of Shipping) (PRS)

SummaryOfEvents:
A GENERAL ALARM WAS RAISED ON 4TH MAY 2006 ON BOARD VESSEL NYK SPRINGTIDE WHEN DECK CADE JAI SHAH DID NOT REPORT FOR DUTY AT 08.30 HOURS LT. AS THE CADET COULD NOT BE TRACED, THE VESSEL WAS TURNED AROUND AT 10.28 HOURS LT TO SEARCH FOR HIM. DSC/MF/HF AND SAT C CALLS WERE TRANSMITTED AT 10.23 HOURS LT AND 11.17 HOURS LT RESPECTIVELY.

THE LAST TIME THE CADET JAI SHAH WAS SEEN WAS ON 3RD MAY 2006 AT 20.30 HOURS LT WHEN HE REPORTED AFTER MAKING THE FIRE ROUNDS. THEREAFTER HE MADE A SATELLITE CALL FROM THE BRIDGE.

Location: 300 nm S.-E. of Port Elizabeth, South Africa
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
Nine hold bulk carrier, ALEXANDROS T was on a voyage from Punta Madeira, Brazil to China, with a cargo of iron ore.
On 3rd May 2006, 07:50 LT (UTC +3, ship's time), flooding of her No. 8 port double bottom tank was noted.  It occurred about 300 nautical miles south east of Port Elizabeth, South Africa.
The crew of ALEXANDROS T tried pumping the water out from No. 8 port double bottom tank without success.  Subsequent flooding was also noticed in holds Nos 5, 6 & 7.  At 20:50 LT the vessel suffered catastrophic structural failure resulting in the breaking of the No. 6 hold.  The vessel sank a short while later.
When the ship cracked, all personnel on the boat deck were swept off the ship by waves.
A drifting lifeboat, which was probably self-freed from releasing gear, was boarded by five crew members shortly after resurfacing.  One other survivor was recovered by the lifeboat.  They were rescued by the crew of a ship in the vicinity.  The next day, a seventh survivor was rescued from a floating liferaft which he had inflated and boarded shortly after resurfacing.  Extensive air and sea search continued for other survivors but unfortunately without result.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The chief engineer was engaged in a routine transfer of gasoil from bunker tank to settling tank. Due to malfunction of the sight glass the tank ran over and oil splashed out on the main engine around the exhaust manifold. Fire broke out. The chief engineer succeded in closing the pump and ran out. Quick closing of fuel tanks, main engine line etc. was executed and all flaps were closed. CO2 was released and the fire was estinguished 10 minutes after it broke out. This was however realized first when the engine room was opened about 2 hours later.

On May 3rd 2006 at around 11.07 hours LT the M/V KATSURAGI  collided with M/V “GUO FENG ” in the above-mentioned location.  As a result the M/V “GUO FENG ” sank, and the sea water in the vicinity was polluted by the remainder of the banker oil in the tanks of M/V “GUO FENG ”. Five crew members died, and one went missing.

Location: RIO PARANA KM 290, FROM SAN LORENZO TO PARANAGUA
SummaryOfEvents:
On 3rd May 2006 the bulk carrier HISTRIA SUN, with two pilots on board, ran aground at 01.05 hours LT  (04:05 utc) in position 33,37,696s/59.42,847w. (arg. charth-1013).
At 14:00 hours LT - appointed protective agents
At 15:00 hours LT - Coast Guard Port State Control/hull+mach inspectors and divers boarded vessel for investigation of the incident and to perform inspection / sub-agent boarding clerk Mr. Atilio Ricardo on board.
At 17:00 hours LT: P&I surveyor Capt. Guillermo Botari on board.
At 18:30 hours LT: T/B "BUNI" arrived to km 290
On 4th May 2006 at 02.20 the vessel was refloated, and at 02.30 hours LT she resumed navigation to San Pedro roads escorted by T/B Buni (ordered by Coast Guard for safety reasons).
At 03:45 hours LT: arrived/passed San Pedro main roads (km 277)
At 05:20 hours LT: anchored at San Pedro roads at km 274 / salvage master Capt. Villela disembarked

THE M/V 'MARIAM EXPRESS' ARRIVED AL HAMRIYA PORT, DUBAI ON 23  OF APRIL 2006 TO LOAD CARGO TO ABU FLUS, IRAQ.  THE VESSEL COMMENCED LOADING ON THE SAME DAY AND SAILED TO IRAQ ON 2 MAY 2006 AT 20.30 HOURS LT.   TOTAL CARGO ON BOARD WAS AROUND 1132 MT.  OF GENERAL CARGO AND VEHICLES.  A SPACE AT THE CENTRE OF THE MAIN HOLD WAS MADE FOR INSPECTION OF CARGO BY THE UNITED NATIONS AT CHECK POINTS AT IRAQ WHICH IS MANDATORY FOR THE VESSELS TRADING IN IRAQ ROUTE.  AFTER THE VESSEL SAILED FROM HARYA PORT, DUBAI AROUND 22.00 HOURS LT THE VESSEL BEGAN LISTING TO PORT SIDE 2 TO 3 DEGREES, AND KEPT INCREASING.  AN IMMEDIATE ORDER WAS PASSED TO THE CHIEF ENGINEER TO UPRIGHT THE VESSEL, BUT DUE TO THE CARGO MOVING TO PORT SIDE ALONG WITH THE LIST, THE VESSEL COULD NOT RETAIN ITS POSITION; INSTEAD THE LIST KEPT ON INCREASING AND BY 22.30 HOURS THE LIST INCREASED TO ALMOST 40 DEGREES.  A ADISTRESS SIGNAL WAS SENT  AND THE VESSEL'S OWNER INFORMED AND ASKED FOR ASSISTANCE.  AT AROUND 24.00 HOURS LT THE VESSEL WAS IN DANGER OF CAPSIZING AND THE CREW WERE ORDERED TO ABANDON SHIP, SO THE LIFE RAFT WAS THROWN DOWN AND THE CREW WENT DOWN.  
THE VESSEL SANK AT 00.35 HOURS ON 3RD MAY 2006, AT POSITION 25 DEGREES 28.87 N 55 DEGREES 07.54 E, BEFORE THE TUG 'NAMROUD', WHICH WAS ORDERED BY THE OWNER, COULD REACH US.  THE COAST GUARD BOAT RESCUED THE CREW AT AROUND 02.00 HOURS AND THEY ARRIVED ASHORE AT COAST GUARD JETTY AT PORT RASHID AROUND 03.00 HOURS.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 2nd May 2006 the m/v HYBUR STAR was sailing in the Miami river when she temporarily lost control and made contact with the quay at 133 West at 13.45 hours LT.

At 1400 on 1 May 2006, Crimson Mars sailed from Bell Bay, northern Tasmania with a local pilot on board. The sky was cloudy and the visibility was clear with a light south-easterly wind. During the ship’s turn to port around Garden Island, at about 1440, starboard instead of port helm was applied for approximately one minute. The error was not noticed initially and by the time maximum port helm was applied at 1441, grounding was inevitable. Soon after, the pilot ordered both anchors to be let go and the main engine to be run at emergency full astern in an attempt to reduce the effects of the impact. At 1442, the ship grounded on Long Tom Reef as the port anchor was let go and the main engine run astern. 

The ship, with its main engine running astern, moved off the reef and refloated at 1446. An attempt to retrieve the anchor resulted in the failure of the port windlass. The ship remained anchored until 1605 when two tugs arrived to assist. The anchor cable was cut and left in the river with the port anchor. The ship then returned to the Bell Bay anchorage with the assistance of the tugs. 

An inspection of the ship revealed that it was severely damaged and that temporary repairs could not be carried out in Bell Bay. The ship’s departure was delayed until contingency arrangements could be put in place. Crimson Mars sailed from Bell Bay on 12 May for Hualien, Taiwan, China to discharge its cargo and carry out permanent repairs.

At about 17 :00 hrs, in position 06°045.5’ North and 096° 38.2’ East, a flash fire was reported on M.T. Suva  on 30 April 2006 while the ship was on  a ballast passage from Singapore to Fujairah. Four people were killed and 2 people sustained minor to serious injuries as a result of this fire.

Onboard a Danish trawler they were hiving up the trawl. The hand of a fisherman was catched by the trawl and the hand/arm was pulled around a bar in the bulwark. The bar control the trawl, while the trawl is pulled on the netdrum.
Consequences1: Ship remains fit to proceed,Serious injuries

SummaryOfEvents:
On 29th April 2006 at 12.00 hours LT, the m.engine of the bulk carrier AGELESS stopped during northbound passage in Suez Canal. At 13.00 hours LT both anchors were dropped at 140KM.
At 13.06 hours LT the vessel turned around and changed direction to south.
The vessel AGELESS returned to Suez and the main engine was repaired to the satisfaction of vessel's class.

Location: Off northeast of Taketomi Shima, Okinawa Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
Freighter Jian Hua (registered Hong Kong, China, 11,280 gt, built 1976), with 27 crews (Chinese), ran aground on the shallows off northeast of Taketomi Shima, Okinawa Prefecture, Japan due to inappropriate selection of water area to wait for customs clearance.
Japan Coast Guard dispatched patrol boats to the scene.
Jian Hua sustained denting and cracking damage to its bulbous bow and water ingress to the forepeak tank. After that, she was refloated by tug boat and was repaired.
None of its 27 crewmembers was injured and fuel oil has not leaked from the vessel.

Location: At sea, en route from Falkland Isles to South Korea
SummaryOfEvents: On 29th April 2006 the Liberian reefer vessel MAUNAKEA was en route to Busan, South Korea, with a cargo of  frozen squid. At around 06.40 hours LT an explosion of the vessel's turbocharger caused a fire in the engine room, which spread to the accommodation spaces. The fixed CO2 extinguishing system was released in the engine room, but the crew was unable to effectively fight the fire in the accommodation because the emergency fire pump was inaccessible. The crew evacuated to the main deck of the vessel and were later rescued by the salvage tug responding to the incident, with one minor injury sustained. The vessel was a total loss.

NEERMOOR, a single hold coaster, had discharged her cargo at Southampton, UK and was on ballast passage to Teignmouth, UK to load.  The ship was fitted with two portable bulkheads that could be moved within the hold in order to divide the space up into three sections.
After sailing from Southampton, the ship's two Able Bodied Seamen (ABs) were tasked to thoroughly clean the cargo hold before arrival in Teignmouth.  To achieve this, there was no requirement to move the bulkheads from their existing longitudinal positions, but both had to be vertically raised to ensure that all remaining traces of the previous cargo were completely removed; this was normal practice for this trade.  While cleaning beneath the bulkheads, they were supported by timber packing.
The ballast passage was made in good weather conditions, and when the ship arrived off Teignmouth the cleaning was almost completed.  The two ABs assisted with anchoring the vessel and then returned to the hold to finish the task.
Working at the forward face of the aft most bulkhead, the ABs used two separate, portable, hand powered jacks to lift vertically the aft bulkhead off its temporary supports; one jack was operated by each AB.
One AB stopped operating his jack and stepped through the opening in the bulkhead to the aft side.  Almost immediately, the bulkhead began to topple, rotating about its lower locating pins so that its top edge moved aft.  The bulkhead continued to fall aft, generally rotating about the lower pins until they, too, became disengaged and the bulkhead fell to the deck.
The AB working on the forward side escaped uninjured.  Tragically, the second AB was fatally crushed between the fallen bulkhead and the bottom of the hold.

SOLASStatus: DONGTAI FORTUNE: Unknown/unspecified, EASLINE TIANJIN: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 27th April 2006, the Hong Kong container vessel “DongTai Forture” which was en route from DaLian, China to Kaoxsiung in Taiwan, China, collided with Singapore container vessel “EASLINE TIANJIN” at position 37°26. 9N, 123°08′.1E at 11.36 hours LT. The collision caused severe damage to port quarter of “DongTai Forture”.  Fortunately, no pollution occurred and no people were injured in the accident.

Location: VARNE BANK (IN THE MIDDLE OF THE DOVER STRAITS)
SummaryOfEvents:
13:12HRS..VESSEL DEPARTED FROM BERTH AT DUNKERQUE-WEST.   THE BALLAST ON BOARD AT THETIME OF DEPARTURE WAS 31620 MT.    
16:30HRS..START OF SEA PASSAGE FROM DUNKERQUE TO TROMBETAS, BRAZIL
16:45HRS..LT. MASTER HANDED OVER THE WATCH TO THE CHIEF OFFICER ON COURSE 225 AFTER CROSSING THE NORTH EAST LANE.   THE VESSEL JOINED THE SOUTH WEST TRAFFIC AND MASTER WENT TO THE RADIO ROOM TO SEND THE DEPARTURE MESSAGES TO VARIOUS PARTIES.
17:15HRS...CHIEF MATE WAS RELIEVED BY THE 3RD OFFICE FOR DINNER.
17:44HRS...THIRD MATE INFORMED THE MASTER THAT THE VESSEL RPM AND SPEED REDUCING WHICH WAS CONFIRMED BY THE MASTER WITH THE GPS.
17:45.16HRS..ENGINE WERE STOPPED AND THE POSITION TAKEN. LAT 50°7¿57.99N, LONG 001°19.6 E.  SPEED BEFORE GROUNDING-15.4KNTS, RPM-102.2
17:45HRS..VESSEL RAN AGOUND ON THE VARNES BANK-IN THE DOVER STRAITS IN THE ENGLISH CHANNEL-DOVER STRAITS COAST GUARD INFORMED.
17:55HRS..DE BALLASTING ON THE NO.4 HOLD COMMENCED.
20:16....DOVER COAST GUARD INFORM THAT A TUG WAS PROCEEDING TO HELP BUT WAS DETERMINED BY THE MASTER THAT AS NEITHER THE CREW NO THE VESSEL WERE IN ANY DANGER AND THAT THERE WAS NO APPARENT DANGER OF POLLUTION THAT THE NEED OF A TUG ASSISTANCE WAS NOT GOING TO BE CONSIDERED.

ShipsInvolved: HACI IBRAHIM (IMO 7721902), IRAN MADANI (IMO 8309622), SANDY CAPE (IMO 7626853)
SOLASStatus: HACI IBRAHIM: Unknown/unspecified, IRAN MADANI: Unknown/unspecified, SANDY CAPE: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
A collision took place between m.v. IRAN MADANI (towed by m.t. SANDY CAPE) and m.v. HACI IBRAHIM, on 25 April 2006, north of Bozburnu Peninsula.  
The convoy was waiting for permission to enter the Strait of Istanbul during the voyage from Setubal, Portugal to Mangalia, Romania when m.v. HACI IBRAHIM collided with m.v. IRAN MADANI and sunk after the collision.  Five crew members from m.v. HACI IBRAHIM sunk with the vessel.  Four crew members of m.v. HACI IBRAHIM were rescued by the Turkish rescue service who was alerted by the Master of IRAN MADANI immediately after the collision.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents:
On 25th April 2006 at 05.30 hours LT the M/Vs TINTO and MARINA-S collided in dense fog. 
The bridge was manned with one officer (OOW) on each of the vessels. The vessels were heading on approx. opposite courses.
From one of the vessels the other ship was observed by radar at a distance of about 5 NM. 
The other vessel did not observe the oncoming vessel by radar.
The MARINA-S altered course to starboard before the collision and was hit on the port side approx. amidships, and sank within a few minutes.
The crew of four, who had abandoned the vessel, were picked up by the M/V TINTO.

On 24th April 2006 the container ship HYUNDAI PIONEER was in open sea, when at 12.06 hours LT  the Exhaust Gas Economizer (EGE)'s  lower hopper was observed to be red hot. The EGE exhaust outlet temperature was noted to be 667 deg centigrade. The EGE casing was also observed to be very hot, with smoke emanating from its casing. It was concluded that there was a serious fire inside the EGE. The vessel was immediately stopped, and the EGE cooled with copious quantities of water spray. At 15.26 hours LT  it was noticed that the vessel had listed about 1.0 deg to port, & water levels in E/R bilges were near floor plate level. The rise in water level was rapid & alarming due to copious amount of water being used for fighting fire in the EGE. Due to Vessel's List & Trim condition,  & as the water was reaching the floor plate in aft area, it was necessary to lower the water level by using the Fire & G.S. pump which has direct suction from the aft bilges. Any further rise in water levels would have led to sloshing of water with rolling/ pitching & probable damage to machineries in the vicinity which would have incapacitated the vessel. All possible openings for air inlet were checked, viz. scavenge drain, stuffing box drain, indicator cocks, soot collection drain, drains for EGE section, M/E exhaust pipe and Turbochargers and all were confirmed shut.  Cooling down of the EGE with five fire hoses was continued till 26th April 06.24 hours LT  to avoid any recurrence of fire. The temperatures were then observed to be 80deg centigrade on the outer side of EGE, & inlet was 26/32 degrees centigrade. By 26th April at 07.08 hours LT the manhole for the EGE was opened and inspected internally & it was confirmed that there was no smoke or hotspot or fire inside the EGE.
- Accumulated water in E/R tanktop continued to be pumped out until 26th April at 12.00 hours LT. Water was lowered to just above tank top & rest of it retained on board. For nearly 42 hours four to five fire hoses were engaged in order to contain & overcome the fire.

Location: 980 miles off from the Sendai lighthouse, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
The No.2 Oyang was 3,527.33gt, 88.94m in length, and powered by one 3,309kw diesel engine. She was a steel trawler. There were a total of 51 crew members on board when the ship left the port of Gamcheon in Busan on 17 April 2006. She was heading for fishing grounds located in the midst of the northern Pacific Ocean, about 105° T/C, at a speed of 10 knots. A
fire started in the 2nd fish storage area at around 11:30 (UTC+11) on 24 April 2006, while navigating at around 37°23’00’’N-162°13’00’’E, at 093° and 980 miles away from the lighthouse of Sendai, Japan. The crew members tried to fight the fire for 4 days by suffocation methods, but were not successful. Consequently, all crew members left the ship at around 14:30 on 28 April 2006, and were transferred onto the 503 Oryong. The No.2 Oyang continued to burn until it sank around 02:40 on 29 April, at around 35°45’00’’N-171°32’30’’E.

The M/V “STAMOS”, on April 24th 2006, was sailing in international waters at South Adriatic in the traffic separation area between the islands of Pianosa/Italy and Palagruza/Croatia when at about 00.20hrs came to collision with the Italian , Motor Fishing Boat “SANDOKAN”. As a consequence of the collision damage sustained to fishing boat stem. There were no injuries or pollution to the environment.

SOLASStatus: DE ZHONG: Unknown/unspecified, GAS CATHAR: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: At about 04.30 hours LT on 23rd April 2006, the tanker GAS CATHAR, with a course of 020°and speed of 11 knots, collided with the m/v DE ZHONG whose course was 237°with a speed of 10 knots, at position 21°43.1′N/113°11.1′E.3,  near Gaolan, Island of Zhuhai, China. The collision resulted in injuries to three crew members on board the m/v DE ZHONG, and serious damage to the port bow of DE ZHONG, causing widespread damage above the water line and creating a hole with an area of 3.4cm x 3.5cm in the hull below the waterline. This caused mass flooding which led to a  3-4°port inclination and serious damage to the back part of port bow thruster. There was no obvious damage to GAS CATHAR. The incident was later investigated by  the Guangdong Maritime Safety Administration, China.

On 21 April 2006 a small coastal products tanker was on passage from the UK to the Netherlands when the main engine began to overheat.  It was suspected that the engine cooling circulating fresh water pump had suffered a vapour lock.  

The vessel went to anchor to conduct investigations and it was found that one of the cylinder head gaskets had failed.  This caused the fresh water cooling system to overheat and become over pressurised.  A replacement cylinder head was fitted, as it was suspected that there may have been some distortion. The engine proven and the vessel sailed at 1300 on 22 April 2006.

Crew member was carrying a light but bulky item down a flight of stairs. He was not using the handrail, and could not see where he was placing his feet. He tripped and fell, breaking his left fibula and damaging his ankle.
ClassificationSociety1: Maritime Technical Systems and Services Ltd. (MTSS)

SummaryOfEvents: On 20th April 2006 the vessel was anchored and awaiting a berth for discharge. No specific instructions or information were supplied to the ship when loading the cargo of copper concentrates. The electrician and a seaman entered no. 4 cargo hold to check the lighting,  without authorisation, and contrary to safety procedures relating to entry to closed space in force on the vessel. The seaman was overcome and collapsed. The electrician went to his assistance and also collapsed. The Bosun then entered the hold to assist, and also collapsed. The three unconscious crew members were then rescued by crew wearing breathing apparatus. One later died, and the other two recovered.

On 20th April 2006 the vehicles carrier CAMELLIA ACE was approaching Gatun Locks south west centre wall when her starboard shoulder made contact with the centre wall, causing an indentation of 6.5 meters between frame nos. 156 and 162. With a height of 40cm. and a maximum depth of 15cm. no rupture of shell plating was observed.

On April 20th 2006 the Hong Kong cargo ship MARITIME FRIENDSHIP was en route from Fang Cheng port of Guangxi Province of China to Clad Stone port of Australia. At 12.36 hours LT she collided with fishing boat Gui He Yu 80266 of Guangxi Province of China at the position 20º14′N/110º35′E in the Qiong Zhou Straits. Poor visibility and the neglect of both ship's to keep a look out were the causes of the collision. As a result, one fisherman died and three fishermen were injured.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: NICOS I. V.: SOLAS, TENAX: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
The ballasted chemical/products tanker Nicos I.V. had been made fast port side alongside to Number 2 berth at Fawley Oil Terminal. Soon afterwards, the pilot asked the master to let go the forward tug Tenax, which had its tow line fast to a bollard on the starboard side, just aft of the forward mooring station. The pilot also told the tug master by VHF radio to let go. 

The pilot’s instruction was relayed by the ship’s internal VHF radio to the Bosun, who, with three able seamen and a deck cadet, went quickly to the tow line. They looked over the side of the ship and saw that there was some slack in the line, but no crew was on the tug’s deck. Therefore, a signal from the tug was not given that it was ready to receive the tow line. An able seaman, the bosun and another able seaman stood in line between the panama lead and the bollard and began to pull the slack of the tow line in by hand. 

Meanwhile on the tug, the chief engineer moved the towing winch control joystick to pay out the line and to give the ship’s crew some more slack. However, when he looked up at the CCTV monitor, he saw that the line was being heaved in onto the winch. He looked down at the towing winch control panel and saw that the tensioning mode switch was still illuminated. He switched the tensioning mode switch off, which gave him control of the joystick and he was able to pay the tow line out. 

When the tow line tightened, the able seaman who was standing nearest the panama lead, had his hands drawn towards the lead. He managed to extract his right hand, but his left hand was badly crushed when it became caught between the tow line and the panama lead. His hand was released when the tug’s chief engineer slackened off the tow line.

The 17.1 meter fishing vessel Nausicaa left Skerries Harbour in the early hours of Tuesday 18 April 2006 for the fishing grounds east of Clogherhead.
There were seven crewmembers on board.

After the net was shop for prawns the crew went for breakfast. 

When the time came to retrieve the nets, the crew were mustered and one crewmember was found to be missing.

Location: Near El Port de la Selva (Spain)
InitialEvent: Capsizing, sinking and Loss of Life
SummaryOfEvents: Le 17 Avril 2006 vers 23 heures, le catamaran de plaisance  de 13 m « Accroch'cœur » de retour de la régate « Routa de la Sal », en provenance d’Ibiza et se dirigeant vers son port d’attache de Canet-en-Roussillon, chavire à proximité de la côte. Deux des trois personnes présentes à l’extérieur sont précipitées à la mer, leurs corps sans vie seront retrouvés ultérieurement. Les quatre membres d’équipage restant se réfugient sur la plate-forme entre les deux coques et ne parviennent pas à signaler leur détresse ni à gonfler le radeau  de sauvetage; enfin de nuit « l’Accroch'cœur » fait côte après que l’équipier le plus âgé et la seule femme de l’équipage très affaiblis aient perdu connaissance (leurs corps sans vie seront retrouvés à proximité de l’épave).  Le chef de bord et le dernier équipier réussissent à gager la terre et à donner l’alerte au début  de la matinée du 18 avril 2006.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The Bulk carrier MAJESTIC was anchored at Moville Anchorage, Londonderry at 04.00 hours LT on Monday, 14 April 2006. The vessel was unable to proceed due to engine problems.  The anchor was heaved at around 11.00 hours LT on April 20.  Repairs were completed and pilot arranged to board the vessel at 13.00 hours LT in order to proceed to the berth.
A male passenger slipped and fell while mid-way descending an outer stairwell on board a ferry. The passenger held onto the handrail and dislocated his shoulder.
At 04.22 hours LT on 16th April 2006 the MV BRILLIANCE collided with MV YU ZHOU KOU HUO CHANG HONG JI 699” in the port of Shang Hai in China.

On 15th April 2006 the m/v TALISMAN was in inland waters but was travelling at high speed and took a short cut, contrary to COLREG. This resulted in the vessel colliding with the m/v STELLA MARIS. Material damage was sustained, but there were no injuries.

On 15th April 2006 the M/V GRANCEM was at the port of Bari when a crew member started the fuel oil purifier in the engine room. The machinery exploded at 03.35 hours LT, resulting in the loss of life of the crew member.
SMALL SMOKE WAS DETECTED AND THE CREW WHERE ALERTED BY FIRE ALARM.

SOLASStatus: EASTERN CHALLENGER: SOLAS, TSUGARU MARU: Unknown/unspecified
Location: In Uraga Suido, off southeast coast of Miura Peninsula, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
In restricted visibility conditions caused by fog, off southeast coast of Miura Peninsula, Kanagawa Prefecture, the Tsugaru Maru (a Japanese registered vessel of 498 gross tons), with 5 crew (Japanese) and the Eastern Challenger (a Filipino registered vessel of 6,182 gross tons), with 25 crew (Filipino) neared each other, culminating in a collision between the two vessels at a position 151º, 5.4 miles from Tsurugi Saki Lighthouse at 0518 hours (UTC+9H) on April 13, 2006, with the bow of the Tsugaru Maru smashing into the port forward part of the Eastern Challenger at an angle of 75º, leading aft on the latter.
As a result of the collision, the Tsugaru Maru sustained a crushed bow and the Eastern Challenger suffered a hole in the shell plating in the port forward section and sank, as water entered through the hole.

VOLGO-BALT 211 grounded because the chief officer fell asleep. He therefore did not alter course at the planned turning point at the entrance to the Sound. 

The look-out had left the bridge before the grounding.

Fatigue was a contributing factor. The chief officer had only 3 hours rest after a full day at work before his watch began. 

The chief officer had a little alcohol approx. 5 hours before the grounding. This might have been a contributing factor.

On 10 April 2006 at approximately 22.25 hours LT an able bodied seaman (AB) on board the bulk carrier PROBO BEAR was fatally injured when he was struck by a mooring line while operating a winch on the forecastle of the ship during a shift ship operation.
An investigation was carried out by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) utilising investigation information provided by the Maritime Administrator of the Republic of the Marshall Islands (International Registries).

ShipsInvolved: KATSU MARU No.8  (-), KATSU MARU NO8 (-), SANTA MONICA (IMO 9017020)
SOLASStatus: KATSU MARU No.8 : Unknown/unspecified, KATSU MARU NO8: Unknown/unspecified, SANTA MONICA: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
On 10th April 2006 at 04.45 hours LT the container ship SANTA MONICA collided with the 10m fishing vessel Katsu Maru No8, causing the fishing vessel to capsize with the loss of one of her four crewmen.

The skipper of the fishing vessel left the wheelhouse unattended to go to the engine room and correct a developing list caused by fuel distribution.  On returning to the wheelhouse he saw the container vessel bearing down on him, but too late to take evasive action.  Prior to leaving the wheelhouse the fishing vessel's radar was on 1.5 mile range scale which would not have shown the container ship approaching at 20 knots.  Visibility was good but the fishing vessel skipper failed to make regular visual checks out of the vessel's windows.

Santa Monica detected the fishing vessel from several miles distance and calculated from ARPA radar that they would pass clear by 0.1 nautical miles, but took no action to increase this distance until it was too late.  During final evasive action of hard to starboard, the container ship's stern side-swiped the small fishing vessel.

One man died and the remaining three crew spent several days in hospital recovering from ingestion of sea water and fuel oil.
sideswiped the small fishing vessel.

One man died and the remaining three crew spent several days in hospital recovering from ingestion of sea water and fuel oil.

ShipsInvolved: DUK YOUNG 101 (IMO 8117433), M. H. THAMRIN PB 1600 (IMO 9151993)
SOLASStatus: DUK YOUNG 101: Unknown/unspecified, M. H. THAMRIN PB 1600: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: AT 04.10 HOURS LT ON 10TH APRIL 2006 THE CONTAINER SHIP “MH THAMRIN PB 1600” COLLIDED WITH THE BARGE “DUK YOUNG” WHICH WAS BEING PULLED BY TUGBOAT  “101 DUK YOUNG” at 31°03´.97N, 122°43´.0E .  THE STERN OF THE “DUK YOUNG” WAS BROKEN ON HER STARBOARD SIDE.

AT 03.18 HOURS LT ON 10TH APRIL 2006 THE SECOND MATE ON BOARD THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP "SIMOON II" DISCOVERED A FIRE. THE CREW MANAGED TO PUT IT OUT, WITHOUT SHORE ASSISTANCE. THERE WAS NO DAMAGE, AND NOBODY WAS INJURED.

ShipsInvolved: STAR MARINER (IMO 9301316), WAN WANG JIANG TUO 428 (-)
SOLASStatus: STAR MARINER: Unknown/unspecified, WAN WANG JIANG TUO 428: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 00.39 hours LT on 10th April 2006, the bow of M/V STAR MARINER collided with the port side of “ANQING Barge 1304” in position 31°24´. 3N, 121°31´ 6E. The M/V STAR MARINER then turned to starboard, resulting in her port side coming into contact with “ANQING Barge 1304”. This led to the sinking of the towing vessel “WANWANGJIANGTUO 428” that was towing “ANQING Barge 1304” on her starboard side, resulting in the loss of four crew members, another three being seriously injured.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: Conception Bay South Newfoundland and Labrador
SummaryOfEvents: On 08 April 2006, the shuttle tanker Kometik, in ballast condition, was tat anchor in Conception Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador. A welder and a crew member were performing welding repairs in cargo tank No. 5 starboard when, at approximately 11:13 hours Newfoundland daylight time, an explosive vapour mixture was ignited in the cargo tank. The welder escaped from the tank with serious injuries and the body of the crew member was recovered by shore-based firefighters later that afternoon.

On 8th of April 2006 at 06.00 LT the pilot on board bulk carrier IVS HUNTER (Mr. W. Clasen) heaved up both anchors and moved vessel from 9 mile anchorage to the area nearby New Orleans city, under Greater New Orleans bridge, for filming. At the first round the vessel sailed up and down the Mississippi River under the command of master and pilot in normal conditions. At 0.946 hours LT the vessel turned back to make a second round, assisted by two tugs with tug lines, and at 09.49 hours LT the forward tug line suddenly parted and  the strong current and NW wind made the vessel drift towards the stern. At 09.50 hours LT, the starboard quarter of the vessel was above water level and made contact with the jetty. As a result, the vessel was damaged and a hole was made in the starboard quarter. Damage to the jetty was unknown.
The Master and crew members took all measures and made every effort to avoid the impact.

On 8th April 2006 the CRESCENT CONNEMARA was on a passage from Loch Inver to Pembroke and was transiting the Sky bridge through the Kyle of Lochalsh when at 04.58 hours LT she grounded momentarily as she scraped the bottom. The vessel then anchored and searched for any signs of damage or pollution. As nothing was found, she went on to berth at Kyle of Lochalsh for diver and class inspection. Damages found required drydocking repairs. No pollution or injuries to persons reported.On 8th April 2006 the CRESCENT CONNEMARA was on a passage from Loch Inver to Pembroke and was transiting the Sky bridge through the Kyle of Lochalsh when at 04.58 hours LT she grounded momentarily as she scraped the bottom. The vessel then anchored and searched for any signs of damage or pollution. As nothing was found, she went on to berth at Kyle of Lochalsh for diver and class inspection. Damages found required drydocking repairs. No pollution or injuries to persons reported.

A counterweight from the port main engine was ejected from No 4 inner crankcase door.  Oil was also discharged causing a small fire that was quickly extinguished.  Maintenance was conducted on the engine a short time previously and this had been completed incorrectly.

Extra training has been put in place to prevent a re-occurrance.

Location: CJK- Anchorage - Nao Cao Shui Dao
SummaryOfEvents:
On 6 April 2006 the bulk carrier OCEAN SPIRIT set sail from the Nantong shipyard, Shanghai, China, and dropped her last outward sea pilot at 19.08 hours LT.  At 20.34 hours LT the main engine suddenly sounded a very loud blast, the vessel vibrated, fire broke out in the vicinity of the main engine cylinders and the main engine gradually stopped.  The crew tried to extinguish the fire with local extinguishing system, but the fire was serious and they could not control it. The  Master therefore decided to release the CO2 fixed fire extinguishing system, and the vessel was turned away from the busy channel it was in to a quieter area. At 21.05 hours LT she safely dropped anchor at "CJK" which was 1 nautical mile from N°S2 buoy (Latitude: 31-00.13 N / Longitude: 122-25.02 E)
The fire was eventually extinguished due to the timely release of the CO2 fixed fire-extinguishing system.

NO. 4 MAIN BEARING ALARM GIVEN OUT AT 1700LT ON 6 APRIL 2006 DURING SAILING AT SEA AND IMMEDIATELY STOPPED THE MAIN ENGINE, AFTER INSPECTING AND FOUND NO.4 MAIN BEARING BURNED OUT. SHIP CREW MADE FULL ENDEAVOUR TO REPAIR THE MAIN ENGINE, BUT NO CAPACITY TO REPAIR THE MAIN ENGINE TO CONTINUE SAILING. THROUGH COMMUNICATION BETWEEN MY SHIP OWNER AND CONCERNING PARTY, TUG SB-408 ARRIVED BESIDE MY SHIP AT 0730LT ON 19 APRIL 2006, AND STARTING TOWING MY SHIP AT 09:45LT, SHIP SAFELY DROPPED ANCHOR WITH TUG´S HELP AT COLOMBO ANCHORAGE AT 1040LT ON 20 APRIL 2006.

At 09.58 hours LT on 6 April 2006, the mooring hawser attaching Dampier Spirit to the CALM  buoy at the Stag oil platform off Dampier, Western Australia, parted and forced the ship to put to sea as a cyclone approached. 
Dampier Spirit’s master had delayed making the decision to disconnect from the CALM buoy when a cyclone, centred 200 miles from the ship, was declared. His decision may have been delayed because of ambiguities in the company’s decision guidelines, the procedures did not accurately reflect the ship’s ability to sail away from danger, the Stag platform was still discharging crude oil into the ship’s cargo tanks and the ship had safely remained at the buoy during a previous cyclone:
After the ship had separated from the buoy, it had difficulty in manoeuvring away from the area because the performance of the ship was reduced by the ‘slow steaming’ fuel injector nozzles fitted in the main engine and by the build-up of barnacle and coral growth on the hull.
The ship was tracking towards Tryal Rocks until the wind eased, allowing it to sail into safer water. If Dampier Spirit had grounded on Tryal Rocks, its 12 100 tonnes of crude oil cargo may have been spilled into the sea, resulting in significant damage to the environmentally sensitive mangroves and turtle nesting grounds in the area.

VESSEL WAS SAILING OUT FROM VANCOUVER B.C. BOUND FOR ULSAN, KOREA AT 0940 LT/06TH, FOUND TROUBLE IN NO.5 CYLINDER OF MAIN ENGINE, WHILE THE VESSEL JUST SEE OFF PILOT AT LOCATION 2 MILES SOUTH WEST OF VICTORIA PILOT STATION IN JUAN DE FUCA STRAIT.  VESSEL INFORMED VICTORIA TRAFFIC CONTROL, AND AS PER THEIR INSTRUCTION DROPPED ANCHOR AT 48-20 N, 123 22W.  LATER FOUND MAIN ENGINE NO. 5 UNIT CYLINDER HEAD CRACKED AND SAME REPLACED BY SPARE.  FINALLY VESSEL SAILED OUT AT 1918 LT/06 AFTER FOUND EVERYTHING SATISFACTORY AND PERMISSION GRANTED BY TRANSPORT CANADA.

On 4th April 2006 the LOCH NEVIS was entering Mallaig harbour, and steering was being maintained by schottel units in synch. At 15.00 hours LT the starboard engine shut down, which resulted in the vessel slewing to port and temporarily touching ground. Engines were restarted and vessel continued to berth without any further incident.

Location: SOUTH WEST PART OF NORTH ATLANTIC OCEAN
SummaryOfEvents: AS PER SHIP`S PHYSICIAN THE SUSPECTED CAUSE OF DEATH WAS CARDIAC ARREST.

Location: NEAR THE BOUNDARY BETWEEN MAINLAND CHINA AND HONG KONG SAR
SummaryOfEvents: MSC BARBARA HEAVED UP ANCHOR AND PROCEED TO YANTIAN PORT IN CHINA AT ABOUT 0730HRS.  THE VESSEL COLLIDED WITH A SMALL CHINESE OIL TANKER "SHEK kONG 005" AT ABOUT 0753 IN CHINESE WATER.  AFTER THE COLLISION THE VESSEL NAVIGATED INTO THE HONG KONG WATERS AND WENT AGROUND AT 0819 INSIDE HONG KONG.  MSC BARBARA WAS REFLOATED AT 1317 AND PROCEED TO YANTIAN ANCHORAGE IN CHINESE WATERS FOR CLASS SURVEY BEFORE BERTHING TO YANTIAN PORT.  NO DAMAGE, NO OIL POLLUTION AND NO INJURY WERE REPORTED IN THE INCIDENT SO FAR.

SOLASStatus: MSC BARBARA: Unknown/unspecified, SHI GANG BO 0015: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 4th April 2006 the weather was foggy when the container ship MSC BARBARA proceeded to YanTian entrance buoy No.1 in order to collect pilot. After hauling up anchor from YanTian anchorage No.4. At 07.55 hours LT, MSC BARBARA collided  with a Chinese construction flotilla made up of one tug and one barge, which were crossing the faraway when passing buoy No.1. The collision broke the hull of the barge SHI GANG BO 0015  and created a hole through which seawater flooded into the hold. The barge was made safe about one hour later when the mud on board had been unloaded, and MSC BARBARA sustained only slight damage. After the collision, MSC BARBARA turned left back to anchorage on the scene, then ran aground at the shoal during turning. She floated up 10 hours later without any damage. Both vessels were to blame for the collision - MSC BARBARA for going too fast in foggy conditions, and the flotilla for crossing the fairway with a small angle and at the wrong time.
