On 2nd April 2006 the master of a loaded 3300grt tanker was taking his vessel off the load berth without a pilot, as he held a valid PEC. The master elected not to take a tug despite the wind being fairly fresh.
He lost control of the vessel as he was just off the berth and the vessel's stern landed heavily between two fenders. The vessel sustained a hole in her aft hull, below the poopdeck. Fendering was also damaged on the berth, which was put out of use for a number of days.

SOLASStatus: HANJIN PHILADELPHIA: Unknown/unspecified, XIN JIE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 2nd April 2006 at approximately 04.35 hours LT, the  general cargo ship “XIN JIE” collided with M/V “HANJIN PHILADELPHIA”. The position of the collision was 31°10´.01N, 123°04´.85E. The M/V remained fit to proceed.

On 2nd April 2006 the Liberian bulk carrier SANKO ROBUST was carrying a cargo of steel when it experienced rudder problems. The vessel entered the Suez Cana with north bound convoy and ran aground at KM116. The vessel was refloated the same day with the assistance of four tugs. The diver team reported that the vessel sustained three holes in forepeak, No. 1 ballast tank starboard side and centre tank No. 1 starboard side. The vessel was towed again to KM 1010 for the necessary repairs, and a Flag State investigation was conducted by obtaining flag state report and follow up communication for clarification.

Location: South of Sh. Khalifa Bin Sulman Al-Khalifah
SummaryOfEvents: On 30th March 2006, at around 21:35 hrs, whilst the motor vessel AL-DANA was cruising in the area south of Sh. Khalifa Bin Sulman Al-Khalifah, with 131 passengers and crew on board, she capsized in fair weather conditions resulting in the loss of 58 lives.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: THE SHIP WAS DOING SPEED OF 13 KNOTS AT THE COURSE 293, VISIBILITY IS ABOUT 0.7 MM, AT 1630 HRS ABLE SEAMAN WAS CALLED FOR HAND STEERING, ONE SHIP WAS PASSING FROM PORT TO STARBOARD FORWARD OF THE SHIP.  ONCE THIS VESSEL PASSED.  OTHER SHIP COME FROM PORT THROUGH THAT PLACE BETWEEN LIGHT HOUSE AND LIGHT BUOY.   FOR THAT VESSEL THIS VESSEL ALTER COURSE TO STARBOARD TO 310.  WHEN THIS VESSEL PASSED, THEN ALTER COURSE TO COME BACK TO COURSE, ALTERED TO 270 AFTER ALTERING THE VESSEL TOUCH THE GROUND.-

THE SHIP WAS DOING SPEED OF 13 KNOTS AT THE COURSE 293, VISIBILITY IS ABOUT 0.7 MM, AT 1630 HRS ABLE SEAMAN WAS CALLED FOR HAND STERRING, ONE SHIP WAS PASSING FROM PORT TO STARBOARD FORWARD OF THE SHIP.  ONCE THIS VESSEL PASSED.  OTHER SHIP COME FROM PORT THROUGH THAT PLACE BETWEEN LIGHT HOUSE AND LIGHT BUOY.  FOR THAT VESSEL THIS VESSEL ALTER COURSE TO STARBOARD TO 310.  WHEN THIS VESSEL PASSED, THEN ALTER COURSE TO COME BACK TO COURSE, ALTERED TO 270 AFTER FALTERING THE VESSEL TOUCH THE GROUND.

EN ROUTE FROM OAKLAND TO TOKYO, AT AROUND 12:00LT ON 27 MARCH 2006, THE 2ND OFFICER WAS NOT FOUND IN HIS CABIN AND HAD NOT CLIMBED TO THE BRIDGE FOR THE NAVIGATIONAL WATCH.  ALL CREW MEMBERS WERE SEARCHING HIM ALL OVER THE SHIP BETWEEN 12:15LT AND 14:30LT.  THE WEATHER AND SEA CONDITION AT THAT TIME WERE FOGGY, WIND WW 14 KNOTS THE SEA 2.5 METERS, SWELL WNW 3 METERS, AIR TEMPERATURE 3 DEG. C, WATER 2 DEG. C, VISIBILITY 200~300 METERS.  THIS FACT WAS IMMEDIATELY REPORTED TO THE COMPANY AND WE STARTED THOROUGHLY SEARCHING AGAIN BUT FAILED TO FIND.  WE EXPECTED HIM ACCIDENTALLY OVERBOARD.  WE DECIDED TO CHANGE OUR COURSE BACK TO THE PREVIOUS ORIGINAL ROUTE TO THE POINT WHERE HE WAS LASTLY SEEN BY SHIP'S CREW. WE STARTED SEARCHING HIM ACCORDING TO THE "INTERNATIONAL AERONAUTICAL AND MARINE SEARCH RESCUE MANUAL" WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF THE AIRPLANE DISPATCHED BY THE JAPAN COAST GUARD, HOWEVER WE COULD NOT FIND HIM DUE TO ROUGH SEA AND HEAVY WEATHER CONDITION AIR TEMPERATURE 1DEG. SEA WATER 2 DEG.

On 26th March 2006 the Liberian container vessel IVORY TIRUPATI departed Ashdod for Zeebruggecarrying a full cargo of potatoes in jumbo bags. On passing Cape Finistere and entering the Bay of Biscay she encountered gale force winds up to 8-9 BF and very heavy south-westerly swell causing the vessel to roll up to 34.40 degrees. At about 23.22 on 26th March one cotainer was lost overboard, and a second was lost at about 223.39 in position 45 26.1N, 008 04.2W. On 27th March at approximately 06.47 hours a third container went overboard. At 11.12 another container broke from the twist locks and was wedged etween the railings and bitts. This container was very badly damaged by sea water and the cargo inside the container was destroyed. This ship initially developed a list of about 20 degrees to starboard and subsequently measured as 22 degrees in port. An inspetion of the cargo holds revealed that the cargo had shifted about 2 - 2.5 metres to starboard in all holds. The vessel diverted to Brest to take refuge and correct list, and damage to the vessel was repaired. On April 7th 2006 was permitted to continue her voyage to Zeebrugge by the local port state control authorities.
ON 26TH MARCH 2006 A BROKEN FUEL PIPE WAS FOUND IN THE MAIN ENGINE ON THE BULK CARRIER "ILENAO". THE PART WAS REPLACED AT AROUND 17.45 HOURS LT.

Breaksea embarked 1500 tons of cargo at Whitegate for Dundalk and sailed at 05.40 hours on 26 March 2006.  There was a force 7 from the south, the sea was rough and there was a 4 metre southerly swell running.  At14.50 hours the engine low oil level alarm sounded and the Ch Eng confirmed the level was dropping and this was followed by a falling oil pressure alarm.  He alerted the master and recommended that the engine be stopped.  Because of the navigational situation and the risk of being blown onto the shore the master kept the engine running.  The master activated the First Response Call System to alert the DPA of the situation.  The DPA immediately made arrangements for 2 tugs to proceed to the scene.  The Master alerted the CG 55 minutes after the failure.  In the meantime the engineers decanted oil from the storage tank to the engine until it was eventually stopped by the master at 16.10 hours.  He was told tug support would arrive in 10 hours.  The anchors were prepared for letting go.

The CG activated 2 lifeboats and an Irish Navy vessel to assist.  The LB arrived at 19.10 hours and connected a tow line which was transferred to the IN vessel soon after.  When connecting the line the Ch Officer badly strained his back.   Soon after midnight the 2 tugs arrived and took the tow, the supporting vessels were then released.  The vessel was eventually secured at Great Island at 13.45 hours the following day.

Subsequent investigation revealed that the scavenge oil pump drive had sheared under excessive torsional load and that the gearwheel pump had been jammed with metal debris.  This caused the drive pinion to fall into the sump which damaged No1 cylinder liner, fracturing the sump and causing the oil loss.

On 26th March 2006 the Ro-Ro ferry PRIDE OF CALAIS was allocated a lay-by berth so that stabiliser and main engine defects could be investigated.  It was a clear and bright day and on arrival at 14.30 hours LT the wind was north-easterly between 30 - 35 knots. The mooring arrangements at forward and aft used a mix of ropes and wires for the same function i.e. breast and spring  lines.  The wires were left on the winch drums with the drum disconnected from the winch drive shaft, the band brakes were on, the control lever in neutral and hydraulic pumps shut down. This procedure was normal and accepted practice.  
The forward and after mooring ropes, were secured in a different manner.  The forward mooring party used ropes on bights and left them on the winch warping drum so that equal rope tension to that of the wire could be achieved.  The ropes were then backed up on bitts with figure of eight turns.  The after mooring party used a different method which resulted in an expensive and potentially dangerous accident.  The single, after ropes were also secured on the drum ends but only backed up with just a couple of turns around a single bitt.
The captain received reports from the mooring decks that the ship was "all fast forward" and all "fast aft".  There was no positive reporting on the status of the winches or of the types and number of lines used.  Unfortunately the practice of having an officer supervising the moorings had also fallen into abeyance and no one in authority checked the moorings despite the very windy and obviously risky conditions.  The master was able to view the forward moorings from the bridge but the after moorings were obscured.  There was an assumption that the after moorings were the same as the satisfactory ones forward. At18.10 hours LT, the bridge received a report that one of the stern line wires had "stranded" and that the on-watch deck team intended to replace it.  
A replacement wire was not sent out before removing the damaged one.  The damaged wire had been removed from the jetty bollard and work was underway to detach the wire from the winch drum when the chief officer arrived at the after mooring deck.  Unfortunately the opportunity to check the other moorings and the suitability the remaining single stern line to take the load was not taken. At about 1835 another ferry entered the port. The ship surged about 15 feet up the jetty and the remaining stern line parted and the ship's stern started to leave the quay.  The ship pivoted about the forward port shoulder causing one of the forward breast ropes to part.  As the ship continued to move off the quay the port after winch brakes rendered and the wires were pulled from the winch wire drums.  As weight came onto the after ropes they were pulled from around the loose turns around the single bitts, rotated the winch warping drum which in turn rotated the winch hydraulic motor backwards.  This huge shock loading pressurised the motor casings and they fractured under the excessive pressure spraying hydraulic oil across the port after winch deck.  
The ship adopted an angle of about 45 degrees to the jetty before a nearby tug was raised on VHF and came to the ferry's assistance and pushed her back alongside.

Location: anchored at buffalo bay alivery- Evia channel
SummaryOfEvents: On 25th March 2006 the general cargo ship GEORGINA P was anchored at Buffalo Bay when a small fire caused a short circuit in a crew member's cabin. There were no injuries caused and no damage to the vessel.

24th march 2006, 0705 LT Pilot onboard the vessel for sailing, 0720 LT the anchor up, then start maneuvering to go ahead as the vessel is clear on the anchorage area, 0750 LT the vessel ran aground under the pilot command, 0753 LT the engine was stop then pilot made some maneuvering in order to be clear on the aground area. The company arranged 2 tug boats to assist the vessel to be clear from aground. two tug boats arrived then started maneuvering the vessel but to no avail.
25 march, 1030 LT two pilots arrived onboard for maneuvering, 1328 LT the pilots again started maneuvering for astern, and there was a slight movement of the vessel, 1720 LT after series of manuevers the vessel was cleared from aground.

On 24th March 2006 the m/v CALIFORNIA and m/v Sinokor Seoul collided in the Malacca straits and at approximately 10.15 hours LT the transom of CALIFORNIA slowy disappeared into the water and she sank stern first, completely disappearing in about two or three minutes.
The estimated draft for arrival in Singapore that should have occurred at about noon on 24th March was forward 13.75m.  and aft 13.83m.  The chief Engineer estimated that there were about 90 metric tonnes of fuel oil, 7 metric tonnes of diesel oil and about 20,000 litres of lubricating oil on board at the time CALIFORNIA sank beneath the waters of Malacca Strait.

On 23rd March 2006 the Bahamas bulk carrier CLIPPER LIS was discharging bundles of steel pipe using ship's cranes at Greensport Terminal, Houston. At approximately 16.25 hours the jib of No. 1 crane detached from its pedestal and fell into the hold. The crane driver was injured and sent to hospital for medical treatment.

SOLASStatus: JIAN HUA SHAN 2: Unknown/unspecified, SAMHO FAMILY: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 0450 LT on 23 March, 2006, Chinese vessel JIAN HUA SHAN 2 collided with MV SAMHO FAMILY in eastern south China sea with the position 22°50′.73N/116°26′.00E, under condition of heavy fog, causing total loss to MV JIAN HUA SHAN 2 and minor damage to MV SAMHO FAMILY.

The fire broke out in the accomodation area of the ship on the way to Montego Bay from Grand Cayman, and spread to adjacent cabins. All passengers were immediately mustered to emergency stations. The fire has been extinguished, according to the line.

At 13.06 hours on 22nd March 2006 the Bulk carrier MARINA 1 (11749 gt, built 1977) and coastal c.c. Kai Hang 78, 3985 gt, (built 1976, Zhenhai),  both en route to Shanghai, were in collision. 
Kai hang 78 was subsequently drydocked in a local ship yard for repair, while MARINA 1 went to a shipyard off Changxing Island next to Shanghai. -- "DPS Teamhead Surveyors."

The motor tanker Azov Mariner departed the port of Malmö, Sweden on 22 March 2006, bound for Riga, Latvia.  The vessel was in ballast after she had discharged her cargo of oil at Malmö’s oil harbour.

As soon as the vessel cleared the fairway to Malmö’s oil terminal, the pilot was accompanied to the pilot station by the  Officer of the Watch (OOW).  The pilot disembarked at around 1215.  The vessel proceeded in a southwest direction, steering a course of 2250(T).

At about 1230, the OOW, who had returned to the bridge, took a global positioning system (GPS) position and calculated that the Azov Mariner was four cables from the Flintrännan NE lighthouse.  However, he immediately realised that the vessel was outside the channel and was in fact navigating further to the East.

The OOW changed over to hand steering and put the rudder hard to starboard but the vessel only altered course by a few degrees and subsequently ran aground.  As a result of the grounding, the bottom shell plating in way of the bow thruster room was perforated.

The vessel was refloated and she proceeded back to the port of Malmö.  There were no pollution or injuries reported as a result of this grounding.

Location: Gil Island, Wright Sound, British Columbia
SummaryOfEvents: At 20:00 hours on 21 March 2006, the passenger and vehicle ferry Queen of the North departed Prince Ruppert, British Columbia, for Port Hardy, British Columbia. On board were 59 passengers and 42 crew members. After entering Wright Sound from Grenville Channel, the ship struck the northeast side of Gil Island at approximately 00:21 hours on 22 March 2006. The ship sustained extensive damage to its hull, lost its propulsion, and drifted for about 1 hour and 17 minutes before it sank in 430 m water. Passengers and crew abandoned the ship before it sank. Two passengers were unaccounted for after the abandonment and have since been declared dead.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
M/V HYUNDAI FORTUNE left Port Aden, Yemen,  laden with 5,143TEU of containers, including 7 TEU loaded fire crackers, for Hamburg, Germany, at 17.00 hours(LMT) on March 21, 2006.
 At 17.50 hours LT on the same date, when she was proceeding in the position of LAT. 12-40-00N, LONG.47-22-30E, near the mouth of the Red Sea, there was a sudden explosion at the rear of the bridge, where the fire crackers in R/F containers were loaded. 

The captain heard the explosion in his cabin and went up to the bridge where he found 2nd officer with a blood spattered face. At 12.50 hours LT the master transmitted a distress signal by INMMARSAT C, MF/HF and VHF. 
The captain received a reply from a Dutch War Ship by means of VHF and transffered the wounded officer to the warship by helicopter, and went to fire places at Upp. DK, Bay No.42 & after part. 

At 12.30 hours LT, the crew started fire fighting. In spite of this effort, another explosion followed and the air in the accommodation was thick with smoke. At 14.38 hours LT, the master decided to evacuate the ship for the crew's safety, and at 15.30 hours LT all the crew were transffered to a rescue ship.

On 21st March 2006 at 12.10 hours LT the bulk carrier MARINA 1 collided with M/V KAI HANG78, which was at anchor at CHANG JIANG KOU NO.3 anchorage. M/V KAI HANG78 sustained damage to  No.1 cargo hold on portside.

SOLASStatus: CHANG NING HAI: Unknown/unspecified, MOL VELOCITY: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 20th March 2006 at  12.35 hours LT the M/V MOL VELOCITY collided with a fishing vessel named ZHE LIN YU YUN 254 at position 31°41´.1N, 123°23´.0E, as a result of which the fishing vessel sank. There were no fatalities.

Ship in loading condition (draft 16.5 m) contacted with an unreported sunken vessel on about 2 hours prior to arrival. The depth in this position was 28-29 meters. Vessel arrived by her own to the discharging berth and, after completion discharging directed to the nearest available shipyard (Qingdao).
Caused damages as follow:
Cracks at FPT, No 1 DB (P+S), No 2 DB (S), No 3 DB (S), No 4 (DB).

SOLASStatus: KOREA GAS: Unknown/unspecified, XIN HAI 7: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On 20th March 2006, Tuvalu registered vessel Xin Hai 7 collided with an anchored vessel, Korea Gas in the port of Incheon, Korea at approximately 0401 hrs (local time) and sunk. Of the 17 members onboard the Xin Hai 7, only 5 were rescued. 3 were confirmed dead and 9 missing.

As the incident occured in Korean waters, the lead investigating state is Korea and The Korean Maritime Safety Tribunal is investigating the incident.

SOLASStatus: TS KAOHSIUNG: Unknown/unspecified, WAN TONG: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On March 18th 2006, the Chinese general cargo-ship WANTONG  was en route  from Guangzhou to Dalian, and passing through ShenZhen water in foggy weather. At 21.47 hours LT the WANTONG collided with Singaporean  container ship TS KAOHSIUNG which was en route from Kaohsiung to Hong Kong, position at Lat:22°13.8′N，Long:114°40.3′E, 15 nm south of Sanmen Island.  The collision caused WANTONG’s bow bulb to break and seriously distorted some containers as well as damaging and slightly scraping the starboard side of  KAOHSIUNG. There was no loss of life and nobody was injured, and  both ships were fit to proceed.

Location: 11 miles south east of Portland Bill
SummaryOfEvents: On 17 March 2006, a 9 metre leisure yacht was being delivered from Hamble to Plymouth. On board were the owner and a delivery skipper. At about 23:40, the delivery skipper went overboard. Due to electrical power problems on board, the GPS was not functioning, and although the alarm was raised by   VHF radio, the owner was unable to give his position, and the VHF radio, soon stopped operating. A search and rescue operation involving three RNLI lifeboat, five merchant ships and a coast helicopter, eventually located both the skipper’s body and the yacht.

On 16th March 2006 at 05.58 hours LT the bulk carrier OLUJA collided with the fishing vessel JOESPHINA MARIA. Neither ship altered course, changed speed or had a proper lookout. 
The bulk carrier was obligated to change course but did not do so. The fishing vessel did nothing to prevent the collision either.
COLLISION WITH FIXED OBJECTS.

On 15th March 2006 at 03.20  the safety vessel was dodging near platform and attempts were made to turn the vessel, which did not respond. The Aquamaster was then lowered and used for steerage. Investigations found that the steering was working correctly, but the rudder had fallen off.
The vessel was then drydocked for repair/replacement. Company investigations discovered that the rudder palm bolts had been fitted upside down, they had not been security welded and had not had the split pins fitted when vessel had been in drydock in May 2004. A dock bottom inspection had also been completed at the time,  which had included a rudder check.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: THE M/V CARIDDI, OWNED BY "PROVINCIA REGIONALE DI MESSINA", AT BERTH IN THE DOCKYARD NAMED "EX PICCIOTTO", AND AT DISARMAMENT SINCE 1992, SANK FOR UNKNOWN REASON.

ON 14TH MARCH 2006 THE PASSENGER SHIP CARNIVAL LEGEND WAS SAILING IN THE CARIBBEAN WHEN A PASSENGER, MR. USHER, WAS FOUND DEAD IN HIS CABIN A001 AT 11.20 HOURS LT.
ACCORDING TO THE SHIP'S PHYSICIAN, DR. RAWLINGS, HE DIED OF NATURAL CAUSES.
THERE WERE NO SIGNS OF VIOLENCE, NOR ANY VISIBLE INJURY FOUND ON THE BODY.

InitialEvent: Ship passing at speed during cargo discharge
SummaryOfEvents:
A UK registered liquid gas carrier was alongside and American port discharging her cargo.  The vessel was tied up using 3 head lines, 3 breast lines and 2 springs forward and 3 stern lines, 3 breast lines and 2 springs aft.  The ropes were in good order.  The winch brakes had been set to render at 60 tonnes.

At 0418 on 14 March the vessel was discharging gas; there were 6 crew on deck, with the 2 Off in charge.  Three engineers were also on the engine room watch.  A state pilot was on the bridge and 2 tractor tugs were on standby alongside.

At 0418 an inbound US flagged tanker, reportedly at 24 feet draft and in ballast passed astern in excess of 14 knots.  The speed was confirmed by AIS.  The close proximity caused the discharging vessel to vibrate.  Conscious of the risk the tugs started their engines and were instructed to push the vessel alongside.  The movement of water nevertheless caused the vessel to surge along the jetty initiating the Emergency Shut Down which tripped the cargo pumps and closed the Emergency Shut down (ESD) valves on the ship and ashore.  At the same time both forward spring lines parted at their tails.  Shortly afterwards the ESD 2 was initiated.  All Powered Emergency Release Couplings (PERCs) released the hard arms from the ship.

Immediately afterwards the 2 forward breast lines parted as the tugs then pushed the vessel alongside. The accident resulted in both gangways being destroyed but there was no other damage and no injuries.  Cargo discharge commenced some 12 hours later.

The USCG issued a Marine Safety Bulletin setting out the Policy for LNG Tankship Operations although a maximum passing speed was not specified.  As of the 19 April 2006 the USCG were continuing their investigations focusing on the actions of the passing vessel.

The motor fishing ship Jan Maria, sailing under German flag, reached its setting positions the fishing area west of Ireland on 13 March 2006 at approximately 22:40 hours. On a routine basis, four crew members would be employed on the alt deck of the stern trawler carrying out the work processes required in preparation for putting out the trawl. The Master navigated the ship. At the same time, he operated the various winches from the control position located in the aft part of the bridge.  This position provided him with the best possible overview of the aft deck. 
While handling the trawl gear as required for setting the trawl, suddenly and contrary to the regular procedure, an extremely high line tension came about at the aft midships guide roller.  A deckhand, who for an unexplained reason was in the danger area not visible from the bridge between the vertical guide roller and the tightening lines, was caught by the lines and pressed with a great force against the guide roller. During the process he suffered severe injuries in the chest area, which resulted in his death shortly of immediately implemented first aid measures and direct contact with the radio medical advisory service. A rescue helicopter alreafu dispatched to the Jan Maria was thereupon recalled from the control centre.
The Jan Maria discontinued the setting procedure immediately after the accident and headed for the Irish fishing port of Killybegs, which it reached at approximately 14:00 on 14 March 2006.

On 12TH March 2006, at 14 58LT the "ESTELLA" sailed from Bonny Town with pilot Abaze Godfrey Tari onboard in ballast condition, her destination Ocrika where she intended to load her next cargo. Departure drafts fore 2.1m aft 5.6m.
At 15.57 hours LT while she was passing Buoy 45G, she changed course to 3380 and at that time a vessel was sighted in radar sailing in the downriver direction and heading towards the "ESTELLA". This vessel´s course was 151o.
"ESTELLA" passed abeam buoy 46R at 16 02 hrs LT and altered course to 310 and established visual contact with "CAPTAIN  P". at a distance of about 3.8 miles.
There were attempts to communicate with the other vessel through VHF channels 14+16. These attempts were unsuccessful, as the other vessel did not respond. Attempts to communicate continued unsuccessfully while the "ESTELLA" was passing buoy 49.
At 16 11 hrs LT while the vessel was abeam of Buoy 49, the course was changed on pilot´s orders to 318o. Calling on VHF and blowing of whistle continued. The vessel´s horn was used with continuous sounds and at the same time continuous attempts to make contact through the VHF radio were carried out without success.
At 16 15 hrs LT while the vessel was abeam of buoy 51, the pilot ordered the helmsman hard to starboard because the other vessel was coming at a high speed  directly towards the "ESTELLA`S" ahead.
In an effort to avoid collision the pilot then ordered hard to port but in the meantime at 16 16 hrs LT the other vessel, wich was the "CAPTAIN P", struck the starboard side of the "ESTELLA" with her bulbous bow in way of No. 5, 6, 7 & 8 and tanks  at high speed, as can be seen from the severe damage to the "ESTELLA" shell plating, wich was ruptured open from No. 5 tank to No. 8 tanks. The bulbous bow of the "CAPTAIN P" hit the starboard side shell of "ESTELLA" initially in way of No. 5 stbd cargo tank at an angle of blow of 30º; but because of her speed and construction of bulbous bow (ice class) she continued her movement tearing off the side shell plating, rupturing the shell and creating a rupture of 35 meters in total length from the bottom plating bilge straight up to and including the deck plating wich was ruptured buckled and set in. All internal strengthening in way, including web section frames vertical and longitudinal frames corrugated tank bulkheads and longitudinal bulkheads between side and centre  tanks were destroyed by the force of the impact generated by the angle and speed of the "CAPTAIN P" wich in essence rammed the "ESTELLA".
As a result of the collision the following tanks were breached and are open to the sea;
-     Nos. 5, 6, 7, 8 stbd side cargo tanks
-     Centre Nos. 7 & 8 cargo tanks
-     Slop tank starboard side
-     No. 1 Double bottom fuel oil tank

The vessel took a list to starboard.
The collision ocurred at position: Lat 04º 35.92N - 007 10.46E.
AT 16.18 hrs LT the "CAPTAIN P" disengaged herself from the "ESTELLA" by an astern movement.
At 16 20 hrs LT "ESTELLA" dropped her port anchor at a location near by at position Lat 04º  35.86N - Long 007º 10.46E.

ON 12th MARCH 2006 AT O9.00 HOURS LT, THE VESSEL WAS BERTHING IN CARGO OPERATIONS. DURING AN OIL BUNKERING OPERATION APPROXIMATELY 5 GALLONS OF IFO 380 FUEL WAS DISCHARGED INTO THE COLUMBIA RIVER, CREATING A VISIBLE SHEEN.

The ships collided as they approached a pilot station to disembark their pilots. Sider Joy initially approached the pilot station on a course of 330 at 8.5 knots, and Maralunga on a course of 041 at a sililar speed. At 2050, the vessels were 3nm apart. As the vessels continued to approach the pilot launch, they continued to close, and by 2103 they were 1nm apart. At this point, Sider Joy commenced a turn to port to provide a lee. When turning towards a westerly course, the tanker was assessed to be passing astern, and the pilot onboard the Sider Joy left the bridge to disembark.  The pilots on board the two vessels were in VHF communication with each other, and it was agreed that the pilot on board Sider Joy would disembark first, followed by the pilot on board Maralunga. It was also agreed that the tanker would pass atern of the cargo ship. About 1.5 minutes after the cargo ship started to alter course to port, the tanker also started to turn to port to pass green to green with a third vessel approaching from the north at 1.5nm, which was also heading towards the pilot station to pick up one of the disembarked pilots. The vessels continued to close, and were within 5 cables at 2107 when Maralunga had turned to a course of 020, and Sider Joy to 302. Three minutes later, the vessels collided, with both at a speed over the ground of about 6.5 knots. Damage to both ships was minor.

SC BALTIC passed the rock at a speed of 14 knots and continued. She managed to sail to Haugesund on her own and obtained the class sailing permit to shipyard. Severe damages in the bottom.
The mate was alone on the bridge as Officer of Watch. Afterwards an alcohol test proved that the officer was under alcohol.

On march 10, 2006 at about 17:20 hrs, aboard of the above mentioned vessel, during the final phase of mooring by dock n° 7 of Olbia port, one of the ship's sailor who was close to ship's "panama eye" with the purpose of leaning outboard the second mooring rope has been suddenly hit and injured by one of the pieces of the first rope, which suddenly collapsed.
Sailor has been promptly rescued and taken to Olbia Civilian Hospital, where he underwent emergency surgery.

The domestic RoRo passenger/ vehicle ferry Red Falcon made heavy contact with the linkspan at Town Quay Southamtpon when it was berthing after a voyage from Cowes, Isle of Wight. 
As a result of the collision 8 passengers and 3 crew were injured, none of the injuries were serious and none of the injured were hospitalised.
The vessel is propelled by twin Voith Sneider units which are normally operated in synchronisation. At the time of the accident the units were being operated out of synchronisation

On 9th March 2006 the general cargo ship “TY ORCHID” was leaving the anchorage of Dandong Port in China when she made contact with the wreck of a sunken vessel. Her hull was broken and she began to sink, but all crew members were rescued. However, considerable pollution resulted as she was carrying 156.92 tons of heavy fuel and 36 tons of diesel.

At about 17:13 on the evening of 08 March 2006, the fishing ship B.C. Safari was making way in the straight of Georgia between Deep Bay and French Creek, British Columbia, when it capsized and sank. The master, who was the lone, is missing and presumed drowned
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 8th March 2006 the bulk carrier WATERMAN N  experienced a machine blackout on the River Maas, Netherlands, at 16.30 hours LT. The vessel had left port shortly beforehand and was headed for sea. The tug boat Smit Polen came for assistance and attached a rope.

SOLASStatus: EASTERN DRAGON: SOLAS, YUAN DONG 101: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On 7th March 2006 the EASTERN DRAGON and the YUAN DONG 101 were both sailing upstream in the Yangtse River. At 19.45 hours LT, near Nantong Port, the EASTERN DRAGON attempted to overtake the YUAN DONG 101 from her port side. As a result there was a collision, and the port bow and forepeak tank of MV YUAN DONG 101 were damaged and MV EASTERN DRAGON was damaged the starboard hull plate below the bridge.
Both vessels anchored at Nantong anchorage and were investigated by MSA.
Before 18.00 hours LT on 9th March 2006, both ships were allowed to sail without class survey.
No casualities and no oil spill were reported from this accident.

SOLASStatus: JIE YUAN 202: Unknown/unspecified, MALTO BLOSSOM: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
M/V.MALTO BLOSSOM HAD COMPLETED LOADED CARGO 9541.524 MT OF STEEL WIRE ROD AT NANJING,CHINA ON 6TH MARCH 2006 AND SAILED OUT FOR SHANGHAI,CHINA WITH 2 PILOTS.
M/V MALTO BLOSSOM ANCHORED AT LAT.32°13.9´,LONG.119°10.8´E (NANJING YIZHENG)IN SAME DAY FOR NIGHT STAY AND LEFT ANCHORAGE AT 0500 7TH MARCH 2006 TO SHANGHAI .
AROUND 0840LT 7TH MAR,SET IN DENSE FOG AND REDUCED VISIBILITY ABOUT 250M,COURSE OF M/V.MALTO BLOSSOM WAS 020 DEGREES.SUDDENLY APPEARED ONE SMALL SHIP OF CHINA ON PORT BOW VERY CLOSED AND PILOT ORDERED “HARD-PORT HER HELM”.IMMEDIATELY BECAUSE OF SHIP WAS TOO CLOSED FROM THE SITUATION AND THEN WENT IN COLLISION WITH THE SMALL SHIP,“JIEYUAN 202”.THE SMALL SHIP PASSED BOW OF M/V.MALTO BLOSSOM FROM PORT TO STARBOARD AND LISTED TO PORT DUE TO THE IMPACT OF COLLISION.THE COLLISION ALSO LEAD TO TWO CREW DEAD,ONE CREW DISAPPEARANCE OF CHINESE SHIP .
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: At approximately 06.37 hours on 7th March 2006 a fire broke out in the engine room of the Liberian flagged container vessel NEDLLOYD DE LIEFDE. The vessel was underway from Port of Spain, Trinidad, to Manzanillo for cargo discharge. Out of the 481 containers on board, 60 were full and the rest mostly empty, but there were no live reefers and no IMDG cargo on board. A fire signal was activitated and fire drill started. The main engine was stopped and generators were shut down, but the fire team were unable to enger the engine room due to extreme heat. The Master and Chief Engineer decided to release CO2, and a Mayday message was sent via VHF Channel 16. A second fire team entered the boiler room from the forward door and eventually the two fire teams managed to extinguish the blaze. Three tugs later came to assist the vessel, which arrived at her destination of Manzanillo on March 8th 2006.

SOLASStatus: EAST CARRIER: Unknown/unspecified, ZHE DAI YU 15257: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 23.45 HOURS LT ON 9th MARCH 2006, THE M/V EAST CARRIER collided with a fishing vessel named ZHE DAI YU 15257, which was at anchor in position 31°41´.1N, 123°23´.0E.  The vessel remained fit to proceed.

InitialEvent: work-related accident (during recovery of portable gangway)
SummaryOfEvents:
The cook of the LASH vessel SPRUCE sustained serious injuries to his left leg and left pelvis as the result of a fall of 6m from the ship's deck into the empty barge hold.
SPRUCE was alongside at Victoria harbour, Hartlepool.  The vessel had completed the discharge of a full load of barges and was then deballasted to her usual seagoing condition of 4.25m draught even keel.
The incident occurred during the recovery of the vessel's portable gangway shortly before SPRUCE was due to let go her ropes and sail from the port.  The injured person was assisting in this operation, although he was not trained for working on deck.
The operation to recover the gangway was labour intensive; five members of crew were used to manhandle the gangway up the side of the vessel to the main deck where the stowage position was located.   The vessel was originally fitted with a method of retrieval for a fixed gangway, but this had been cropped and removed a number of years previously.
The minimum number of deck and engine personnel required by the vessel's Minimum Safe Manning Certificate (SMC) were insufficient for mooring operations and supplementary tasks.  It was necessary for the cook and the steward (who were not included on the SMC) and motermen to assist on deck at times of peak workload.
On SPRUCE, the working regime relied on a system of Inter-Departmental Flexibility, but this had not been accounted for when determining the crew numbers under the SMC or when developing the ship's safety management system.
AT 5:50, LONDON TIME, BULK HAPPY DAY HAD A MACHINE BLACKOUT AT FREIBURG ROADS ON THE ELBE.  TUGS BUGSIER 12 AND BUGSIER 15 WENT FROM BRUNSBUTTEL TO THE AID OF THE SHIP.

SOLASStatus: GANG LONG YUN 3: Unknown/unspecified, STAR XINGANG: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 01.20 hours LT on 5th March 2006, the vessel Gang Long Yun 3 was en route from TianJing to Shanghai, when she collided with Panamanian bulk carrier STAR XINGANG at the Laotieshan channel (38°23′. 7N, 121°12′.4E). NO.4 Hatch on  Port side was  damaged. Gang Long Yun 3 was later towed to a safe place.

The Pandion was enroute from Nynäshamn to Holmsund, Sweden and was loaded with Bitumen. At 0745 hrs the vessel passed the lighthouse Väktaren at a distance of about 100 metres and than touched the bottom. After a while the Pandion received a list to port.
When the vessel came closer to the Holmsund harbour the rudder was by mistake turned about 15 degrees to starboard and the vessel grounded. The Pandion managed to refloat by shifting cargo and could by own powder proceed to Tallin for repair.

WAITING TO BERTH AT THE NORTHERN PERUVIAN REFINERY OF PETROL PERU IN TALARA, SEVEN ARMED MEN BOARDED THE VESSEL IN THE EARLY HOURS OF MARCH 4.  WHILE HOLDING THE MASTER AND CREW AT GUN POINT, ROBBERS STOLE PERSONNEL EFFECTS, MONEY, WATCHES, LAP TOPS AND ALSO EXPENSIVE TANKER EQUIPMENT GPS, RADIOS, ETC.
, M.V.“LUCK HARBOR”dragged the cultivation drafts on her way from    to   due to the heavy winds and seas and neglectful in taking precautions

On 2nd March 2006 at 11.20 hours LT, the TK BARCELONA dropped anchor at Novorossiysk outer anchorage area.

The crew members were keeping anchor watches and were aware of the weather forecasts indicating that the wind in the area was expected to increase.

On 3rd March 2006 at 16.00 hours LT the wind was Northwesterly force 7.  By 19.00 hours LT the chief mate, who was on watch, advised the master of the vessel that the wind had increased to force 9.

At around 19.10 hours LT the vessel started to drag anchor and the master decided to head out to the open sea.  At 19.15 hours LT the vessel was cleared by the port control authorities to proceed out to sea, the anchor was heaved up and the master tried to steer the vessel on a heading out to sea.  During these manoeuvres at 20.25 hours LT, the vessel experienced difficulties in keeping her course because of the effects of the weather.  Some time later, the master realised that his vessel was in risk of hitting an anchored vessel.  As she was not responding to the helm because of the weather, the master decided to drop the starboard anchor and apply full astern on the main engine to avoid a collision.  His intentions were to have the wind and sea swing his vessel round and then proceed out to the open sea.  After some time the vessel turned around into the wind and the master heaved up the anchor and headed out to the open sea.

During this manoeuvring the vessel came to a position close to the shoreline and again was experiencing difficulties in keeping on course due to the weather, which by now had worsened.  The master decided to repeat the same manoeuvre and dropped the starboard anchor in an attempt to swing the vessel into the wind.  However, the master became aware that the anchor was not holding and the vessel was drifting closer to the shoreline.  The port anchor was released but the vessel continued to drag both anchors and drift closer to the shoreline.  At 21.38 hours LT, the vessel touched the bottom but by 22.30 hours LT, she was hard aground.

Some days later the vessel was re-floated with the assistance of tugs and towed to a shipyard for repairs.

SOLASStatus: MAERSK DABOU: Unknown/unspecified, Zhe Pu Yu 31123: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 2nd March 2006 at approximately 19.49 hours LT the container ship MAERSK DABOU was proceeding from Shanghai to Shenzhen when it collided with the fishing vessel Zhepuyu 31123, owned by Yuan Hongbin.  The “MAERSK DABOU”left the scene of the accident, and the  “ZHEPUYU 31123” subsequently sank, as a result of which six fishermen lost their lives.
On 2nd March 2006 at 10.00 hours LT the chemical tanker M/V BOTANY TRADITION was in port No. 1 at Maribynong when a small spillage of cargo onto the deck occurred. None was spilt onto the harbour.

On 2nd March 2006 the fishing vessel JOHANNA was in the North Sea when she deliberately entered the prohibited zone of a gas production platform at 02.50 hours LT. Due to a sharp manoeuvre with the fishing nets out around the platform, the vessel made contact with the pillars of the platform,  with the result that production on the platform had to be stopped. Damage to the protective coating of the pillars was caused by the contact.

A Danish tanker on a river was turning and entered into a canal in order to pass a lock. A pilot was on board. The pilot estimated that a tugboad was not necessary. The tanker had several sharp turns. The tanker hit the lock and got damages on the stem and bulp. The tanker had to proceed to shipyard for repair afterwards. The causes were strong and turbulent current, narrow passing space at the lock and not using a tugboat.

On 28th February 2006 the bulk carrier PROTECTOR was en route from Matola Grain Berth Terminal to Maputodu after discharging about 10,000 tonnes of wheat in bulk. Between the hours of 12.00 - 14.00 and during sailing manoeuvres whilst still on the Maputo Channel, the vessel contaced the quay side at the container depot  owned by MIPS- Mozanbique International Port Services, and caused heavy damage to the quay side. It is not clear how this happened. The vessel sustained heavy bulbous bow damage.
The reason for the vessel to veer towards the quay is still being ascertained, however it seems that there was no failure of equipment and that the incident was due to either an incorrect  helm order or shallow water effect- squat or similar- as the vessel transited the lower end of the Motola channel before turning to starboard into the main harbour area.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP "RAFFAELE SAVARESE" HAD BEEN LAID UP SINCE 24TH OCTOBER 2003, AND WAS NOT IN GOOD REPAIR. SHE WAS LETTING IN WATER, AND HAD BEEN THE OBJECT OF SEVERAL INTERVENTIONS TO EMPTY OUT THE WATER. THE SHIP OWNER HAD BEEN WARNED MANY TIMES THAT THE SHIP WOULD SINK IF APPROPRIATE PRECAUTIONS WERE NOT TAKEN. 

ON 27.02.2006, BECAUSE OF DRIVING RAIN AND CONSEQUENT FLOODING, THE SHIP SANK IN SPITE OF THE INTERVENTIONS OF A TANKER OF CIVIL DEFENCE.

OVERFLOW OF FUEL OIL ON DECK.  
AS PER TANK SOUNDING AND PUMP CAPACITY AND OVERFLOW PERIOD IT IS ESTIMATED AS 1.7CU.MTR. ON DECK AND SOME OIL HAS SPILLED OVER INTO THE SEA.  DURING TRANSFERRING OF F.O. FROM #1(P) DOUBLE BOTTOM TANK TO #2 (P) WINF STORAGE TANK IN ENGINE ROOM.

The EVANGELIA M loaded a cargo of feed barley in bulk at the port of Odessa, Ukraine.  The vessel was bound for the port of Jubail, Saudi Arabia.  On 25 February 2006, the vessel stopped at Istanbul, Turkey for bunkering and at 22.00 hours LT she resumed her voyage.

On 26 February 2006, at 04.00 hours LT, the chief mate took over the navigation watch from the second mate.  The master was also on the bridge at the time.  At 04.30 hours LT the chief mate called VHF the VTS station, ‘Sector Gelibolu’ and informed them of the vessel’s position and intentions.  The VTS station advised the vessel to standby for further instructions via VHF.

At 05.30 hours LT, the VTS station called the vessel and informed the chief mate that the passage was not scheduled for that day and that they were to proceed to an anchorage area, 16 miles Northeast of Gelibolu lighthouse.

The vessel at the time was 13 miles from Gelibolu lighthouse and was instructed to alter course to the indicated anchorage area.  The master decided to wait for some more time before turning back to enable the vessel’s engineers to change over from heavy oil to diesel oil.

At 06.10 hours LT, the master ordered the helmsman to put the wheel hard to starboard and the vessel started to turn around to starboard away from the traffic separation zone.  At 06.21 hours LT, as the vessel had almost completed the 180 degree turn, she made contact with the bottom and lost all forward speed.

The main engine was stopped and the VTS station was informed of the grounding.  Attempts to refloat the vessel by own power failed and a salvage company was contracted to assist the vessel which was re-floated with the assistance of two tugs on 01 March 2006 at 18.00 hours LT.

A diver’s inspection was carried out which confirmed that the vessel had suffered no damages other than paint scratches to the bottom.  The vessel was allowed to proceed on her voyage to Jubail, Saudi Arabia.

A vessel was departing port, with a pilot onboard, navigating through an ice channel, speed 10 knots. 30 minutes after casting off the main engine automatically shut down, the vessels speed was quickly reduced by the ice flow, steering was lost and the vessel drifted to the starboard extremity of the channel where she grounded approximately 6 minutes after the engine shut down. The starboard bow was approximately 1 cable outside of the fairway. The main engine had been repaired but was stopped to avoid the possibility of further damage.
The master ordered sounding (internal and external) and informed the port authorities. No damage was found. 
After deballasting was complete the vessel refloated using her own power, and with a tug to assist turning in the channel and to stand by as required.
The vessel returned to port where divers undertook a full underwater survey, under supervision of Class. No damage observed other than superficial damage to echo sounder and log sensors.

However, problems with the main engine alarm & protection system were found, in effect the engine had been automatically shut down when there was no real fault on the engine. There had been a failure of a pressure sensor which resulted in an automatic shut down.
There is an emergency RUN button fitted but it was not used.

On 21st February 2006 the "Amundsen" Canadian coast guard ice breaker was approaching the bulk carrier ATLANTIC EXPRESS in order to break the ice around her.  She had become stuck in concentrated ice on her way from Contrecoeur Canada to Quebec, before passing Quebec Bridge. At 17.07 hours LT the  Tug boat "Ocean Bravo" made fast on forward bow starboard side to assist the vessel to pass the bridge, which she did shortly afterwards.

InitialEvent: Engine Room Bilge water treated by Oil Separator to avoid mixture.
SummaryOfEvents:
On 21st February 2006 the refrigerated cargo vessel WASHINGTON was scheduled to treat the bilge water by Oil Separator before entering the special area of MAPOLANNEX I REGULATIONS 10, but had been unable to do so because of bad weather and rough seas around the North Atlantic ocean. The crew members therefore stopped treatment of bilge water and kept it in the tank.   
When the weather conditions became more favourable they decided to discharge the Engine Room Bilge water treated by Oil Separator to avoid it becoming mixed and kept it below 15 ppm.

On 20th February 2006 the ANGLIAN WAY was approaching berth when a sudden squall of wind NE 30-35 Knots caused the ship to drift towards the small tug "Tayra", which was moored close to RoRo berth.  The ANGLIAN WAY made contact with "Tayra", causing a slight dent on the tug port quarter, but there was no damage to the "Anglian Way".  The area of the port was very confined with little room for manoeuvre when the wind force increased.

During a voyage in Skagerrak, a crewmember went missing. The crewmember was not on duty. The last time, he was seen on board, was at noon. At approx. 13 hours they could not find him and they began searching on board. At approx 14 hours PAN PAN was send out. The ship turned around and began searching. A SAR operation by helicopter, aeroplane and ships was initiated. The crewmember was not found.
Engineer inspecting the engineer room fell through floor plates which had not been replaced or resecured properly. The  vessel was undergoing a repair/refit.

WHILE ON PASSAGE TO HUMBER ANCHORAGE OFF CLIPPER GAS FIELD VESSEL WAS DUE TO A/CO WHEN PLATFORM 48/19 WAS RIGHT AT 1.8 MILES. WHEN VESSEL WAS MORE THAN 4 MILES AWAY FROM A/CO POSITION TRIED TO CONTACT VTS HUMBER USING BOTH VHF SETS ON CH 14 AND 15. AS VESSEL DID NOT USE DUAL WATCH ON CH 16, DID NOT REPLY WHEN CONTACTED BY GUARD VESSEL ON CH 16 ALSO DID NOT CHECK DISTRESS COLLISION MESSAGE SENT. VL ALTERED COURSE WHEN 4 MILES OFF AS NOTICED GUARD VESSEL SHOWING FLASHING LIGHT. THIS WAS CONSIDERED TO BE A NEAR MISS BY GUARD VESSEL AND HUMBER COAST GUARD WAS INFORMED BY THEM.

Location: Off north west coast of Spain
SummaryOfEvents: On 18th February 2006 the container ship CMA CGM VERDI was at sea and carrying containers on deck that had been stowed and secured as normal. The vessel was pitching heavily, yet the motion of the ship was not excessive and the angle of roll was under 10 degrees. However, at 00.58 hours LT a stow of containers were lost overboard, and before arrival at port the vessel lost a total of 77 containers,  and a further 52 were damaged. The cause of the collapse of the container stow was not clear.

InitialEvent: GROUNDED AND CRACKED OF THE HULL
SummaryOfEvents: THE SHIP RAN AGROUND AND BROKE UP LAST NIGHT, TWO MILES EAST OF DONGSHEN ISLAND, FUJIAN.  THE REPORT SAID THAT VESSEL GROUNDED AT 2308 AND LOST CONTACT WITH THE RESCUE CENTER IN SHANGHAI.  A HELICOPTER SURVEYING THE SCENE AT 0614 TODAY REPORTED THAT THE HULL HAD CRACKED INTO TWO PARTS.  AFTER AN EMERGENCY SEARCH, IT WAS REPORTED AS OF 0830 THIS MORNING THAT ONE SEAFARER HAD SURVIVED, THREE WERE DEAD AND 33 WERE MISSING.  SEVEN SHIPS ARE SAID TO BE INVOLVED IN CONTINUING RESCUE OPERATIONS.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents:
Le C MA-CGM Otello, porte-conteneurs de 8238 EVP, armé à Marseille, faisait route de Porte Kelang (Malaisie) au Havre, via le Canal de Suez, franchi le 12 Février 2006, et le Detroit de Gibraltar, franchi, lui le 16 Février 2006.

A partir du Cap Saint-Vincent, doublé ce même 16 Février, il fait route au nord  et subit  un vent fraîchissant de secteur Ouest et une mer du vent se creusant sur une grosse houle de Nord-Ouest, générant un tangage prononcé.
Le 17 Février 2006 à 01 : 00 heure, il double le Cap Finistère et fait route au 027°. Le navire tangue et  sur une mer devenue très forte.

A 07:25, le bord constate la perte de 50 conteneurs de 40 pieds, ainsi que l’affaissement et le ripage de 20 autres, tous situés sur l’arrière des superstructures à tribord. Celle-ci est supposée  s’être produite entre 05:00  et 07:25 heures. Le commandant prévient les autorités concernées, puis poursuit  sa route et arrive au Havre le 18 Février 2006.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: STRUCTURAL FAILURE OF BOTTOM TIER OF 3HIGH REEFER CONTAINERS (FEU), CAUSING COLLAPSE OF 2 STACKS OF CONTAINERS (FEU), THESE 2 STACKS LEANS ON 3 HIGH CONTAINERS (FEU) ON DECK. THIS VESSEL WAS ROLLING UP TO 40" IN HEAVY SWELL TOO ROUGH SEA IN VICINITY OF BAY OF BISCAY THESE 3 HIGH TIERS ALSO COLLAPSED CAUSING THIS CASUALTY.   FIVE CONTAINERS (NOT SIX) LOST AT SEA.

AT ABOUT 2300 ON FEBUARY 16, 2006, M/V"HEND DA 1" STRUCK A ROCK AND BROKEN, THEN SUNK NEAR AN AREA OF DONGJIA ISLAND (25°17.30N/119°46.40E) DURING HER VOYAGE FROM FUZHOU, CHINA TO BITUNG, INDONESIA. THERE WERE 37 PEOPLE ON BOARD , INCLUDING 26 CREWS AND 11 OTHER NON-CREW PERSONS. UNTIL NOW, 2 PERSON WERE RESCUED, 10 PERSON DIED AND 15PERSON IS STILL MISSING.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Vessel approached Holyhead TSS port from West, turning at a point 150m east of Admiralty pier dolphin.  At the turning point vessel was seen to shudder and list to stbd.  Charted depth was 5.7m plus tidal height of 1.25m, vessel draft 4.3m.  Stbd hull was holed midships, approximately 0.1m x 2m in stbd pump room.  Compartment was flooded, requiring 350 tonnes counter flooding in port ballast tanks to keep vessel upright. Cooling pumps flooded leading to loss of stbd generators.  Position of vessel confirmed in accordance with passage plan by ECDIS, VDR and VTS playback.  Damage thought due to uncharted obstruction.  Vessel alongside 20-30 mins late, all passengers disembarked safely; no injuries, no pollution.  Sidescan and bathymetric survey of inner harbour planned to commence 19/20 Feb.

Investigation received from Safety Manager indicates that the vessel had recently been fitted with new bridge systsem.  The IAS, GPS and ECDIS clocks had not been synchronized and the electronic charts had not had danger areas highlighted.  The vessel conducted its turn about 50 further south than normal, but there should have been adequate depth of water.  Sidescan and diver surveys found several boulders, but none were considered large enough to have caused the damage.  No signs of paint or scraping were found.  

The company has now marked danger areas on its charts and included clock synchronization in daily checklists.  An operational memo has been published warning of the dangers of squat at speeds over 10kts.  The harbour authority will complete sidescan surveys every 3 months over the coming year to ensure a safe minimum depth is being maintained

ON 15TH FEBRUARY 2006 A CHIEF OFFICER ON BOARD THE BULK CARRIER "SANTA ISABEL" ACCIDENTALLY DISCHARGED ABOUT 3 LITRES OF LUBRICATION OIL BY FORGETTING TO CHANGE THE MANUAL VALVES FROM HIGHT LEVEL TO LOW LEVEL.

THE OWNERS SUBSEQUENTLY CHANGED MANUAL VALVES STERN TUBE LUBRICATION SYSTEM TO AIR SEALING LUBRICATION SYSTEM ON LAST DRY DOCK(JULY/2006).

At 2232 on 12 February 2006, the Switzerland registered combi freighter KATHRIN ran aground on the Goodwin Sands in the Dover Strait.  The vessel was re-floated 15 minutes later and continued on passage to New Holland, River Humber, where she arrived on 15 February.  
There were no injuries or damage to the vessel, and there was no pollution.
The grounding occurred when KATHRIN was on passage from Aviles, Spain to New Holland.  The ship was in ballast, and had crossed the south west traffic lane of the Dover Strait TSS when the Master, who was the OOW, fell asleep whilst he was alone on the bridge. The ship ran aground about 18 minutes later.

The investigation carried out by the MAIB highlighted several contributory factors including the fact that the Master was under the influence of alcohol and that contrary to regulation, and company requirements, it was usual practice on board for an additional lookout not to be used during darkness.

On the 12th Febrary 2006 at 16.25 UTCm while transiting in the Pembroke Reach with Pilot onboard, the BOA VISTA came into contact with the Neyland Point beacon. Given below is  sequential description of the event.
14.30 UTC: Vessel picked up pilot Capt. Bevan at Milford Haven pilot station to enable own vessel to proceed & berth at Pembroke Harbour Ro-Ro terminal. Master-Pilot Exchange was carried out immediately.
14.54 UTC: vessel entered West Channel.
15.15 UTC: Bow thruster on standby & vessel reduced speed to allow outbound ferry to clear the channel.
16.12 UTC: Tug ANGLEGARTH fast on port quarter with one tug's line.
16.23 UTC: With ship on a heading of 090(T) and speed about 4.0 kts Pilots ordered Rudder to Hard starboard, to enable the vessel to turn to starboard onto a new course of 132(T).
16.24 UTC: It was however observed that the vessel was not turning to starboard & was closing in onto the Neyland Beacon which was on the Port bow. Pilot immediately ordered Port Engine to Full Ahead, Starboard Engine to Full Astern and Bow Thruster Full to Starboard and also ordered to cast off the tug which was pushing on the port quarter.
16.25 UTC: The Neyland Point beacon came in contact with the port side of the vessel at a distance of apprx 30 mtrs from the bow and continued to scrape past the port side for a length approximately 20 meters. The tug had by then stopped pushing & had fallen astern of the ship by slacking the tug's line which was on a winch drum on the tug, however the tug could not be cast off at that instance as the tug line was very heavy. The stern passed clear of the Neyland Point beacon with a clearance of 3 meters.

The damage to the ship was limited to a couple of paint scratches of approximately 20 meters length on the port side and damaged hand rail below the Port side Passenger access door. The beacon had her platform & guardrails damaged on the side of contact with the ship.

16.27 UTC: Engines were stopped to check for any damages but no serious damages observed and vessel proceeded to berth.
16.48 UTC: First line ashore.
17.42: All fast & finished with Engines after positioning & lowering of stern ramp. Tug was cast off, Pilot away & Agent onboard.
18.15 UTC: Harbour master onboard and discussed the event with Master. Charts were checked & vessel position verified. Damage to the ship was noted. It was agreed between the Harbour Master & the Vessel Master that a soft glancing contact was made between the vessel & the beacon with no serious damage done to either & the vessel was cleared to sail on completion of cargo.
Harbour Master requested a Statement Of Facts from the vessel to be sent to the local agent of the Vessel after sailing.
18.45 UTC: Harbour Master disembarked from the vessel.

21.18 UTC: Vessel sailed out of Pembroke after discharging her cargo.

10 FEB 2006 AT 23:18 LT, MSC JILHAN WAS ENTERING NEW SOUTHERN LOCK IN BRUNSBUTTEL for transit of Kiel Canal. INSIDE OF LOCK, 3 VESSELS HAVE ALREADY BEEN MOORE. 2 SMALL SHIPS TO THE STARBOARD SIDE OF LOCK, AND ONE "TRANS CARRIER" TO THE PORT SIDE, ABOUT 5 MTRS AHEAD OF EXPECTED OWN VESSEL POSITION.
VESSEL WAS UNDER PILOTAGE OF KIEL CANAL PILOT VESSEL WAS ENTERING THE LOCK AT THE SPEED OF ABOUT 2 KNOTS. VESSEL WAS NICELY PORT SIDE ALONGSIDE. THE ENGINE WAS RUNNING ASTERN AND THE SPEED DROPPED. USING BOW THRUSTER TO PORT-NO ANY EFFECT, (BOW THRUSTER WAS TESTED PRIOR ENTERING THE LOCK AT PRESENCE OF CANAL PILOT-NO REMARK). AFTER COLLISION IT WAS FOUND THAT BOW THRUSTER WAS OUT OF ORDER-5 SETS OF BURNT ROTORRESISTOR BLOCKS INSIDE OF CONTROL SWITCHBOARD OF BOW THRUSTER, BUT NO ANY ALARM CAME TO THE BRIDGE OF ENGINEER CONTROL ROOM)
23:22LT VESSEL BOW WAS GOING TO STARBOARD. SPRING LINE WAS ASHORE TO TAKE THE STARBOARD TURN, DEAD SLOW AHEAD, WHEEL HARD TO PORT. THE SPRING WAS PARTED AND AT 23.25 LT MV MSC JILHAN STRUCK THE STERN OF MV TRANSCARRIER WITH MINOR DAMAGE TO BOTH VESSELS.
TRANS CARRIER HAS SLIGHTLY DAMAGE OF STERN RAMP AND RESUMED ITS VOYAGE SOON AFTEER THE INCIDENT.
MSC JILHAN SAILED FROM LOCK, AFTER KIEL CANAL AUTHORITIES INVESTIGATION AT 0030 11/02/06 AND BY REQUEST OF PORT STATE CONTROL OFFICER WAS MOORED TO DOLFINS INSIDE OF KIEL CANAL AT 0140 11/02 WITH ASSISTANCE OF ONE TUG BOAT. ON REQUEST OF PORT STATE CONTROL OFFICER, CLASS GERMANISCHER LOYD SURVEY CARRIED OUT FM 0530 LT TILL 0830 LT. CONDITION OF CLASS, MACHINERY IMPORTED: "BOW THRUSTER FOUND OUT OF ORDER. TO BE REPAIRED NOT LATER THAN NEXT YARD PERIOD". AT 08.40 LT 11/02/06 VESSEL RECEIVED PERMISSION FM KIEL PORT STATE CONTROL OFFICER TO RESUME THE VOYAGE. AAT 10.10 KIEL CANAL PILOT O/B, VESSEL RESUMED VOYAGE. 

NOT ANY TUG WAS ESCORTED MSC JILHAN DURING TRANSIT OF KIEL CANAL.

Location: Off Björn Island, Gulf of Bothnia
SummaryOfEvents:
Whilst on a voyage from Norrsundet, Sweden to the Kiel Canal and loaded with a timber cargo above and below deck, the general cargo vessel BREMER VICTORIA run aground at Björn, a small island off the mainland Swedish coastline in the Gulf of Bothnia.
Although damage was sustained to the forward underwater part of the vessel and she was held fast on the rocks, there was no pollution and no personal injury. Under the command of the vessel´s Master various attempts were made overnight to free the ship using her own engines.  The Swedish Coast Guard boarded the vessel the vessel at 09h30 on 11th February to assess the situation and assist where possible.  A pilot boarded at 10h10 when further attempts were made with the assistance of a tug to free the ship.  The vessel remained fast and the pilot departed at 19h00.
Another vessel owned and operated by the same company that was nearby and in ballast arrived at the scene at 08h20 on 13th February 2006 and by using her own deck cranes managed to lighten the BREMER VICTORIA sufficiently for her to float free of the rocks by 14h30 the same day.  Both vessels returned to the loading port of Norrsundet to discharge the cargo.

On 10th February 2006 the DISCOVERER SEVEN SEAS sailing off the southern Indian coast.  At approximately 09.20 hours LT a crew member, Mr. Preveen Prajapat, was descending a ladder when he slipped and fell roughly 40 feet into the water and drowned.

The vessel was at the time undergoing an annual Safety Equipment Statutory Survey.  The class surveyor requested the crew to start the starboard lifeboat engine.  One crew member entered the enclosed lifeboat and started the engine without any problems.  The boat was still in the stowed position with the gripes on.

After starting the engine, the crew member indicated that he was about to engage the propeller in gear.  Almost immediately, the forward and aft hooks opened simultaneously, the lifeboat moved off the davits and fell down the shipside with the electrician still inside.  The lifeboat hit the water on her port side but self-rightened immediately.  The drop was about eight metres.

The crew member walked out of the lifeboat from the aft access hatch.  The embarcation ladder was lowered and the crew member climbed back on board.  He suffered minor bruising in the mask region.  A medical examination at one of the local clinics did not reveal serious injuries.The lifeboat was recovered and the damages sustained were assessed.  The minor repairs were carried out on the following day.

SOLASStatus: EVER BRIGHT: SOLAS, MIN LIAN YU 1028: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At 12.26 hours LT on 9th February 2006 the MV EVER BRIGHT collided with the fishing boat MIN LIAN YU 1028 in vicinity of MAZU ISLAND at position: PA:26-19.4N/120-01.3E.
The fishing boat MIN LIAN YU 1028 capsized at the scene of the accident, with the result that seven crew lost their lives, and one went missing.

S.A., collided with M/V XIN LIANYUNGANG owned by the China Shipping Container Lines Co., Ltd.  The collision took place in the East China Sea at position: 26°53′N/121°26′E.  The M/V EVER GAIN sank as a result, with the loss of ten crew members.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 8th February 2006 the Dutch fishing vessel was in the North sea. At 13.00 hour LT, whilst heaving up full fishing net, a crew member was hit by slipping wire and later died from his injuries.

Location: ANTWERP SHIP REPAIR IN DRY DOCK NO. 6
SummaryOfEvents: AT 10:30: CHIEF OFFICER FOUND DENSE SMOKE AT BALLAST TANK COMPATMENT. 1032: REPORTED TO MASTER.  1035: RIGGED FIRE HOSES, SCBA SEA AND DRY DOCK AUTHORITY INFORMED FIRE BRIGADE.  1050: FIRE BRIGADE ARRIVED AT DRY DOCK 1100:FOUR FIRE BRIGADE WORKERS ON BOARD.  1120: TWO PEOPLE ENTERED IN BALLAST TANK COMPARTMENT.  1130: DECK WATER STARTED.  1142 FIRE EXTINGUISHED USED PORTABLE C02 AND REMOVED THE JUTE FROM THE COMPATMENT THAT WAS EMITTING SMOKE.  1142: FIRE BRIGADE WORKERS EVACUATE AND SEALS THE COMPARTMENT.  12:00 ALL FIRE BRIGADE ENGINES LEFT THE DOCK.  1305:HEMIST BOARDED.  1315: CHECK THE CONTENTS WITH EXPLOSIMETER INSIDE BALLAST TANK COMPARTMENT AND FORWARD PEAK TANK AND FOUND SAFE FOR ENTRY IN HOT WORK.  1336: CHIEF  OFFICER INSPECTED BALLAST TANK COMPATMENT I N FORE PEAK TANK. FOUND NO DAMAGE.  THE FIRE BRIGADE LOCATED THE CAUSE (SEAT) OF FIRE TO BE HAND FULL OF NEW JUTE LYING IN THE BALLAST TANK COMPATMENT.  THIS WAS SMOLDERING N GENERATING SMOKE, WHICH GOT TRAPPED IN THIS SMALL COMPATMENT.  THERE WAS NOT FIRE AS SUCH.

SOLASStatus: HUA ZUN: SOLAS, QIONG LIN GAO 10081: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 06.26 hours LT on February 7 2006 the Cambodian cargo vessel HUA ZUN was en route from Yang Jiang Port, China, to Campha Port, Viet Nam,  when she collided with the fishing boat Qionglingao 10081 of HaiNan Province of China, at position 20º10′.30N/110º20′.74E in the Qiong Zhou straits. The collision resulted in four crew on the fishing boat being injured, and the fishing vessel sank. Hai Nan Maritime Search and Rescue Center harmonized and organized 2 tugs, and many fishing boats in the vicinity to search, 13 fishermen in distress were finally rescued.

On 7th February 2006 at 02.22 hours LT the vessel was transiting Kiel canal, when a main engine piston failure caused the oil mist detector to stop the engine. The vessel temporarily lost steerage and came into contact with a dolphin, but when no engine faults were found the engine was restarted. The vessel then continued on passage to port, but knocking noises were heard emanating from the engine while the vessel was in Elbe. The engine was stopped again, and this time an investigation found a scored piston and cylinder of #3 unit. The vessel was then towed by tugs to discharge berth, where an engine repair team was waiting.
ON 06.02.2006, AT 21:50 HRS THE M/V HANIFE ANA GROUNDED AT NORTH OF BRINDISI, NEAR COSTA MERLATA, DUE TO THE FAULT AND THE LACK OF SKILL OF THE MASTER OF THE SHIP.

On 6th February 2006 en route from Abiddjan to Istanbul, the bodies of four stowaways were discovered at approx. 12.00 hours LT on board M/V C-AKABEY. After investigations had been carried out it was agreed that the stowaways could have boarded the vessel at Abidjan any time between 29th January and 5th June 2006 whilst the cargo of cocoa beans was being loaded in loose bags.  The security of the vessel and prevention of stowaways joining a vessel were arranged by ship's crew in full complience with ship's ISPS Security Plane.

On 5 February 2006, PACIFIC SUN berthed at number eight wharf Darling harbour, Sydney.  The weather was fine with little wind.  The twelve to four quartermaster was assigned to clean rust streaks from the outside of the port bridge wing windows.  At 12h05, the senior second officer checked the safety harness and completed a work permit, as required by the working aloft procedure, but no workplace risk assessment was used in planning the job.
The quartermaster, wearing the safety harness, then started work on a catwalk outside the port bridge wing.  At about 1249, he fell approximately 24 metres onto the wharf below.  He died as a result of the injuries sustained from the fall.  He was an experienced seaman who had been inducted in the ship's safety management system and had done this task many times.

InitialEvent: collision with floaitng or submerged objects
SummaryOfEvents: On 5th February 2006 the tanker TRUST FRIENDSHIP was at sea when she collided with an unidentified object at around 05.40 hours LT. Her hull sustained some damage, but nobody was hurt.
ON 2ND APRIL 2006 THE REFRIGERATED CARGO SHIP "OCEAN THERESE" RAN AGROUND AT LATITUDE 63 24.I N: LONGITUDE 07 45.1 E. AND WAS TAKING WATER IN ENGINE ROOM AND HULL. TWO TUGS ARRIVED TO ASSIST. .

04.02.2006 TIME 1030HRS TO 1215HRS. MASTER COMPLAINED OF A PAIN IN RIGHT SIDE UPPER CHEST. HE CAME ON BRIDGE AND SAT ON BRIDGE WING STILL STATING ABOUT FEELING UNEASINESS AND DIFFICULTY IN NORMAL BREATHING. THE INTERNATIONAL MEDICAL CENTER (CIRM) WAS CONTACTED AND SYMPTOMS WERE PASSED ON TO THEM SEEKING MEDICAL ADVICE IN THIS MATTER. CIRM ADVISED VESSEL TO ADMINISTER OXYGEN AND ALSO ADMINISTER DIAZAPAM TABLET 5MG 12 HOURLY. IMMEDIATELY MASTER SHIFTED TO SHIP HOSPITAL AND OXYGEN ADMINISTERED. SAME TIME DIAZAPAM TABLET ADMINISTERED. IN COURSE OF THIS TRIED TO FEEL THE PULSE AND MEASURE BLOOD PRESSURE. BUT UNABLE TO GET EITHER BODY TEMPERATURE FOUND LOW AND MASSAGE OF FEET AND HANDS CARRIED OUT. MASTER STILL COMPLAINED OF INCREASED BREATHLESSNESS AND OXYGEN WAS ON CONTINUOUSLY AS ADVISED. OBSERVED BODY COLOUR GOING PALE RAPIDLY. AFTER CONTACT WITH CIRM FIRST TIME CONTACTED A DOCTOR GIVING HIM SYMPTOM DETAILS. HE ADVISED MASTER TO BE IN BED, TO BE REASSURED, OXYGEN CONTINUED AND TO REPORT TO HIM LATER. MEANWHILE FOUND MASTERS CONDITION RAPIDLY DETERIORATING AND INCREASED RESTLESSNESS. AT ABOUT 1215 HRS LT FOUND NO RESPONSE FROM MASTER AND NO SIGN OF BREATHING. CHECKED AND FOUND BOTH EYE PUPILS DILATED AND NOT RESPONDING TO LIGHT FINGER NAILS TURNED BLUE. DESPITE SEVERAL ATTEMPTS TO GIVE ARTIFICIAL RESUSCITATION COULD NOT REVIVE THE MASTER. NARRATED THE WHOLE INCIDENT TO DOCTOR, WHO SUGGESTED WE HAD LOST MASTER.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: THE M/B N02 CYLINDER IN LET VALVE HAD A SMALL TROUBLES, AFTER CHANGE THE IN DED VALVE THE MEN WERE NOT INJURED.
SUSPECTED CAUSE OF DEATH: RENAL FAILURE RESUSCITATION FOR 20 MINUTES.

At 0133am Egypt local time on February 3, 2006 (2333UTC 2/2/06) the 11,779 GT Panama registered RORO Passenger vessel, AL SALAM BOCCACCIO 98 sank almost 57 miles from its port of destination, the Egyptian port of  Safaga. There were 1031 lives lost; and 387 persons, including 24 crew members were rescued in this accident.

The survivors were rescued by vessels in the area and the Egyptian Navy. 

While the M/V AL SALAM BOCCACCIO 98 was sailing inbound to Safaga, the auto pilot was disconnected at 190903UTC, and the fire alarm and the auto pilot alarm sounded 190913UTC. It was reported that the vessel caught fire in the RORO deck at 191014UTC by RORO deck watchmen. 

The Master and the crew of the vessel battled the fire for around 4 hours without any success which caused the vessel to list excessively to starboard side, as the water accumulated on the deck because the scuppers were blocked with cargo. Eventually M/V AL SALAM BOCCACCIO 98 capsized at 2333 UTC on February 2, 2006.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: ON THE 1ST OF FEBRUARY 2006 AT 19:40 HRSM/V ALICAN DEVAL WAS PASSING CAPO PASSERO'S LIGHTHOUSE WITH COURSE NE TOWARDS INSTANBUL WHEN THE VESSEL CHANGED HER COURSE TO FIND RECOVERY AT POZZALLO HARBOUR DUE TO ADVERSE WEATHER CONDITIONS. AT 20:30 HRS THE SHIP WAS VERY CLOSE TO THE COAST, SO THE MASTER REALIZED THE DANGER AND GAVE ORDER TO PUT THE STEARING ALL AT LEFT POSITION WITH FULL AHEAD ENGINE. AT 20:33 HRS THE SHIP'S DEFINITIVELY GROUNDED. THE MASTER OF THE SHIP GAVE ORDER TO PUT THE ENGINE FULL ASTERN TRYING TO REFLOAT THE SHIP. AFTER SEVERAL ATTEMPTS THE MASTER ORDERED THE STOP OF THE MAIN ENGINE AND TRANSMITTED THE SITUATION TO THE OWNER'S OFFICE AND TO THE COASTGUARD LOCAL OFFICE OF AUGUSTA.

The fishing vessel MARY-LIS was fishing in Femer Belt on the evening of 1 February 2006, with a crew of three onboard. At around 19.00  hours LT, as the last part of the catch was being tackled in, the ship suddenly heeled to starboard.
The skipper, who was handling the tackle winch from the deck, immediately eased out the winch. The ship did not get back on an even keel, but found balance for a brief moment with the rail under water.
The skipper engaged the propeller and swung the ship around in an attempt to get the sea from aft in order to minimize the list. This was done without any positive result and the ship capsized. 
The skipper managed to get out of the wheelhouse.
The two others crewmembers, who were on the deck amidships, got caught under the shelter deck but they managed to get out.
Together they managed to disengage the life raft from its stowing position on the top of the wheelhouse and to release it. The ship’s second man drifted away while they were working with the life-raft and the others lost contact with him in the dark. 
The water was very cold, and none of the crewmembers had had the time to put on life jackets or immersion suits.
The skipper and the 3rd man entered the life raft and managed to release it from the ship.
The Danish Admiral Fleet was alarmed by the ship’s EPIRB and a search and rescue operation was initiated.

The Danish Admiral Fleet tried to establish contact with the ship via Lyngby Ra-dio. As the ship did not reply to the calls, ships and a rescue helicopter began searching for the ship.

The skipper and the ship’s 3rd man were rescued from the raft by the helicopter approximately 1½ hours after the ship’s EPIRB had been activated.

Shortly after, the ship’s 2nd man was found dead.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:

ON  28-TH OF JANUARY 2006 AT 1534 LT, DURING MOORING OPERATIONS ON BERTH N0 24 OF ROSTOCKER FISHEREIHAFEN, PROTRUDING- EXPOSED 1 METER LONG OUT OF LIMIT PIER (ON THE WATER), THE END ARM OF SHORE TURNING LOADING CONVEYOR HIT ON STARBOARD SIDE SLOP OF LIFEBOAT. THE ABOVE DAMAGE TO MAKE IMPOSSIBLE TO LAUNCH THE LIFEBOAT.
ClassificationSociety1: Polski Rejestr Statkow (Polish Register of Shipping) (PRS)

InitialEvent: OTHER - Loss of cargo containers overboard
SummaryOfEvents: On 2 January 2006, while on passage from Le Havre, France to Newark, USA, MV NEDLLOYD GENOA encountered heavy weather. The weather conditions deteriorated with wind speeds of up to 68 knots. The vessel encountered several swell waves, the final one being 10 to 12m in height.  The wave struck in the vicinity of bay 14. The vessel suffered a container collapse in bay 34 resulting in the loss of 27 containers overboard, 28 containers collapsing on deck and 9 containers remaining secured in position.

SOLASStatus: ALICE: Unknown/unspecified, PINTAIL: Unknown/unspecified, TWIN STAR: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 27th January 2006 the bulk carrier TWIN STAR was entering the Port of Callao, Peru, when she collided with M/V PINTAIL (CYPRUS) and M/V ALICE (MALTA) at approximately 07.17 hours LT. This resulted in the total loss of the m/v TWIN STAR.

A general cargo vessel was leaving the port of Riga where the sea water temperature was -18 deg C.  The vessel was designed with the rudder pintle passing through a watertight compartment which was used for ballast.  At the time of sailing the compartment was full of fresh water which had frozen.

As the vessel tried to manoeuvre the rudder stock twisted.  As a result the vessel entered a nearby shipyard for repairs and was returned to service soon afterwards.

There were no casualties.

On 25 January 2006, the container ship HEINRICH S, sailing under the German flag, aproached the port of Koper, Slovenia.  Once the ship had moored, the gangway was scheduled to be deployed at approximately 07:30.  The crew members working on this task were the boatswain and a deckhand.  Both were positioned on the already lowered gangway to set up the handrails.  Neither the boatswain nor the deckhand was wearing fall prevention gear or a life jacket.  It was intended to raise the inboard handrail first.  In doing so, the boatswain lost his balance and fell onto the quay from a height of approximately 5 metres.  From the quay he rolled into the water and sank immediately.  He could not be recovered alive.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed
